title: Mayor de Blasio Meets With Parents Opposed to State Testing
description: It has been a sore point for the leaders of New York Citys opt-out movement that Mayor Bill de Blasio, who promised to be an advocate for public-school parents, has not fully embraced their protest against state tests.

title: A Futuristic Suit That Gives You a Taste of Old Age
description: What could it possibly be like to be old? The stooped shuffle, the halting speech, the dimming senses.

title: Virginia State Trooper Killed in Bus Station Shooting
description: A Virginia police trooper was killed in the midst of a training exercise at a Greyhound bus station in Richmond, Va., on Thursday after a man he had been talking to pulled out a handgun and shot him, the authorities said.

title: A $200,000 Ballot Error and Other Misprints at New York Citys Board of Elections
description: The New York City Board of Elections has a proofreading problem  and even small mistakes are turning out to be costly.

title: Donald Trump Acknowledges Misstep on Abortion Question
description: Donald J. Trump on Thursday allowed that he might have misspoken on the topic of abortion when he told the MSNBC host Chris Matthews that women who have abortions should face some form of punishment if the procedure is banned.

title: A Dance Between Dealer and Carmaker on Lifting Sales
description: Auto sales hit an all-time high last year in the United States, and many analysts expect another record this year.

title: FanDuel and DraftKings Suspend College Sports Contests
description: HOUSTON  Two days before the Final Four was to begin, the two largest daily fantasy sports sites, FanDuel and DraftKings, announced an agreement with the N.C.A.A. to indefinitely suspend contests involving college sports, bowing to pressure from college sports governing body.

title: Obama and President Xi of China Vow to Sign Paris Climate Accord Promptly
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China said Thursday that they would sign the Paris Agreement on climate change on April 22, the first day the United Nations accord will be open for government signatures.

title: New York Budget Deal With Higher Minimum Wage Is Reached
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and state legislative leaders announced on Thursday that they had reached a budget agreement that would raise the minimum wage in New York City to $15 by the end of 2018, but initiate slower increases elsewhere, even in the citys wealthy suburbs.

title: Tim Howard Says Womens Team Should Fight for Rights
description: Goalkeeper Tim Howard does not spend much time in the United States, but that will change in May when he leaves Everton, his Premier League club for a decade, to join the Colorado Rapids in M.L.S. Howard, 37, figures that is where his career will end, perhaps after a fourth trip to the World Cup, in Russia in 2018. In an interview with The New York Times on Thursday, Howard discussed his career, the pay dispute between U.S. Soccer and the womens national team, and why he took a year off from the national team.

title: A Manhattan Clock Tower Will Keep What Makes It Tick
description: A developers plan to silence one of the last great mechanical tower clocks in New York City  an officially designated landmark, at that  has been thwarted.

title: Fans Back Brooke Henderson at ANA Inspiration
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  In the morning group ahead of Brooke Henderson, Ai Miyazato birdied the par-5 18th hole at Mission Hills Country Club to take the early lead Thursday in the ANA Inspiration, the womens first major, at five-under-par 67. In the group behind Henderson, Lydia Ko, the womens world No. 1, also birdied 18 to post a 70, her best opening score in four starts in this event.

title: Cup Stacking: A Sport Whose Growth Runneth Over
description: William Orrell is the best in the world in his sport. A 17-year-old from North Carolina, Orrell is ranked No. 1 and is the reigning junior Olympic and world champion. He has a popular YouTube channel, a product line named after him, and legions of admiring fans in dozens of countries.

title: In College Basketball, Cavernous Stadiums Tend to Dampen Shooting
description: HOUSTON  For a long time, the most famous  and probably the first  college basketball game played in a large domed stadium was between No. 2 Houston and No. 1 U.C.L.A. in January 1968 at the Astrodome. Despite the presence of center Lew Alcindor, later known as Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Bruins shot 26 of 77 from the field  a paltry 34 percent, held down by Alcindors eye injury  in their 71-69 loss.

title: Shirley Hufstedler, Judge and Cabinets First Education Secretary, Dies at 90
description: Shirley Hufstedler, a pathbreaking former federal judge who became the nations first cabinet-level secretary of education, nominated by President Jimmy Carter, died on Wednesday in Glendale, Calif. She was 90.

title: N.C.A.A. May Act More Forcefully Against Laws Seen as Discriminatory
description: HOUSTON  The N.C.A.A. may soon take a more proactive role in using its power to withhold athletic events from states whose laws are seen as discriminatory, the chairman of the Division I board of directors said Thursday.

title: A Message to Our Loyal Fans
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  High on my list of Things I Would Rather Not Have To Do is give people bad news, but in all likelihood, youve already solved the puzzle and gotten the sad message.

title: Review: In Arthur Millers Crucible, First They Came for the Witches
description: The Devil has returned to Broadway, with the power to make the strong tremble. It is time to be afraid, very afraid, of a play that seemed perhaps merely worthy when you studied it in high school English class.

title: Bernie Sanders Seeks to Win Over New York by Stressing Brooklyn Roots
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont kicked off his effort to win the April 19 New York Democratic presidential primary with a large, boisterous rally in the Bronx on Thursday night, highlighting his local roots and telling New Yorkers that he would work to make sure people have well-paying jobs, affordable housing and access to good public education.

title: Brazil: Judge Removed From Inquiry Into Ex-President
description: Brazils highest court, the Supreme Federal Tribunal, ruled Thursday that a federal investigation into the finances of former President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva should be removed from a crusading anticorruption judge. The interim decision, which is not the courts final ruling and can still be amended by the justices, transfers the jurisdiction for the inquiry to the high court from Judge Srgio Moro, who has overseen the investigation into the graft scandal at Petrobras, the national oil company. The ruling established that intercepts of Mr. da Silvas phone calls should be reviewed by the court because some of the calls included conversations with senior officials who enjoy special judicial standing. The court has still not ruled on whether President Dilma Rousseffs nomination of Mr. da Silva to her cabinet, a move suspended in March by Justice Gilmar Mendes, should be allowed.

title: Obamas Clemency Problem
description: Edina, Minn.  IN my pocket is something ancient: a 1,700-year-old Roman coin. It bears three human images and the word Clementia. That was the name of the Roman goddess of mercy, who was often depicted standing beside (and holding the hand of) the Roman emperor. The message was clear: Mercy was a virtue not only of individuals but also of governments. The framers of the United States Constitution embraced that tradition when they preserved for the president one of the traditional powers of kings: the pardon power.

title: Learning From Obama
description: Like many political junkies, Ive been spending far too much time looking at polls and trying to understand their implications. Can Donald Trump really win his partys nomination? (Yes.) Can Bernie Sanders? (No.) But the primaries arent the only things being polled; were still getting updates on President Obamas overall approval. And something striking has happened on that front.

title: Dude, Wheres My City?
description: SEATTLE  I tend to ignore the usual measurements of what makes a city robust and healthy, the urban bragging points. Along the West Coast, these superlatives roll out with regularity. Seattle, two years ago, was proclaimed the fastest growing city in the United States. San Francisco usually tops the list of most expensive places to live. And Portland, Ore., just posted the highest percentage rise in home prices among major cities.

title: Hints of an End to the Fighting in Yemen
description: After a year of civil war, there is a glimmer of hope for long-suffering Yemen. The main combatants, Iranian-backed Houthi rebels and Saudi-backed government forces, have agreed to a cease-fire  starting April 10, and the United Nations plans to revive peace talks a week later.

description: PERHAPS the most complex trial in history between a sovereign nation, Argentina, and its bondholders  including a group of United States-based hedge funds  officially came to an end yesterday when the Argentine Senate ratified a settlement.

title: My Banished Brother
description: The first time I saw my brother, Jimmy, he was 60 years old, and I was standing at his hospital bedside in the town of Dunkirk, N.Y. He was intubated with intractable pneumonia and lay in a drug-induced sleep, his sparse ginger hair so different from the rest of my brunette family. His ID bracelet showed his birth date: June 26, 1953, exactly 18 months after mine. Until that moment, I hadnt known his birthday.

title: Advice on Boys and Sex, From the Author of Girls and Sex
description: Girls and Sex: Navigating the Complicated New Landscape is a book for both young women and their parents  but primarily their parents  about whats changed for girls with respect to sex. The author, Peggy Orenstein, looks at every aspect of that evolving world in the hope of helping girls learn to develop satisfying intimate relationships, and helping their families offer guidance.

title: How to Grow More Than One Kind of Fruit on a Tree
description: Youll need a very sharp knife, says Paul Barnett, a horticulturalist. Outside his home in southern England, 250 different apple varieties ripen on a single tree  everything from the common Golden Delicious to the rare and bitter cultivars bred for making cider. You could create whats sometimes called a fruit-cocktail tree by grafting a nectarine together with, say, a peach, a plum and an apricot, or manipulating a lemon tree to also grow grapefruits. But Barnett prefers a more traditional approach. Keep apples with apples and pears with pears, he says.

title: The Poor Creatures
description: With the issue of guns in America a hot topic on social media, op-ed pages and presidential debate stages, a new book shows how much of this is in fact old news. Peter Manseaus Melancholy Accidents reprints newspaper reports, spanning the years 1739 to 1916, about accidental shootings, inadvertent suicides and other firearm-related deaths in this country. The book takes its title from the phrase that was regularly used to describe these incidents.

description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Inside the List
description: Where Theres a Will: Cynthia DAprix Sweeney, a former copywriter who returned to school in her 50s, made news a couple of years ago when her debut novel, The Nest, sold for seven figures. (Interviewing her for The Los Angeles Times recently, the author Meredith Maran began, Tell me why I shouldnt hate you.) But in publishing as in politics, a big war chest alone doesnt necessarily ensure success. Money is very important, the eminent publisher Howard Kaminsky told this newspaper in 1985, in an article headlined Why Best Sellers Sell Best, and Other Publishing Secrets. (The short version: Nobody knows.) But theres no guarantee of money making something happen. You need a book with intrinsic value, even if its frivolous intrinsic value. Now Sweeneys novel is out, and early reviews confirm that The Nest  a dark comedy about adult siblings squabbling over their lost inheritance  is worth the buzz. Still, Sweeney has maintained a sense of perspective. Were not people who are flashily trying to get attention, she said of herself and her writer friends in a recent profile in New York magazine. Whatever props we get, its just because were diligent workers. Or, as she put it in her interview with Maran: Its not like I went out there saying, Ill only accept a million dollars for this book. Its lunacy, that much money. On the other hand, I wish the publishing world was structured differently, so an author getting paid a lot for her book wasnt such a rare thing that its news. I wrote the book I wanted to write. I was just hoping someone would want it. She can stop worrying on that count: The Nest enters the hardcover fiction list at No.3.

title: Bernie Sanders Hauls In $44 Million in March Fund-Raising
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont raised $44 million in March, his campaign announced Friday, beating his previous best monthly haul.

title: For Extraordinary Flavor, Add a Few Drops of Squid Ink
description: Black rice with squid ink may sound like the epitome of hip cuisine, something trendy to post on social media, but in fact risotto nero has been on the menu in Italy for quite a long time. The same goes for black spaghetti, pasta al nero. In Spain, arroz negro and black paella have long been standard fare, too.

title: Short Stories
description: PRODIGALSStoriesBy Greg Jackson219 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.

title: Royals Poised for a Third Run
description: Up on the third floor of the museum at the Baseball Hall of Fame, in front of an oversize photograph of giddy players in championship caps and Champagne goggles, is a gray Kansas City Royals jersey. Actually, it used to be gray. Now, preserved for ages, it is caked in Citi Field dirt, smeared from the bottom of the buttons up through the script across the chest.

title: Philip Kerrs The Other Side of Silence, and More
description: Yesterday I tried to kill myself. That sour sneer of a voice belongs to Bernie Gunther, the Prussian homicide cop who survived World War II as the house detective at Berlins fashionable Adlon Hotel. The war has been over for more than 10 years in Philip Kerrs new book, THE OTHER SIDE OF SILENCE (Marian Wood/Putnam, $27). Bernie is currently a concierge at the Grand Htel du Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat, just another deracinated wanted man living quietly and under a false name, like so many other expat denizens of the French Riviera. He even has a wonderful cover story for anyone impolite enough to ask how he spent the war  as a captain in the army Catering Corps, he swears.

title: Saudis Moving to Reduce Dependence on Oil Money
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  A top Saudi prince has announced new elements of a plan to reduce the kingdoms heavy dependence on oil, amid a drop in world prices that has sent shock waves through the Saudi economy.

title: Overall Stagnation in Legal Jobs Hides Underlying Shifts
description: Michael Simkovic is an associate professor of law at Seton Hall Law School.

title: A Place Called Winter, by Patrick Gale
description: A PLACE CALLED WINTERBy Patrick Gale368 pp. Grand Central Publishing. Paper, $15.99.

title: Jane Mendelsohns Burning Down the House
description: BURNING DOWN THE HOUSEBy Jane Mendelsohn287 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

title: It Finally Looks Like the Cubs Turn
description: One team clinched a World Series berth at Wrigley Field last October, but it was not the Chicago Cubs. They never led in the National League Championship Series, falling meekly to the Mets in four games. They responded with the perfect winter.

title: Fraudulent Student Debt Relief Firm Shut Down by Consumer Bureau
description: THE last thing that borrowers struggling with student debt need is to pay for something they could get free. But that has happened to borrowers who have been misled by shady student debt relief companies.

title: The Dig, by John Preston
description: You dig things up at your peril, and a thousand movies tell you why: Buried scandals come back, along with half-dead monsters, jewels with curses and far too many Egyptian queens. John Prestons subtle novel The Dig imagines something even more remarkable: an excavation that carefully, gently exposes the searchers own lives and feelings to the light, just as they brush sand away from buried treasure. He has written a kind of site report that shimmers with longing and regret.

title: And After Many Days, by Jowhor Ile
description: AND AFTER MANY DAYSBy Jowhor Ile246 pp. Tim Duggan Books. $25.

title: Save Room for Pie, by Roy Blount Jr.
description: SAVE ROOM FOR PIEFood Songs and Chewy RuminationsBy Roy Blount Jr.279 pp. Sarah Crichton Books/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $26.

title: Homes for Sale in Nassau and Westchester Counties
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks featured properties are four-bedroom homes in Rye Brook, N.Y., and Massapequa, N.Y.

title: Lust and Wonder, by Augusten Burroughs
description: LUST AND WONDERBy Augusten Burroughs298 pp. St. Martins Press. $26.99.

title: Alligator Candy: A Memoir, by David Kushner
description: ALLIGATOR CANDYA MemoirBy David Kushner243 pp. Simon & Schuster. $26.

title: Danielle Duttons Margaret the First
description: MARGARET THE FIRSTBy Danielle Dutton167 pp. Catapult. Paper, $15.95.

title: The Summer Before the War, by Helen Simonson
description: THE SUMMER BEFORE THE WARBy Helen Simonson479 pp. Random House. $28.

title: Rush Oh! by Shirley Barrett
description: RUSH OH!By Shirley BarrettIllustrated. 355 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $25.

title: An Edinburgh Hotel With a Boutique Sensibility (on Steroids)
description: Standard rooms start at 79 (about $115).

title: In St. Petersburg, Friendly Service and Fresh Fare
description: Pull up to the curb outside Sundial St. Pete, a shopping, dining and entertainment megaplex that crash-landed, Wizard of Oz style, in quaint downtown St. Petersburg. Bypass its beckoning entranceway for the adjacent door to Locale Market, a sprawling two-story emporium that makes Zabars look like a walk-in closet. Pass the glossy hillocks of organic honeycrisp apples, find your way upstairs and, voil!, you have arrived at FarmTable Kitchen, the celebrity chef Michael Minas fresh take on New American fare thats as polished-yet-playful as its name is generic.

title: Paperback Row
description: STOKELY: A Life, by Peniel E. Joseph. (BasicCivitas, $18.99.) After the deaths of Malcolm X and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Stokely Carmichael, who embodied the black power movement, was considered an heir apparent in the battle for civil rights. His life is a crucial, if sometimes overlooked, part of the route black America took to its present understanding of itself and its complex relationship to this country, our reviewer, William Jelani Cobb, wrote.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Greenwich Village, Union Square and Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn.

title: Subtle Shifts at Boutique Fairs in Paris
description: PARIS  The Paris art market, though far smaller than that of New York and London, is where collectors go for speciality events and dealers they cannot find anywhere else.

title: As Floor Fight Looms, G.O.P. Convention Delegates Become a Hot Commodity
description: The chairman of the Republican Party in American Samoa, Utu Abe Malae, began feeling the pressure almost immediately: phone calls, commitment forms, anything the presidential campaigns could do, say or send to nail down his support as a delegate.

title: Editors Choice
description: GIRLS AND SEX: Navigating the Complicated New Landscape, by Peggy Orenstein. (Harper, $26.99.) In Orensteins thought-provoking study, more than 70 interviews with teenagers shed light on their experience of sexuality.

title: Review: Shiki Sushi & Yakitori, in White Plains, Focuses on Fresh Fish Flavors
description: Shiki Sushi & Yakitori is a welcome addition to the many sushi restaurants that have found an enthusiastic audience in Westchester.

title: Poetic Justice
description: Reimagining light verse, free verse and more.

title: Artist Says Brazilian Protesters Copied His Giant Rubber Duck
description: As Brazilians have protested  corruption scandals in their government and called for the impeachment of their president, a Dutch artist has mounted a singular protest of his own. He says the giant yellow rubber duck that protesters have hauled into the streets as a makeshift mascot in the past month is too similar to his own creation.

title: The Dirty Old Men of Pakistan
description: Karachi, Pakistan  IN the world we live in, there is no dearth of pious men who believe that most of the worlds problems can be fixed by giving their women a little thrashing. And this business of a mans God-given right to give a woman a little thrashing has brought together all of Pakistans pious men.

title: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Spar Over Fossil Fuel Donations
Satellite Images Can Pinpoint Poverty Where Surveys Cant
description: An explosion of data has already changed how we market products and politicians. Now a similar innovation is beginning to change how we combat poverty around the world.

title: Helen Mirren and Allison Williams Celebrate David O. Russell
description: This years SAG-Aftra dinner honored the work of the Joy director and the Ghetto Film School, which introduces minority students to filmmaking.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Spain in Our Hearts
description: This week, Adam Hochschild talks about Spain in Our Hearts; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Anna Quindlen discusses Millers Valley; John Williams talks about James McBride and his new biography of James Brown; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: How the $15 Minimum Wage Went From Laughable to Viable
description: BACK in November 2012, when Alterique Hall, an $8-an-hour McDonalds cashier in New York, joined 200 fast-food workers in the first one-day strike for the Fight for $15 campaign, many scoffed at their demand for $15 an hour as pie in the sky. Frustrated with his meager pay, Mr. Hall said, Its time for a change.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Rufus Wainwright
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the singer Rufus Wainwright, whose new album, Take All My Loves: 9 Shakespeare Sonnets, is out on April 22. He shares his list exclusively with T.

title: Chinese Phrase Adds Mystery to Anbangs About-Face on Starwood
description: HONG KONG  An obscure phrase on foreign investment tucked into Chinas insurance regulations is being viewed as stunningly cryptic by Western standards. But the collection of words  not even a full sentence  adds to the mystery surrounding the sudden decision by the Chinese insurer Anbang Insurance Group to walk away from  a $14 billion bid for the Starwood hotel chain.

title: Bruce Baillie, a Film-Poet Collapsing Inner and Outer Space
description: One of the most perfect films that Ive ever seen runs a total of three minutes. Shot in 1966, Bruce Baillies All My Life opens on a pan of an old picket fence framed by the blue sky above and a stretch of summer-brown grass below. On the soundtrack, you can hear the crackle and hiss of an old record thats soon filled with the sounds of Ella Fitzgerald singing All My Life in a 1936 session with the pianist Teddy Wilson.

title: Brussels Airports Reopening Delayed by Security Dispute
description: PARIS  Concerns over security at Brussels Airport have delayed its reopening, the airport operator said on Friday, more than a week after two suicide bombers heavily damaged the departure terminal.

title: Three Bedrooms on Park Avenue for $26.6 Million
description: Two nearly identical apartments more than midway up 432 Park Avenue, the tallest residential tower in the Western Hemisphere, topping out at 1,396 feet, have sold, according to city records, and were the most expensive transactions of the week.

title: Pro-Trump Chalk Messages Cause Conflicts on College Campuses
description: Students at several college campuses are clashing with their administrations and debating the limits of free speech after finding chalk messages voicing support for Donald J. Trump scrawled on campus property.

title: Review: Brick Farm Tavern Brings in the Porcinis, Then Readies the Dirt
description: The temptation to sculpt our food is primordial. I have seen ice swans necking atop a pond of cubed cheese, a cake with breasts, radish art. Still, I was surprised to find at Brick Farm Tavern in Hopewell an edible representation of its very landscape, the farm next door, in the form of a crushed porcini soil, from which I could harvest tiny root vegetables right there on my plate. The enthusiastic description from my waiter had been worthy of an eye roll.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Review: The Grill in Hauppauge Pairs Sound Fundamentals and Worldly Ambitions
description: For 13 years, Michael Silva was a waiter at the Grill Room in Hauppauge. Last November, following the arc of a classic American success story, Mr. Silva took over as owner, along with three business partners, of the restaurant, now simply called the Grill.

title: Managed by Q, an On-Demand Start-Up, Raises $25 Million
description: Managed by Q began two years ago during a boom in on-demand start-ups, offering a service to clean offices in New York City whenever clients needed it.

title: Chocolate Babka
description: A fudge center and chocolate crumb topping give this babka a serious upgrade.

title: A Better Chocolate Babka
description: A chocolate babka has charms that arent always apparent from its dowdy exterior.

title: New Ebola Case Confirmed in Liberia; Guinea Tries a Vaccine
description: A new case of Ebola was confirmed Friday in Liberia, less than three months after that country was declared free of the deadly virus and only three days after the World Health Organization announced the end of an international emergency to contain and eliminate it.

title: The Two Men Producing Some of the Most Exciting Home Design Today
description: Meet Adam Blackman and David Cruz.

title: Blackman Cruz: Rebels of the Design World
description: Adam Blackman and David Cruz prove that the best work comes from the union of two wildly different visions.

title: Alternative Lenders Turn to Seasoned Insiders for Help
description: Alternative lenders are bracing for a regulatory onslaught.

title: Popular Quartz Countertops Pose a Risk to Workers
description: As sleek engineered stone countertops grow in popularity, safety experts are warning that workers who handle them are at particularly high risk from an old workplace hazard  silica, the mineral tied to silicosis, a debilitating and potentially deadly lung disease.

title: Review: The Cottage Aims for Complex Food in a Simple Setting
description: The Cottage, a new restaurant in Westport, is well named. It is small, cozy and very homey, very much like a New England seaside cottage, with sprays of pussy willows on counters and duck motifs wandering along the walls.

title: Obama Rebukes Donald Trumps Comments on Nuclear Weapons
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday questioned Donald J. Trumps fitness for office after statements from the Republican front-runner that the United States and its allies should move away from decades of constraints on the use of nuclear weapons. We dont want somebody in the Oval Office who doesnt recognize how important that is, Mr. Obama said.

title: The Female Identity, Discussed in Art
description: The Barbie doll and her brand of ideal beauty debuted in 1959, and since then she sometimes has been at the center of a debate about societys depictions of women. Critics have complained that Barbie conveys harmful messages about body image to impressionable girls, while others have defended the petite blonde as a miniature representation of an adult woman who breaks glass ceilings.

title: Tech Start-Ups Choose to Stay Private in I.P.O. Standoff
description: Over the last several decades, there were two distinctly dark periods for American technology companies  the bursting of the dot-com bubble in 2000 and the 2008 financial crisis. In those periods, investors had such distaste for risk that technology companies shied away from initial public offerings of stock.

title: At Ethical Brew in Teaneck, Live Folk Music Meets Social Action
description: Paul Goldman was not trying to show off his big-heartedness when he took a first date to an Ethical Brew concert in Teaneck. But he figured demonstrating an interest in charity wouldnt hurt.

title: Global Trade Becomes an Election Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Sexual Assault on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Faith in Justice, Restored
description: To the Editor:

title: Feel the Math
description: The Sanders campaign has come much further than almost anyone expected, to the point where Sanders can have a lot of influence on the shape of the race. But with influence comes responsibility, and its time to lay out some guidelines for good and bad behavior.

title: Review: Race and Rock n Roll in Memphis
description: A goofy white guy who has trouble keeping a job as a stock boy finds success as a radio D.J. A gifted black singer stuck in her brothers underground club gains mainstream recognition and a glossy new life as a star. The two share a tender, bittersweet romance. And all around them, dancers flip and kick their way through songs that evoke the early days of rock n roll: the 1950s.

title: Implausible Supreme Court Scenario
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Owl Shop in New Haven, Smoking Is Encouraged
description: Cool jazz, fine whiskey and smoke-filled rooms used to go together. Then smoking bans arrived, literally changing the atmosphere in jazz clubs. But those bans bypassed establishments like the Owl Shop, a cigar store in the heart of New Haven, and a decade after a major renovation, the shop has transformed itself into a music lounge where the smoke-filled past lives on.

title: In Revenge Porn Case, Criminal Court Decision May Affect Lawsuit
description: A big law firms novel lawsuit filed on behalf of a woman who says she was a victim of revenge pornography may be complicated by a decision in a related criminal case.

title: Slack, a Leading Unicorn, Raises $200 Million in New Financing
description: Some unicorns are still galloping.

title: Review: Saving the Media Seeks Remedy for Ailing Fourth Estate
description: The emergence of the Internet and various forms of digital production and distribution have had a profound and well-documented impact on the media business.

title: Review: Remembering David Bowie, With One Artist and One Song at a Time
description: A tribute is not a resurrection. The Music of David Bowie, at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, manifested Mr. Bowies absence as much as his legacy, in a concert featuring Michael Stipe, Laurie Anderson, Cat Power, Perry Farrell, the Pixies, the Flaming Lips and Hearts lead singer, Ann Wilson.

title: Orange and Bouygues Telecom Call Off Takeover Talks
description: Another telecommunications deal in Europe has fallen apart.

title: Were You Influenced by Zaha Hadids Work?
description: The New York Times would like to hear from women in the architecture field about what Zaha Hadid meant to them.

title: California and New York Lead the Way Toward a Decent Wage
description: California has won the race with New York to become the first state to enact a statewide minimum wage of $15.

title: Jacob Zuma Says Hell Repay South Africa for Home Improvements
description: JOHANNESBURG  A day after South Africas highest court ruled that he had violated the Constitution in a long-running scandal involving government money spent on upgrades to his homestead, President Jacob G. Zuma said Friday that he would pay back part of it in accordance with the ruling, but that he had never meant to undermine the Constitution.

title: Facebook Live, Annoying and Intrusive, Seems to Be Paying Off
description: Facebook says it thinks live video is a big deal. Media companies and amateurs have found validation in surprisingly large audiences by posting on Facebooks new video product, Live. Thousands of people show up to watch whenever a major Facebook page goes live, seemingly out of nowhere. Hundreds leave comments and ask questions. Facebook Live  the product  is working.

title: San Francisco Joins the Growing World of Small Operas
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The War Memorial Opera House, a majestic Beaux-Arts landmark here that seats more than 3,100, is perfectly suited to the spectacle of grand operas like Verdis Don Carlo, which the San Francisco Opera will perform in June. But it would completely overwhelm Svadba-Wedding, Ana Sokolovics intimate a cappella work for six women, whose harmonies are only occasionally punctuated by glockenspiel or rain stick.

title: Andrew Sullivan, Political Blogging Pioneer, Joins New York Magazine
description: Andrew Sullivan, a pioneer in political commentary during the early days of blogging but an infrequently heard voice in the current election cycle, has joined New York Magazine as a contributing editor.

title: Underground Parties in Paris
description: A group called We Are the Oracle hosts semi-secret parties at elusive sites throughout the French capital, including abandoned chateaus and the catacombs.

title: Partying Underground in Pariss Secret Corners
description: PARIS  Inside an abandoned seven-floor, 70-room house near the Arc de Triomphe, more than 650 revelers in floor-length gowns, curly white wigs and feathered masks gathered on a Friday night in January.

title: Condos Rise Where an East Village Church Stood
description: In the East Village, it became something of a guessing game: What would happen at Avenue A and East 12th Street, which languished as a dusty lot after the Mary Help of Christians Church complex was razed in 2013?

title: An Exemplary Foster Father, a String of Suspicions and Sexual-Abuse Charges
description: When New York City needed foster care for vulnerable boys with emotional problems, the answer was often the Long Island home of Cesar Gonzales-Mugaburu.

title: Pabst Raids Dads Beer Fridge as It Looks to the Future
description: LOS ANGELES  Eugene Kashper looks the part of someone who likes to throw back a few P.B.R.s from time to time  hipster glasses, scruffy facial hair, faded T-shirts and jeans and well-worn sneakers.

title: Turkey Has Forcibly Returned Thousands of Refugees to Syria, Amnesty International Says
description: CAIRO  Turkeys government has forced thousands of Syrian refugees to return to their war-torn country in recent months, exposing the perils of an agreement that allows Greece to send refugees arriving by boat back to Turkey, Amnesty International said in a report issued Friday.

title: With College Transfer Rules, Hypocrisy Never Sits Out a Year
description: HOUSTON  Have you heard the one about Spike Albrecht, the University of Michigans senior point guard? He is seeking medical redshirt status because he missed most of this season after double hip surgery. Assuming he gets it, hell have a year of athletic eligibility left after he graduates. But if he is going to play college basketball as a graduate student, he will have to do it somewhere besides Michigan. Last year, his coach, John Beilein, told Albrecht and his father, Chuck, that were one over for scholarships next year, and were recruiting a top point guard, according to an article  this week by Pat Forde of Yahoo Sports.

title: Seeing Red
description: When the photographer Frank Fournier revisited his work from New York in the late 1970s, he noticed a surprising recurrence of red shades.

title: Seeing Red
description: In 1965, the French director Jean-Luc Godard was asked about the amount of blood in his movie Pierrot le Fou. Godard objected. Not blood, he said. Red. For Frank Fournier, 68, who began photographing in New York in 1976 after moving from France, the color red emerged as a surprise message rising from the citys fabric. At the time, he was just learning to work with color film, walking the city and experimenting with the sensual properties of Kodachrome stock. I was following the light, he said the other morning. I didnt realize I was following red. Decades later, when he was editing images from that period, he noticed the recurrence of red shades. Red could be flashy or low-key, as bright as neon or as staid and solid as faded bricks. It really popped out intensely, Mr. Fournier said. You would think in New York yellow was the color to catch, because of the cabs.

title: Helen Mirren, Chris Tucker and Allison Williams Talk About Race at SAG-Aftra Dinner
description: Parker Posey couldnt recall the last time she worked opposite a black or minority actor. Isnt that terrible? she said.

title: New Yorks Age of Genius
description: David Reid borrows the title of his rambling interpretive historical essay about 20th-century New York cultural iconography from an observation Gore Vidal made in The New York Review of Books decades ago.

title: To Buy or Rent a Home? Weighing Which Is Better
description: Rob Austin and his wife, Natalia, have a 10-month-old son, healthy incomes and plenty of cash in the bank for a down payment on a house. But they are happily renting a townhouse in Pasadena, Calif., with no plans to buy for now, given the frothy prices in their area.

title: How Are New York City Taxi Plates Assigned?
description: Q. Is there any formula to the way New York City taxi plates are assigned? Can they be identified by borough? Also, what is the significance of the small letter after the license number? I have seen A to H.

title: Our Natural History, Endangered
description: When people talk about natural history museums, they almost always roll out the well-worn descriptive dusty, to the great exasperation of a curator I know. Maybe hes annoyed because hes spent large sums of his museums money building decidedly un-dusty climate-controlled storage sites, and the word implies neglect. (Let me know, the curator advises by email, if you want to hear me rant for an hour or so on this topic.)

title: The Winter Flounder, a Master of Disguise With a Wandering Eye
description: Nothing suits a winter flounder like cold water. Unlike most local fish, winter flounder enter shallow bays and coves in midwinter to spawn and stay until the sun warms the water to temperatures above what they prefer. This habit earned these flatfish their name. It also brought them closer to humans, who found that they were fine eating.

title: Review: For Roomful of Teeth, Its All About the Polyphony
description: Prima la musica, e poi le parole (First the music, then the words)  the title of a Salieri opera  often seems to be the ethos of Roomful of Teeth, a remarkable vocal octet that incorporates Inuit throat singing, yodeling and traditions from Georgia, Korea and India into its concerts.

title: TVs Genealogy Craze Yields Game Shows and Paper Chases but Also Interesting Lessons
description: All sorts of people are swabbing inside their cheeks and spitting into collection tubes these days in the interest of researching their ancestry. Yet an old-fashioned paper chase remains far more telegenic, as TLCs Who Do You Think You Are? demonstrates once again when it returns for a new season on Sunday.

title: A Palestinian Teachers Method
description: Hanan Hroub, an elementary-school teacher, with her students in the West Bank city of Ramallah in February. She recently won a $1 million global education prize.

title: A Restaurant Where Soil Ends Up on the Plate
description: Two New Yorkers relocated to Hopewell, N.J., to farm. In 2015, they added a restaurant, with an avant garde take on farm-to-table staples.

title: Review: Spanish Nights of Falla and Massenet
description: With a triumvirate of cultural power players behind its creation, the 1919 premiere of The Three-Cornered Hat was virtually assured of success. Produced by the superstar impresario Diaghilev, with music by Manuel de Falla and sets by Picasso, the ballet tells a tale of adultery narrowly  and comically  averted in an Andalusian village.

title: Zaha Hadid: More Than a Female Architect
description: London  WHEN I was still an architecture student at Yale, I got stuck in New York City traffic with one of my professors, Zaha Hadid, and her chauffeur. I asked her whether she had any advice for me, a young female architecture student graduating into a depressed market dominated by men. She simply said, Come work for me.

title: The Soviet Style for the Upper Class
description: On Wednesday morning, Ivo Lupis commanded an 87-year-old woman up to the swinging rings, then the trapeze, and then to the mat for some forward rolls.

title: Unable to Pay $100 Bail, Homeless Man Dies in New Hampshire Jail
description: In their last conversation, Jeffrey Pendleton told his father that he was doing well, living in New Hampshire with a woman and working at a Burger King restaurant.

title: Amid Clashes, Greece Presses On With Plan to Deport Migrants
description: PARIS  Violent clashes erupted in Greek refugee camps among panicked migrants as Greece and the European Union pressed ahead on Friday with their intention to expel them from Europe and deport thousands back to Turkey, despite strong objections from rights groups and United Nations relief officials who say the plan is illegal and inhumane.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: Spain in Our Hearts
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Friday Night Music: Quilt at Kennedy Center
description: In my not-so-secret identity as 60-something wannabe hipster, I have an overwhelming preference for live performances; I go to concerts as often as schedule allows (which isnt often enough  but going tonight!), but videos are often a pretty good second best. And I ran across this concert video of a band I still hope to see one of these days. So much great music, so little time.

title: From the Archives: Martha Graham and Her Dancers
description: Photographs of Graham and her works as the Martha Graham Dance Company celebrates its 90th-anniversary season.

title: Of Stew and Soju
description: Pocha 32, in Koreatown, is modeled after the humble street stalls in South Korea that serve comfort food and stiff drinks to late-night revelers.

title: Tented Walls and Family-Style Korean Dishes at Pocha 32
description: If many customers dont fully remember their evening at Pocha 32, where dinner frequently begins after 2 a.m. and nearly always includes the Korean spirit soju, they can at least leave behind proof that they were there.

title: Living and Breathing Martha Graham
description: It was 1943 at Schraffts, and Agnes de Mille, full of self-doubt in spite of the successful opening of Oklahoma!, was having a rough day. She spilled her worries to Martha Graham, who told her: You have to keep yourself open and aware to the urges that motivate you. Keep the channel open.

title: Choreographers Who Dare to Risk Boredom in the Name of Insight
description: At the Berlin Conference of 1884-85, European powers met to divvy up Africa. In 2065 BC, the Adham Hafez Company imagines a similar conference, decades from now, in which power is reversed and African queens set out a new world order.

title: How DJ Ruckus, Also Known as Greg Andrews, Spends His Sundays
description: DJ Ruckus (Greg Andrews) travels the world, from Paris to Beijing, spinning at more than 200 events a year, including private parties for high-profile clients like his cousin Lenny Kravitz, and runway shows for designers like Alexander Wang and Louis Vuitton. If I manage to catch a break, its always on a Sunday, said Mr. Andrews, 32, who lives in Alphabet City in Manhattan. He usually spends the day with his fiance, the Australian model Shanina Shaik, 25. SHIVANI VORA

title: Libyas U.N.-Backed Government Ventures Farther Into Tripoli
description: CAIRO  The leaders of Libyas fragile new unity government cautiously expanded their authority in Tripoli on Friday, venturing from their fortified base in the city port to make public appearances in a downtown mosque and square, while political factions from nearby towns pledged their allegiance.

title: Police Say Woman Lied About Slashing in Manhattan
description: A woman wearing a headscarf lied when she claimed she was slashed in Lower Manhattan by a man who called her a terrorist, the police said on Friday.

title: Brave Testimony Helps Convict Costa Rican Slayers of a Turtle Conservationist
description: There is seemingly no end to the violence against environmentalists and community-rights campaigners on the worldsloosely-governed resource frontiers.The murder last month ofBerta Cceres, a much-lauded Honduran indigenous activist, was just the most prominent recent example.

title: As China Evolves, the Artist Cao Fei Is Watching
description: Fresh off the plane from Art Basel Hong Kong this week, the Chinese artist Cao Fei was stationed at MoMA PS1, ready to supervise the installation of her first United States museum retrospective. At 37, she seemed too young to warrant an extensive survey. Dressed in a black hoodie and fashionable striped pants, Ms. Cao could have been one of the characters in her early videos, teenagers influenced by hip-hop culture or 20-somethings costumed as Japanese manga characters.

title: Memo to Kia Dealers
description: In a memo sent to dealers on March 14, Kia instructed them to hold those cars for a minimum of 15 days as test drive models.

title: Why New York Citys Waterworks Works
description: One hundred years ago, mountain water from the Catskills began flowing into the cupped hands of New York City.

title: Memo to Nissan Dealers
description: Nissan Motor has dealers buy cars for use in what it calls dealer rental fleets. The cars are supposed to remain in rental service for 90 days, and some are in fact rented by dealership customers. But occasionally, Nissan waives the 90-day rule.

title: John Kasich Presses Super PAC to Pull Ad Assailing Ted Cruz
description: Gov. John Kasich is no fan of Senator Ted Cruz, but he does not want his allies borrowing one of Donald J. Trumps go-to insults.

title: Rupert Murdoch and Jerry Hall? The Fascination of Odd Couples
description: The cackling can sound like a chicken who is facing his certain death; the eye rolling suggests that vaudeville is not dead.

title: Review: House Rules and All Kinds of Games
description: People play a lot of games in A. Rey Pamatmats intriguing, untidy House Rules, produced by Ma-Yi Theater Company. They compete at gin rummy and Monopoly, arguing over whether to leave money on the Free Parking space. They try to learn a variation of mah-jongg and battle over sungka, a traditional Filipino pastime played with cowrie shells.

title: Female Architects on the Significance of Zaha Hadid
description: The death of Zaha Hadid at 65 on Thursday has reverberated through quarters of the architecture world from Baghdad, where she was born, to New York, London and Guangzhou, China, where she built. But the sense of loss, mounting online, has been most pronounced among female architects, who saw Ms. Hadid as a rare beacon of hope for their own success in a male-dominated field and a barometer of its continuing sexism.

title: Cirque Replaces Lead Actor in Broadway-Bound Paramour
description: Cirque du Soleil, citing creative differences, said it had made a late-in-the-game decision to replace one of the lead actors in its first Broadway show, the musical Paramour.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Nuclear Security, Donald Trump, Saudi Arabia
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Teslas New Model 3 Jump-Starts Demand for Electric Cars
description: DETROIT  Despite a steady stream of new models from a number of automakers, sales this year of electric and hybrid vehicles have failed to keep pace with the growth in the overall American market.

title: Evening Hours | Easter
description: Bill Cunningham covers Easter services and festivities around New York.

title: More Details on Bankers Tragic Death, but Questions Persist
description: Wall Street has always had a problem balancing the staffing equation: having the right number of people around to give those employed a meaningful work experience but also free time to unwind and recharge.

title: Bill Cunningham | Hopping
description: At the Fifth Avenue Easter/spring promenade: a suit from when Hollywood led the fashion world in World War II and two men in a symphony of gray, white and black. Also, men in outfits paved in candy corn and in jellybeans.

title: Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona Signs Abortion Drug Bill That Skirts New F.D.A. Protocol
description: One day after the Food and Drug Administration relaxed its guidelines for use of an abortion-inducing drug, Arizonas Republican governor, Doug Ducey, signed a bill on Thursday requiring abortion clinics to follow the earlier protocol, which medical experts have described as outdated, overly restrictive and less healthy for women.

title: Sikh Captain Says Keeping Beard and Turban Lets Him Serve U.S. and Faith
description: The Army has granted a decorated officer, who is Sikh, permission to wear a religious beard and turban in uniform, ending a protracted battle that pitted individual religious freedom rights against what the military said was a need for uniformity and strict safety standards.

title: Daniel Berehulak Named Photojournalist of the Year
description: Daniel Berehulak was named Photojournalist of the Year and The New York Times dominated the awards in the National Press Photographers Associations Best of Photojournalism 2016 contest.

title: Daniel Berehulak Named Photojournalist of the Year
description: Daniel Berehulak has been named the Photojournalist of the Year for large-circulation publications in the National Press Photographers Associations Best of Photojournalism 2016 contest. Scott McIntyre of The Naples Daily News in Florida was selected as the Photojournalist of the Year for smaller-circulation publications.

title: New York State Steps Up Arrests of Parole Violators
description: The police and parole officers of Team 7 took up positions around the Harlem apartment building  a few at the fire escape, some out front on 140th Street, the rest in the lobby  in case Cynthia Garrett turned out to be a runner.

title: Review: Enrico D. Wey, Transcending Boundaries at Danspace Project
description: During the premiere of his new solo at Danspace Project on Thursday, Enrico D. Wey began to drip sweat. Thats not unusual for a dancer, but here it felt momentous. Mr. Wey stood firmly in the center of a square white floor, his torso bent forward in a passage of slow, muscular, trembling movement. Though on display, surrounded by the audience on all sides, he was also hidden, his long black hair veiling his face. His body coursed with tension, and the drops of sweat, pooling at his feet, confirmed that he was working hard. Or were they tears? Either way, he seemed suddenly vulnerable, a shift that narrowed the distance between him and us.

title: Steven Soderbergh on Rebooting The Girlfriend Experience for TV
description: What do The Girlfriend Experience, the new Starz television show about prostitution, and The Girlfriend Experience, the 2009 Steven Soderbergh film about prostitution, have in common?

title: Does a Video Glimpse Into Chicagos Year of Violence?
description: CHICAGO  As the video begins, a man in a baseball cap and sweatshirt is on a street, moving in a circle as he talks into a camera he seems to be holding. Suddenly the sounds of pops, one after the next, interrupt. The camera flips to different views, then lands face up, pointed to the sky, as a gunman steps into clear view, still shooting.

title: Somali Militant Leader Believed Killed in Drone Strike
description: WASHINGTON  An American drone strike in Somalia is believed to have killed a key leader of the Shabab militant group, a United States government official said Friday, as the Obama administration continued its intensified air campaign against the group.

title: Bull in Queens Is Captured, and Jon Stewart Chauffeurs It to Freedom
description: For a bull lost in a bustling stretch of Jamaica, Queens, the green lawn outside a school building was probably the closest thing to a pasture.

title: Supreme Court Fight Rescues a Justice From Obscurity
description: WASHINGTON  There are the legal giants of the Supreme Court, justices such as John Marshall, Louis D. Brandeis and Earl Warren. Then there is Rufus W. Peckham.

title: Ronnie Corbett, of The Two Ronnies British Comedy Team, Dies at 85
description: Ronnie Corbett, the diminutive comedian who teamed with Ronnie Barker to delight audiences for almost two decades on the hit BBC comedy show The Two Ronnies, died on Thursday. He was 85.

title: A Yoga Master, the King of Baba Cool, Stretches Out an Empire
description: HARIDWAR, India  Sitting on an orange sofa set over a Persian carpet, in a gated office park of freshly painted tan buildings and manicured lawns, Baba Ramdev is surrounded by the trappings of any major corporate leader almost anywhere in the world.

title: F.D.A. Proposes a Limit on Arsenic in Rice Cereal for Babies
description: The Food and Drug Administration proposed on Friday a limit for inorganic arsenic in infant rice cereal, saying that this common starter food is a leading source of exposure to the toxin.

title: The Power of C.E.O. Activism
description: OVER the past few years, chief executives  including prominent figures like Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs and Howard Schultz of Starbucks  have been taking public stances on controversial issues like race relations and gender equality that are unrelated to their core businesses. Its headline-grabbing stuff. But is it politically effective?

title: Thousands Could Lose Food Stamps as States Restore Pre-Recession Requirements
description: WASHINGTON  Hundreds of thousands of people could soon lose food stamps as states reimpose time limits and work requirements that were suspended in recent years because of high unemployment, state officials and advocates for the poor said Friday.

title: Police Officer in Mail Carriers Arrest Is Stripped of His Badge
description: A lieutenant with the New York Police Department who oversaw the arrest of an on-duty mail carrier in Brooklyn has been stripped of his gun and badge and placed on administrative duty.

title: A Showdown Between Mohaymen and Nyquist Before the Kentucky Derby
description: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla.  The showdown is billed as East vs. West, harking back to a golden era of horse racing when War Admiral and Seabiscuit ruled opposite coasts and fans clamored for a meeting to settle the score once and for all.

title: Yankees Pick C.C. Sabathia for 5th Rotation Slot
description: MIAMI  Sixteen coaches, scouts and executives convened late Thursday afternoon as the Yankees prepared to break camp in Tampa, Fla., and board a flight to Miami for their final two exhibition games. For an hour, they debated, dissected and discussed the merits of the two candidates for the final spot in their starting rotation.

title: North Carolina Law May Risk Federal Aid
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is considering whether North Carolinas new law on gay and transgender rights makes the state ineligible for billions of dollars in federal aid for schools, highways and housing, officials said Friday.

title: New Yorks Path to $15 Minimum Wage: Uneven, and Bumpy
description: With the budget agreement worked out in Albany this week, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo can say he has steered New York onto the road to a statewide minimum wage of $15 an hour. But the trip will be uneven, probably quite bumpy in spots, and its duration remains uncertain.

title: Mike Hopkins, Boeheims Successor, Is Learning to Ride Waves as Head Coach
description: HOUSTON  Mike Hopkins, the longtime Syracuse assistant and the designated successor to Coach Jim Boeheim, went bodysurfing with his family late last summer in the waters off the Southern California coast. Bodysurfing is generally benign, but even experienced watermen like Hopkins can be surprised once in a while. When a wave caught him unprepared, his board slipped and smacked him in the face.

title: Eric Engberg, CBS Newsman, Dies at 74; Pioneered Political Fact-Checking
description: Eric Engberg, a former CBS News correspondent who hosted the CBS Evening News segment Reality Check, which was aimed at keeping politicians honest, died last Sunday at his home in Palmetto, Fla. He was 74.

title: Islanders Play for Home Ice, Be It Ever So Slushy
description: EAST MEADOW, N.Y.  The Islanders gathered Friday for their annual team photo at their new practice center, which is close to Nassau Coliseum, their former rink. They were all smiles, though their mood was surely tempered by the knowledge that they would be without their top defenseman, Travis Hamonic, who was injured during Thursdays win over Columbus. The Islanders are also concerned about a key element where they now play  namely, poor ice conditions at Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

title: Second Member of Amateur Crew Dies During Round-the-World Race
description: BOSTON  The amateur sailors aboard the yacht IchorCoal had already had to deal with death and mourning in September, when their crew mate Andrew Ashman was killed in an onboard accident near the Portuguese coast shortly after the start of the Clipper Round the World Race.

title: Man Dies After Construction Site Fall in Brooklyn
description: A construction worker died after he was struck by debris and fell in a shaft at a site in Brooklyn on Friday, the police said.

title: Angela Merkels Unpopular Goodness
description: Berlin  WHEN I returned to Berlin recently after a few months away, a friend asked me to try a new Chinese restaurant in Kreuzberg, a hip multiethnic neighborhood in the city. Its close to the subway station Kottbusser Tor, he texted. But take a cab, otherwise its too dangerous.

title: In Miami, Facing Risk of Zika With Resolve but Limited Resources
description: MIAMI  One recent sunny morning, Chalmers Vasquez, Miami-Dade Countys mosquito control manager, peered into a rain-filled Miller High Life bottle in a weedy backyard.

title: Why Should Never Trump Mean Ted Cruz?
description: With more than half of the 2016 presidential primary races in the history books, Republicans desperate to deny Donald Trump their partys nomination now say Wisconsin, where Ted Cruz is leading, will show that their effort has turned the tide. They shouldnt start bragging yet.

title: Donald Trump Steps Awkwardly Into Abortion Debate for Second Time This Week
description: Donald J. Trump said on Friday that current laws on abortion should remain intact, but also agreed with those who see abortion as murder in an interview taped for CBSs Face the Nation.

title: Crib Note
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Its a RED LETTER day when we get a Brad Wilber/Doug Peterson puzzle. They are consistently well-filled, well-clued and really good at tripping me up.

title: Trump, Truth and Abortion
description: Maybe Donald Trump did everyone a favor with his famous jail-the-women comment. When he blurted out that there has to be some form of punishment for anyone who has an abortion, he blew the cover off the carefully constructed public face of the anti-choice movement.

title: With Skid Over, Mets Decide on Roster for Opener
description: LAS VEGAS  When the Mets pitchers, including perhaps the best rotation in baseball, convened for their first meeting this spring, Manager Terry Collins singled out Logan Verrett for providing maybe the best start of 2015. Collinss point? Even if the rotation is set, the Mets need contributions from everyone.

title: Why Texas Is Deep in My Heart
description: Houston  MARCH was not a good month for a certain kind of Texas loyalist. There was the State Board of Education candidate, Mary Lou Bruner of Mineola, who insisted that President Obama had been a male prostitute in his youth.

title: A Nuclear Job Half Done
description: As he ended the Nuclear Security Summit on Friday, President Obama could claim some success in leading the international community to curb the amount of nuclear materials that could fall into terrorists hands.

title: Budget Deadline Keeps New York Legislators Up All Night
description: ALBANY  There was an impromptu round of salsa dancing on the Assembly floor, a spirited exchange of hostilities in the Senate and an untold number of last-minute trips to the Dunkin Donuts  the nearest purveyor of decent caffeine  on the first floor of the State Capitol.

title: Hamas Releases Photographs Said to Show Captured Israelis
description: JAFFA, Israel  The armed wing of the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas showed photographs on Friday of four Israelis, two of whom it said were captives being held in Gaza. Two others were Israeli soldiers who were killed during the 2014 conflict in Gaza, Hadar Goldin and Oron Shaul.

title: Time for South Africas Jacob Zuma to Step Down
description: Cronyism, corruption and scandal have swirled around Jacob Zuma since before he became president of South Africa in May 2009, and the muck has only deepened since. On Thursday the countrys highest court ruled that he had violated the Constitution by refusing to pay back millions that the government spent improving his home.

title: Abortion and Punishment
description: DONALD J. TRUMP gave his primary opponents a gift when he said this week that if abortion is outlawed, there has to be some form of punishment for the woman. He let them look as if they cared about women.

title: Judge Cancels Pretrial Hearing at Guantnamo in Sept. 11 Case
description: WASHINGTON  A military judge on Friday abruptly canceled a two-week pretrial hearing scheduled to open on Monday at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, in the case against Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other detainees accused of aiding the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Tests on Knife Rule Out Link to O.J. Simpson Case, Police Say
description: A knife reportedly found at a home that once belonged to O. J. Simpson is not connected to the 1994 killings of Mr. Simpsons ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald L. Goldman, the Los Angeles Police Department said on Friday.

title: Frank De Felitta, Audrey Rose Horror Novelist and Documentarian, Dies at 94
description: Frank De Felitta, who wrote Audrey Rose, a best-selling horror novel about reincarnation, because, he said, he suspected that his own son might be channeling a dead pianist, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 94.

title: Despite Protests on State Testing, Some New York City Parents Are Happy to Opt In
description: With the New York State math and reading tests set to begin next week, the opt-out movement has made noise from the State Education Department to City Hall, with opponents of the tests pushing for even more students to sit them out this year.

title: Harold Morowitz, 88, Biophysicist, Dies; Tackled Enigmas Big and Small
description: Harold J. Morowitz, a boundlessly curious biophysicist who tackled mind-boggling enigmas ranging from the origin of life to the thermodynamics of pizza, died on March 22 in Falls Church, Va. He was 88.

title: On the Trail: The Week of March 27
description: Candidates campaigned across New York, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin this week.

title: City Began Inquiry Into Sale of Nursing Home to Developer Before Mayor de Blasio Knew of Deal
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has said he knew nothing about how his administration had allowed a Lower East Side nursing home, once protected from development by a restrictive deed, to be sold to make way for luxury condominiums.

title: With Little Up for Grabs, Knicks Defeat Nets
description: The Knicks jogged onto the court at Madison Square Garden on Friday night to the song Trophies by Drake that is often used by teams to inspire their chase to attain significant goals.

title: Anti-Vaccine Film, Pulled From Tribeca Film Festival, Draws Crowd at Showing
description: A roiling controversy over the truthfulness and intent of a documentary about the widely debunked link between vaccines and autism did not keep theatergoers away from its premiere on Friday. Several dozen people (and more than a handful of reporters) arrived for the first showing of Vaxxed: From Cover-Up to Catastrophe at the Angelika Film Center in Manhattan, along with a producer and co-writer of the film, and some of its distributors.

title: Mans Confession in Transgender Womans Death Is Admissible, Judge Rules
description: A Brooklyn man charged with manslaughter in the beating death of a transgender woman in Harlem told prosecutors and detectives he had been flirting with her just moments before the attack, unaware that she was transgender.

title: What to Watch Saturday
description: For those in another universe who still havent caught the latest Star Wars installment, iTunes provides it for less than the price of a movie ticket. Trainwreck, the Amy Schumer vehicle, makes its way to cable. And Peter Dinklage  Tyrion Lannister to Game of Thrones fans  hosts Saturday Night Live.

title: Corrections: April 2, 2016
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This is close to a Goldilocks scenario.

title: Every Woman Whos Ever Been Labeled Crazy
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: And the Awards for Best Audio Fiction Go to
description: First came the Oscars, then the Tonys. Now, get ready for the Sarahs.

title: High Times Wants to Be the Playboy of Pot
description: Picture a mood-lit Las Vegas casino, at first glance indistinguishable from any other pleasure palace on the Strip: salarymen hunch over $20 blackjack tables as waitresses with plunging necklines circle the floor.

title: The Story of Their Life
description: Gloria Vanderbilt and Anderson Cooper chart their family landscape in a new documentary and a memoir.

title: At Home With Gloria Vanderbilt
description: Sometimes Anderson Cooper imagines himself as the Thomas Cromwell to his mothers Henry VIII, the voice of reason  the tether  to her buoyant impulsiveness. And sometimes he pictures Gloria Vanderbilt, who has been in the public eye since her birth 92 years ago, as an emissary from a distant star, marooned on this planet and trying to make sense of it all.

title: Third Man Is Charged in Belgium Over Foiled Plot in France
description: PARIS  A third man has been charged in Belgium in connection with a foiled plot to stage a major terrorist attack in France, officials said Saturday.

title: A.C.P.T. 2016: The Fun Begins
description: SPECIAL POST  Deep inside the Ballroom at the Stamford, Connecticut Marriott Hotel, puzzle creator Eric Berlin paces the floor, going over the myriad last-minute details in his head. One forgotten clue, one slip-up in planning and the whole exercise  a multi-puzzle, interactive escape room where solvers have to join forces to put the clues together in order to be released  falls apart. Fortunately for the hundreds of people who willingly locked themselves into a hotel ballroom just to solve puzzles, everything went off without a hitch.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from an island inhabited by pigs in the Bahamas to a chess tournament in Moscow.

title: American Anger: Its Not the Economy. Its the Other Party.
description: Americans are angry. Thats the sentiment that many believe is driving the 2016 election. They are angry because the rich are getting richer, the average guy is struggling and the government in Washington hasnt done anything to stop the trend.

title: A Little Variety
description: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES  This weeks puzzles include:

title: Rift Among Navy SEALs Over Members Who Cash In on Brand
description: Eric Greitenss bid for governor of Missouri hinges on his experience as a Navy SEALs member, which he has chronicled in three books and promotes on his campaign web site, where he is pictured wearing his combat uniform, holding a rifle. In the SEALs we learned, there is no prize for second place in a gunfight,  he said recently on Twitter.

title: Mike and John on Annotation Terror and Annoying Video Alerts
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mr. Manjoo is off this week, so John Herrman, a David Carr fellow, is filling in.

title: When Your Dog Meets the Co-op Board
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Fighting Between Azerbaijan and Armenia Flares Up in Nagorno-Karabakh
description: MOSCOW  Heavy fighting broke out Saturday in Nagorno-Karabakh, an Armenian separatist enclave in Azerbaijan and a longtime ethnic tinderbox in the South Caucasus region.

title: Bill Green, Who Dissected Washington Post Scandal, Dies at 91
description: Bill Green, who as the ombudsman for The Washington Post in 1981 delivered a blistering verdict on journalistic lapses in response to a Post article about an 8-year-old heroin addict that was debunked the day after it won a Pulitzer Prize, died on Monday in Durham, N.C. He was 91.

title: Obama Gets Scant Credit in Indiana Region Where Recovery Was Robust
description: ELKHART, Ind.  Seven years ago President Obama came to this northern Indiana city, where unemployment was heading past 20 percent, for his first trip as president. Ed Neufeldt, the jobless man picked to introduce him, afterward donned three green rubber bracelets, each to be removed in turn as joblessness fell to 5 percent in the county, the state and the nation.

title: Big Love for Little Monkeys That Help People With Limited Mobility
description: Q. What does Helping Hands do, and what does your job involve?

title: Variety: A Playful Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Put another book on the pile for me. WORD WATCHING, by British comedian ALEX HORNE, looks like a fabulously funny exploration of wordplay and its no secret that I use the acrostic to decide which books to read more often than I use the Book Review.

title: Trump Does It His Way
description: WASHINGTON  YOU could hear how hard it was for Donald Trump to say the words.

title: Guatemalan Womens Claims Put Focus on Canadian Firms Conduct Abroad
description: LOTE OCHO, Guatemala  Her husband was away in the fields, she said, when the truckloads of soldiers, police officers and mining security officials arrived. A half-dozen armed men swarmed into her one-room house, blocking her exit and helping themselves to the meal she had made for her children.

title: Electoral Map Is a Reality Check to Donald Trumps Bid
description: Donald J. Trumps presidential candidacy has stunned the Republican Party. But if he survives a late revolt by his rivals and other leaders to become the partys standard-bearer in the general election, the electoral map now coming into view is positively forbidding.

title: After WikiLeaks Revelation, Greece Asks I.M.F. to Clarify Bailout Plan
description: Greece called on the International Monetary Fund on Saturday to explain whether it was seeking to usher Athens toward bankruptcy ahead of a pivotal referendum in June on Britains membership in Europe. Greeces comments came after I.M.F. officials raised questions in a private discussion published by WikiLeaks about what it would take to get Greeces creditors to agree to debt relief.

title: A.C.P.T. 2016: Ready? GO
description: SPECIAL POST  Theres a special part of the American Crossword Tournament that I find particularly thrilling, and I want to share it with you. Its not necessarily the Championship rounds, although those are definitely exciting. The entertainment is great. But thats not what thrills me.

title: Even in a Warming World, It Will Still Snow Somewhere
description: Actually: Anyone who utters an argument like this is mixing up climate and weather.

title: Why Slaves Graves Matter
description: I GREW up in a small rural town in West Tennessee. My family is rooted in that region, where my ancestors were once enslaved. In the 1970s, when I was a teenager, we regularly attended an old country church that was located in the curve of a gravel road and surrounded by undeveloped Southern land. The church had rustic wooden floors, handmade pews and a piano that was often missing an accompanist. The congregation didnt mind though; they made their own music, tapping the pews and the floor as they sang.

title: Philadelphia Is in the Final Four ... and in the Cellar
description: HOUSTON  It is the best of times, it is the worst of times. It is the spring of hope, it is the winter of despair. They may have the best basketball team in the country, and they definitely have the worst basketball team in the country.

title: Claims of a Ponzi Scheme in the Collapse of a Rare-Wine Seller
description: From the outside, the Premier Cru wine store in Berkeley, Calif., looked like a traditional, upscale wine seller. The 29,000-square-foot store was lined with tapestries, wood shelves and a rare wine room stocked with trophy Bordeaux and Burgundies.

title: A Spring of Discontent for Canadian Hockey
description: OTTAWA  Canada, where hockey passion is so intense that weddings on rinks are a thing, will not have a single team in the N.H.L.s Stanley Cup playoffs. Its as if Argentina were shut out of the worlds premier tango competition, or France had no representation in the Michelin Guide.

title: As Warriors Near a Record, the Bulls Offer a Model for a Dynasty
description: With the Golden State Warriors sitting four wins shy of tying the N.B.A. regular-season record  with six games to play  the comparisons to the 1995-96 Chicago Bulls will continue to crescendo. And while the Warriors could certainly look to that team for inspiration in how to remain dominant once the playoffs roll around, the executives who make Golden States personnel decisions may want to look to the years immediately before Chicagos finest season for a blueprint of how to turn their domination of the N.B.A. into a full-fledged dynasty.

title: Coca Crystal, Avatar of Counterculture and Provocateur, Dies at 68
description: In April 1977, the conservative activist Phyllis Schlafly was about to be honored by the Womens National Republican Club at the Waldorf Astoria hotel in Manhattan when she was hit by a well-aimed apple pie.

title: Gender Divide in Tournaments Shortchanges Fans and the Sport
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Lexi Thompson and Jordan Spieth represented the United States as teenagers in a mixed four-ball match at the 2008 Junior Ryder Cup. As Spieth remembered it, Thompson carried the pair. He described her as almost unbeatable. Eight years later, Thompson and Spieth are carrying American golf as the highest-ranked American players in the world.

title: When Whites Just Dont Get It, Part 6
description: LETS start with a quiz. When researchers sent young whites and blacks out to interview for low-wage jobs in New York City armed with equivalent rsums, the result was:

title: Faith and Doubt
description: Should we avoid claiming with certainty whether or not God exists?

title: Jobs and Trade on the Campaign Trail
description: The campaigns of Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders have tapped into a deep well of anger and anxiety about international trade. While their ideas for changing American trade policy are unrealistic  and, in Mr. Trumps case, nonsensical  their campaigns are doing something important by calling attention to the governments failure to help workers who have been hurt by globalization.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: A Trans-Atlantic Role Reversal
description: AMERICANS are from Mars and Europeans are from Venus. With one pithy line 14 years ago, the foreign policy theorist Robert Kagan captured what seemed like obvious differences between the United States and Europe in the post-Cold War, post-9/11 age.

title: Why Trump Cant Break the G.O.P.
description: Everywhere you look, in the year of Donald J. Trump, observers are talking about a national party realignment or a Republican death spiral. Our two-party system has not undergone a major realignment since the South became solidly Republican. There has not been a major-party demise since the Whigs collapsed on the eve of the Civil War.

title: How a Great City Could Survive Even Rob Ford
description: WHEN Rob Fords time as mayor of Toronto became a reality show that lurched from one cringe-inducing revelation to another, one question loomed: How did he come to lead Canadas largest city? His rumpled suits, fondness for profanity, racist and homophobic remarks, public drunkenness, admitted drug use and general boorishness made Mr. Ford seem like an outlier in a city that had carefully cultivated a reputation for multiculturalism, tolerance and sophistication.

title: Race and the Death Penalty in Texas
description: This month, the Supreme Court will consider whether to hear the appeal of Duane Buck, a black man from Texas who was sentenced to die for the 1995 murder of his ex-girlfriend and a man who was with her. There is no dispute about his guilt; the issue is how he ended up on death row.

title: Locked Up for Seeking Asylum
description: I RECENTLY received a phone call from Alabama. It was Samey Honaryar, an Afghan who had worked as an interpreter with the United States military and had fled Taliban persecution hoping to find asylum here. Samey is not accused of committing any crime. Yet for nearly a year, hes been locked up in Etowah County Detention Center, among the worst and most remote of immigration detention centers, with little access to lawyers or medical attention.

title: The Republicans Gay Freakout
