description: A man in Austin, Tex., was killed and six other people injured on Wednesday in what the authorities were investigating as a chemical suicide in a housing complex near the University of Texas.

title: Yankees Futility Against Left-Handers Continues
description: TORONTO  By the end of last season, it did not seem to matter who stood on the mound against the Yankees if he was left-handed. A parade of Yankees would walk to home plate, see a few pitches and pivot back toward the dugout, the indignities culminating in a shutout by the Astros Dallas Keuchel in the wild-card playoff game.

title: The Nets See Their Season, Long Over, Come to an End
description: Existential question: If a team plays an entire regular season, but few choose to watch, did it really finish with 61 losses?

title: Senators Reach Deal to Act on Comprehensive Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Senators on Wednesday reached a deal to act on a comprehensive energy bill as soon as this week, breaking a three-month partisan standoff over the tainted water scandal in Flint, Mich.

title: Bernie Sanders, in New York, Presses Fight Against Status Quo
description: Locked in a fierce fight with Hillary Clinton to win the New York primary, Senator Bernie Sanders took his plea for a political revolution to the heart of Greenwich Village on Wednesday and heaped particular scorn on Wall Street to the delight of several thousand jubilant supporters.

title: Bronx Apartment Fire Kills Two Young Sisters
description: Two young sisters were killed Wednesday night when a fire swept through a Bronx apartment, officials said.

title: 11 Face Money Laundering Charges in Federal Inquiry of Korean Brothels
description: A four-year federal investigation into a network of Korean brothels led to the unsealing of charges on Wednesday against 11 people accused of participating in a broad ring that brought Korean women into the United States to work as prostitutes in the New York area at so-called spas.

title: Group Home Workers Are Charged With Falsifying Records
description: One current and two former employees of a nonprofit that ran group homes in Brooklyn were arraigned on Wednesday on charges of falsifying records, the New York City Investigation Department said. The homes were closed last year after three teenagers sneaked out during the night and raped a woman in Manhattan.

title: The Americans Season 4, Episode 5: Under Pressure
description: Weve all seen one too many Under Pressure montages, from Stanley Cup promos to Coca-Cola ads to Happy Feet 2. But The Americans redeemed the genre on Wednesday night in this episode. Best. Under Pressure Scene. Ever.

title: Rangers Lose Henrik Lundqvist and Fall to His Little-Known Counterpart
description: PITTSBURGH  A third-string goaltender put the Rangers in an early postseason hole on Wednesday. Now the Rangers may have to rely on a backup of their own to even their Eastern Conference quarterfinal series against the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | evasive
description: evasive  \i-va-siv, -ziv, e-\  adjective

title: New York City Proposes Compromise for Kingsbridge Ice Center
description: Alicia Glen, a deputy mayor, said in a letter that a failed project would be a major blow to the Bronx neighborhood.

title: A Lawsuit, Then a Compromise Offer on a Stalled Bronx Ice Center Plan
description: On Tuesday, the developer seeking to turn a vacant Bronx armory into a $350 million ice hockey and skating center filed a lawsuit claiming the de Blasio administration was conspiring to block the project, known as the Kingsbridge National Ice Center, or KNIC.

title: Sanders Speaks in Manhattan
description: An energized crowd showed up for the campaign rally at Washington Square Park.

title: Golden State Warriors Set N.B.A. Record With 73 Wins
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Coach Steve Kerr of the Golden State Warriors had largely resisted acknowledging the importance of his teams pursuit. For his players, the number 73 had sparkled for months like a diamond amid the confetti of so many lopsided wins. They wanted to make history. Kerr was more concerned with chasing another championship.

title: What to Watch Thursday
description: Tatiana Maslany gets even more exposure as Orphan Black begins a new season with a new night and time. 30 for 30 reminisces about the magic of Shaquille ONeal. And feast on Chefs Table before Netflix serves a new course.

title: Kobe Bryant Ends Career With Exclamation Point, Scoring 60 Points
description: LOS ANGELES  There would be a celebration for Kobe Bryant on Wednesday. Everybody knew that much. The signs were everywhere. Look outside: a block party. Look courtside: gift bags for all. Look up: purple and yellow balloons suspended from the rafters of Staples Center.

title: Corrections: April 14, 2016
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: 2 Years After Boko Haram Kidnapping, the Search Goes On for Nigerian Girls
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  The last time Manasseh Allen saw his teenage cousin was at a family wedding two years ago. She was a shy girl focused on her studies, Mr. Allen recalled, and the moment the wedding was over, she rushed back to her school to study for exams.

title: Why Should My Store Be Boycotted Over a Law I Despise?
description: Asheville, N.C.  Malaprops Bookstore/Cafe is an independent bookseller in the center of Asheville, a beautiful, culturally diverse city surrounded by the mountains of western North Carolina. We host author events several nights a week, offer space to a dozen book clubs, set up forums on community issues, and welcome all kinds of folks through our doors. Were a place away from work and home where a person can relax, feel safe and be inspired.

title: The Real Welfare Cheats
description: We often hear how damaging welfare dependency is, stifling initiative and corroding the human soul. So I worry about the way we coddle executives in their suites.

title: Outrageous Sentences for Marijuana
description: Lee Carroll Brooker, a 75-year-old disabled veteran suffering from chronic pain, was arrested in July 2011 for growing three dozen marijuana plants for his own medicinal use behind his sons house in Dothan, Ala., where he lived. For this crime, Mr. Brooker was given a life sentence with no possibility of release.

title: The Death of Liberalism
description: Liberalism is dead. Or at least it is on the ropes. Triumphant a quarter-century ago, when liberal democracy appeared to have prevailed definitively over the totalitarian utopias that exacted such a toll in blood, it is now under siege from without and within.

title: Campaigns of Ultimate Disappointment
description: Im already completely exhausted by this presidential campaign season. The candidates seem to share that fatigue. Nerves are fraying as story lines grow stale.

title: In Paris, a Protest Movement Awakens
description: PARIS  A revolt over proposed labor-law reforms in France has set off an uprising among French youth, fed up, they say, over their governments failure to tackle a host of problems and thus robbing them of their future. Calling itself Nuit Debout  roughly translatable as Standing Up at Night  the movement recalls Spains 2011 anti-austerity Indignados movement and the Occupy movement in the United States. But there are also echoes of Frances own history of popular revolt, including the student-led protests of May 1968.

title: The Lessons of Kasich
description: We have reached, at last, the John Kasich moment. The next six Republican primaries are in his kind of territory: blue states, Northeastern, moderate, exactly the sort of places where his positioning as the electable, reasonable Republican is designed to pay off big.

title: Banks Still Too Big to Regulate
description: Regulating the big banks has become a race against time, with bank regulators still too slow at enforcing legal requirements under the Dodd-Frank financial reform law.

title: After Bankruptcies, Coals Dirty Legacy Lives On
description: THE bankruptcy filing on Wednesday by Peabody Energy, the worlds largest private- sector producer of coal, is the latest in a series of major coal company collapses that threaten to leave behind a costly legacy that will haunt taxpayers and consumers for years.

title: Are Big Banks Still a Problem?
News Qs | Inky the Octopus Escapes From a New Zealand Aquarium
description: The following lesson activities are based on the article Inky the Octopus Escapes From a New Zealand Aquarium.

title: What Its Like to Live in Segregated New York
description: The New York Times asked residents in community districts that were highly divided along racial and ethnic lines to describe what they liked and didnt like about their neighborhoods.

title: Nonnegotiable: A Jersey City Address
description: There was no question where Craig Vagell would live. As an applicant for a firefighting job in Jersey City, he had a residency requirement to fulfill.

title: The Sexy Bride Look and the Designers Behind Them
description: Led by three Israeli designers, a growing number of wedding dresses have taken on a distinctly Mediterranean flavor: low backs that skim the derrire, deep navel-revealing necklines and a shocking amount of sheer fabric.

title: Segregation Issue Complicates de Blasios Housing Push
description: As New York City tries to spur construction of tens of thousands of apartments to meet an accelerating need for below-market-rate housing, a deeper problem has largely gone unmentioned by municipal officials: the persistence of residential segregation in one of the worlds most diverse cities.

title: What to Look For in the Democratic Debate
description: Join us for New York primary live updates.

title: Student Question | Should All High School Students Be Able to Get a Summer Job if They Want One?
description: Should all high school students be able to get a summer job if they want one? Is the experience potentially so rewarding that the government should work with nonprofit organizations and the business community to create a universal summer jobs program?

title: Motivated by the Spirit of Chris Hondros
description: Covering the chaos of the Libyan civil war in 2011 transformed Bryan Denton. He began the war as a promising 27-year-old photojournalist and provided some of the most vivid coverage of the conflict for The New York Times. But its not his personal successes that stick with Mr. Denton  its the victims he photographed, and the deaths of several colleagues, especially his friend Chris Hondros.

title: Whats Going On in This Poem? | Taking It Home to Jerome
description: Updated | April 20

title: America Hasnt Gone Crazy. Its Just More Like Europe.
description: Sofia, Bulgaria  FOR most Europeans these days, traveling to America is like landing on Mars. Even the most sophisticated political analysts cant make head or tail of what is happening in the country. They are offended by the rise of Donald J. Trump, puzzled by Bernie Sanderss democratic socialist appeal to young American voters, and confused by President Obamas unsentimental, risk-averse foreign policy that decided against punishing President Bashar al-Assad of Syria for crossing Mr. Obamas own red line on chemical weapons.

title: Upping the Pressure on Egypt
description: Human rights abuses in Egypt under President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi have reached new highs, yet the Western governments that trade with and arm Egypt have continued to pursue business as usual with the argument that regional security and economic interests trump all. Now, a stalled investigation into the abduction and murder of an Italian student has forced at least one of these countries, Italy, to reconsider its relationship. It is time for other Western democracies to reconsider theirs.

title: For Women Who Run, the Bathroom Problem
description: On a recent weekend trip to Washington, I was running in Rock Creek Park when the water and coffee Id had that morning caught up with me. Id run there only once before so was unsure where relief lay. Im also a woman, so I couldnt just pull over to the nearest bush or tree and relieve myself discreetly, the way guys do, through the benefits of outdoor plumbing.

title: Your Thursday Briefing: Boko Haram, Golden State Warriors, Amazon Kindle
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Bite of Hong Kong
description: Classic Cantonese cooking in Manhattans Chinatown.

title: Bite of Hong Kong Requires More Than a Few Nibbles
description: The fish rise and fall in their wall of tanks. The crabs crouch like linebackers and tap their Morse code. Choose, you are told.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus on Clinton, Trump and an Election-Year Veep
description: A female politician in the fight of her life as she strives to make White House history. A nation in the balance as its officials contend with an arcane electoral system that varies from state to state. A proud republic debased by a presidential campaign fixated on minor gaffes and riddled with filthy language.

title: Senators Propose Holding Part of Refunds for Taxpayers Rainy Day Funds
description: Ahead of tax day on Monday, an unlikely pair in the Senate has teamed up on a proposal to encourage American taxpayers to salt away rainy day funds, by allowing them to defer up to 20 percent of any refund due from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: New York Today: All Eyes on Brooklyn
description: Updated, 12:13 p.m.

title: The Architect Ma Yansong Blends East and West
description: Ma Yansong, 40, has become one of Chinas best-known architects. His curvilinear, free-form and futuristic designs are often compared to those of his mentor, Zaha Hadid, who died on March 31 at 65. Mr. Ma says his greatest inspiration is nature; his recently completed opera house in the northern Chinese city of Harbin resembles a snow-capped mountain, while his master plan for the city of Nanjing calls for sloping buildings covered with vertical louvers that look like waterfalls. While Mr. Mas firm, MAD, continues to land splashy projects in China, he is also expanding in the United States. He will soon open MADs second American office, after Los Angeles, in New York, and now has three stateside projects underway: a high-rise in Manhattan; an apartment and retail complex in Beverly Hills, Calif.; and George Lucass provocative museum project in Chicago, a tent-like design that has gotten mixed reviews  one local politician compared it to a palace for Jabba the Hutt. In this edited interview, Mr. Ma talks about how he deals with such criticism, how traditional Eastern values inform his perspective and what he thinks about Chinas ban on weird architecture.

title: Morning Agenda: Five Banks Seen as Too Big to Fail
description: FIVE BANKS SEEN AS TOO BIG TO FAIL | Nearly eight years after the financial crisis, five of the largest American banks are still seen as too big to fail,  Nathaniel Popper and Peter Eavis write in DealBook. The Federal Reserve and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation determined that JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Wells Fargo, State Street and Bank of New York Mellon submitted plans for insolvency, also known as living wills, that were not credible or would not facilitate an orderly resolution under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley received passing grades from only one of the two agencies.

title: Jeremy Corbyn, Labour Leader, Urges Britons to Vote to Stay in E.U.
description: LONDON  Until now, Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of Britains opposition Labour Party and a longtime critic of the European Union, has said relatively little about the coming referendum on the countrys membership in the 28-nation bloc.

title: 2-2 Draw Is Good Enough for Bayern Munich
description: LONDON  For just 11 minutes in the magnificent Estdio da Luz in Lisbon, it looked as if Benfica might roll back the clock to the early 1960s, when the Portuguese champion was a real force in European soccer.

title: Inspired by an Old Tradition
description: Dutch artists reference still lifes by old masters in exotic compositions.

title: Dutch Artists Breathe New Life Into Taxidermy
description: HAARLEM, the Netherlands  When Damien Hirst, the man who submerged a shark in a tub of formaldehyde and sold it for millions of dollars, buys up nearly every piece at only your second gallery show, its a sign that you might be doing something right as a taxidermy artist.

title: Europe, in Wake of Attacks, Votes to Collect Air Passenger Data
description: BRUSSELS  After a wave of terrorist attacks in recent months, European Union lawmakers took a decisive step on Thursday in favor of bolstering security with the approval of a continentwide system to collect and share information on airline passengers.

title: Cannes Film Festival Announces Lineup
description: LONDON  Julieta, a new movie by Pedro Almodvar; Its Only the End of the World, by the upstart Canadian director Xavier Dolan; and The Last Face, a Sean Penn movie set in Africa, are among the movies that will compete for the Palme dOr at this years Cannes Film Festival, festival officials said on Thursday.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Squirrels
description: The philosopher William James once posed the following problem: A squirrel runs around the trunk of a tree, and a man, trying to see the squirrel, chases it. But in the end, the man is unable to catch up to the squirrel; all he sees is bark and more bark. He goes round the tree, sure enough, and the squirrel is on the tree, the philosopher says, but does the man go round the squirrel or not?

title: The Fresher the Spice, the Better the Chicken Paprikash
description: It was Christopher Columbus who brought the pepper to Europe, a souvenir of his travels in the New World, and the Ottoman Empire that brought it to Eastern Europe, dried and ground fine into crimson spice. Hungarians in particular went mad for the stuff, stirring the seasoning into their theretofore-plain stews and fricassees: paprika, they called it, from the Latin piper, or pepper.

title: Why Was This Woman Gaining Weight Despite Her Diet?
description: The condition, in retrospect, seemed fairly obvious. Why was it so hard for the doctors who knew the patient best to see it?

title: Democrats Prepare to Debate as G.O.P. Candidates Gather for Dinner
description: The five remaining presidential candidates will appear at two separate party events in New York City on Thursday night, the last time each group will share a room before the state primary on Tuesday. It is also potentially the last time each partys candidates will be in the same place before their conventions.

title: The Minecraft Generation
description: Jordan wanted to build an unpredictable trap.

title: Tiananmen Protest Museum Says Its Being Forced Out of Hong Kong Location
description: HONG KONG  After two years on the fifth floor of a Hong Kong office building, the only museum dedicated to the 1989 Tiananmen protest movement is expected to close this year. The organizers of the June 4th Museum say they are scrambling to find a new location.

title: Former UBS Trader Challenges Bar Over Libor Misconduct
description: LONDON  A former UBS derivatives trader said on Thursday that he would fight an effort by the Financial Conduct Authority of Britain to bar him from the financial services industry for misconduct related to the setting of a global benchmark interest rate known as Libor.

title: A Champion of Japans Right Wing Is Jailed Over Campaign Payments
description: TOKYO  Two years ago, Toshio Tamogami, a deeply conservative former military commander turned politician, drew more than half a million votes as a candidate for governor of Tokyo, fueling concerns about the growing appeal of far-right ideology in Japan.

title: Pressure on Exxon Over Climate Change Intensifies With New Documents
description: Pressure on Exxon Mobil and the energy industry increased on Wednesday with the release of a new cache of decades-old industry documents about climate change, even as Exxon pushed back against efforts to investigate the company over its climate claims through the years.

title: Volodymyr Groysman Approved as New Prime Minister by Ukraines Parliament
description: MOSCOW  In Ukraines most sweeping political reshuffle since its revolution two years ago, Parliament voted Thursday to seat a close ally of the president as prime minister and handed critical ministerial posts to presidential staff members.

title: Philip Kerr: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of The Other Side of Silence thinks heroes are always too heroic to be real. Or wholly sympathetic. James Bond is nicely flawed. Sadistic. Sexist. Bitter. I like that.

title: In the Hospital, Resisting the Urge to Do More
description: There was absolutely no way around it. She was dying. I gave her a few hours at best, with maximum pedal to the metal intensive medical care. Paramedics had picked up this homeless woman after she collapsed under a bridge in Oakland, Calif. Her heart had completely stopped. She had died under that bridge. But the paramedics had somehow pulled her back, with a jump-start to her heart. And then brought her right to my service in the intensive care unit.

title: The Muzzling of the Malaysian Mind
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  On Thursday the High Court here rejected yet another challenge to the Sedition Act, paving the way for the governments record-breaking case against the political cartoonist Zulkiflee Anwar Haque, better known as Zunar, to proceed. Zunar faces up to 43 years in prison on nine counts of sedition  the most counts anyone in Malaysia has ever been charged with.

title: California Surfers Look to Courts for Relief Against Bay Boys
description: PALOS VERDES ESTATES, Calif.  From high atop the oceanside cliffs, the shimmering blue-green water of Lunada Bay appears to be a surfers dream.

title: Taking a Trip, Literally, on Colorados Pot Trail
description: We were somewhere north of Denver, not far from the pot farm, when my neighbor on the party bus pulled hard on his pipe and said: Know what it is I love about this country? Everyone gets stoned.

title: Where to Go in New Orleans
description: Central City is far from the pandemonium of Bourbon Street. An area sandwiched between the French Quarter and the Uptown residential neighborhood, its main thoroughfare, Oretha Castle Haley Boulevard, was a thriving shopping and cultural district in the late 19th century and a hub of civil rights activism in the 1960s. But the area eventually became rundown. Now, thanks largely to investments from the New Orleans Redevelopment Authority and resolute entrepreneurs, Central City is re-emerging as a cultural and commercial destination.

title: Targeting Beyond China
description: DSSELDORF, Germany  On March 27, Chinese police crashed my fathers 70th birthday party in Chinas southwestern Sichuan Province. They accused my family of causing a forest fire the day before by lighting incense and burning paper as part of the annual tomb- sweeping festival to honor deceased relatives. Three of my siblings were summoned to the police station and found out quickly that they were not being detained over an arson charge.

title: Capability Brown, the Master of the English Garden
description: Few people have had as large an impact on British gardens as the landscape artist Lancelot Brown, more often known as Capability Brown. His naturalistic style and gracious designs have proved timeless, and his gardens remain popular almost 300 years after he did his best work.

title: A First Date: Total Recall
description: Dear Diary:

title: Obama Hails Young Inquiring Minds at His Final White House Science Fair
description: WASHINGTON  Back in 2009, when President Obama announced that the White House would be hosting an annual science fair, he explained the decision this way: If you win the N.C.A.A. championship, you come to the White House. Well, if youre a young person and you produce the best experiment or design, the best hardware or software, you ought to be recognized for that achievement, too.

title: U.S. and Philippines Bolster Air and Sea Patrols in South China Sea
description: MANILA  Philippine and American forces began conducting joint naval patrols in the South China Sea last month and will immediately start air operations over the area, United States Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said during a visit here on Thursday.

title: First Draft Focus: Throwback Thursday  Washington Square Park, Redux
A Tough Year for Banking Takes Shape
description: If this week is any indication, 2016 is shaping up to be another tough year for the nations biggest banks.

title: BlackRock, Hurt by Volatile Markets, Reports Slide in Profit
description: Volatile global markets had their effect on BlackRock, the worlds largest asset management firm, as its earnings for the first quarter of this year declined by 14 percent.

title: Ramapo Town Supervisor Arrested in Federal Fraud Case
description: Christopher St. Lawrence, the elected supervisor of Ramapo, a town in Rockland County, N.Y., was arrested on Thursday in a federal securities fraud case stemming from the financing of a local minor-league baseball stadium that has long been a divisive issue for the towns residents.

title: After South Korea Spurns Park Geun-hye, She May Press Agenda Abroad
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Park Geun-hye of South Korea had hoped that this weeks legislative elections would give her party a stronger majority in Parliament, one that would let her finally push through changes to labor law and other domestic initiatives that have long been stalled.

title: A Lisbon Home With a Vertical Garden
description: LISBON  Under the shadow of its huge domed basilica, the Lisbon district of Estrela is an area of quiet streets and discreet white-and-pastel-painted mansions.

title: Anna Wintour Adds to Her Body of Film Work
description: Anna Wintour, editor of American Vogue and artistic director of Cond Nast, continues apace her campaign to shape public perception of fashion. She uses her magazine to do it, of course, but she is also doing it on a different scale through film  for the big screen and small.

title: Mississippi Law on Serving Gays Proves Divisive
description: To hear some supporters tell it, a measure signed into law last week in Mississippi does little more than let bakers reject wedding cake orders from same-sex couples.

title: Bernie Sanders Itinerary in Rome Will Not Include Pope Francis Visit
description: It looks as if Senator Bernie Sanderss brief Roman holiday will not include a meeting with Pope Francis.

title: How to Watch the Democratic Debate
description: Join us for live analsis of the Democratic debate.

title: New York Times Plans International Digital Expansion
description: The New York Times Company will invest more than $50 million over the next three years to support an ambitious plan to expand its international digital audience and increase revenue outside the United States, the company said on Thursday. The Times has formed a new team, NYT Global, to lead the effort.

title: Many Verizon Customers Not Likely to Notice Strike
description: About 36,000 Verizon workers on the East Coast went on strike Wednesday. Did you notice?

title: 1941: Mrs. Roosevelts Plea
description: A novice in the field of propaganda organizations, the three-week-old Women United filled Carnegie hall last night with 2,300 ardent peace-lovers. They came to the hall to hear speeches by Senator Bennett Champ Clark, Democrat of Missouri; Senator Robert R. Reynolds, Democrat of North Carolina; Mrs Robert A Taft, wife of the Republican Senator from Ohio, and Mrs Theodore Roosevelt Jr.

title: Stopping OS X Apps From Automatically Starting
description: Q. When I turn on my Mac, I notice the Dock shows Google Chrome always open, even though the browser window doesnt appear on screen and Im not opening the program myself. Why is this and how do I turn it off?

title: Wall Street Art Show Postponed
description: A sprawling pop-up art show that was set to take over almost 150,000 square feet of 23 Wall Street has been postponed and shortened because of funding issues. Simon Birch, the shows Hong Kong-based organizer and primary artist, has raised $3 million, including $1 million of his own money, but came up short on funds for the nonprofit putting on the show.

title: Justin Trudeau Seeks to Legalize Assisted Suicide in Canada
description: OTTAWA  The government of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau introduced legislation on Thursday to legalize physician-assisted suicide for Canadians with a serious and incurable illness, which has brought them enduring physical or psychological suffering.

title: Jane Austen and Shakespeare, for the 21st Century
description: Great stories are timeless, but times have changed  and so two wonderfully irreverent new series of books are updating some of the classics. The Austen Project puts Janeite favorites like Pride and Prejudice in the hands of contemporary writers like Curtis Sittenfeld, whose Eligible (Random House, April 19) recasts Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy as a magazine writer and a neurosurgeon in modern-day Cincinnati. And for the Crown Publishing Groups Hogarth Shakespeare series, novelists such as Howard Jacobson and Margaret Atwood are reimagining the Bards works in modern prose.

title: Why Do Older People Love Facebook? Lets Ask My Dad
description: When Facebook was born in 2004, the oldest baby boomers were in their late 50s, and older members of the silent generation were reaching their early 80s. If you thought they were going to sit back and let gifs, emojis and status updates pass them by, you were wrong, according to new research.

title: Donald Trumps Allies Look to Make Friends in Congress
description: While Donald J. Trump is busy barnstorming New York, his allies in Washington are busy trying to win the support of Republicans on Capitol Hill.

title: Houston Deputy Is Shot in Ambush-Style Attack at Traffic Stop, Police Say
description: A man shot and wounded a deputy constable at a traffic stop in Houston late Wednesday in what the authorities described as an ambush-style attack.

title: Open Season on Jeremy Lin? In Video, Fan Highlights Hard Fouls
description: Hsiu-Chen Kuei waited until her husband and three sons had gone to bed one night recently before surreptitiously beginning work on an ambitious personal project.

title: Its Not Cancer: Doctors Reclassify a Thyroid Tumor
description: An international panel of doctors has decided that a type of tumor that was classified as a cancer is not a cancer at all.

title: Tate Modern Announces Revamping of Collections for Opening of New Wing
description: LONDON Tate Modern, the modern and contemporary art museum in London, on Thursday announced a reorganization of its collection displays that will be unveiled when a new wing opens on June 17.

title: Tribeca Interview: Jason Sudeikis and Jessica Biel
description: In The Devil and the Deep Blue Sea, having its world premiere Thursday at the Tribeca Film Festival, Jason Sudeikis plays a buttoned-down architect. When his extroverted and expectant wife, played by Jessica Biel, is killed in an accident, he finds it a struggle to cope. In his grief, he meets a homeless teenager (Maisie Williams), who has also experienced loss. The two build an unconventional bond and work through their trauma by building a raft meant to sail across the Atlantic.

title: Automakers Revisit Tactics That Hurt Them Before Recession
description: When the car industry collapsed in the recession, automakers pulled back sharply on aggressive leasing deals and other financial incentives that had artificially increased their sales for years.

title: An Artist and a Poet Capture Death in a Hospice Room
description: For Ts ongoing series, the Rome prize-winning artist Nari Ward responded to a poem by Carol Muske-Dukes, the former poet laureate of California.

title: 1966: Iraqi President Killed in Crash
description: BAGHDAD  President Abdul Salem Aref and other top Iraqi government officials were killed last night [April 13] when their helicopter crashed during a violent sandstorm near the southern city of Basra. The other dead included Minister Abdul Latif Al-Darraji, Industry Minister Mustapha Abdullah and the governor of Basra district, Baghdad radio said. Premier Abdul Rahman Bazzaz immediately assumed presidential powers until a successor is elected. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 15, 1966

title: U.S. Mideast Policy: The Israeli Ambassadors View
description: To the Editor:

title: Ringo Starr Cancels North Carolina Show, Also Citing Bias Law
description: Following Bruce Springsteens lead, Ringo Starr will not be performing in North Carolina any time soon. The former Beatles drummer announced that he was canceling a scheduled June 18 concert in Cary, N.C., in protest of a  law that limits bathroom access for transgender people and eliminates local anti-discrimination ordinances based on sexual orientation.

title: Donald Trump Holding a Strong Lead in Pennsylvania
description: Donald J. Trump holds a double-digit lead in Pennsylvania, according to a new poll that shows moderate Republicans providing him a boost in the state ahead of its primary election later this month.

title: Inglenook Focuses on the Long Term to Regain Its Glory
description: RUTHERFORD, Calif.  When Philippe Bascaules arrived here in 2011 to take over as general manager of Inglenook Vineyard, one of the first things he did was to present the owners, Francis Ford Coppola and his wife, Eleanor, a plan for managing and renewing the grapevines. The plan covered the next 50 years.

title: McCarter Theaters Season to Include Nilo Cruz and Ken Ludwig
description: A new work from the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Nilo Cruz (Anna in the Tropics) and a stage adaptation of Agatha Christies 1934 novel Murder on the Orient Express will make their premieres as part of the 2016-17 season at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, N.J., the company announced on Thursday.

title: Strong Earthquake Strikes Japans Kyushu Island, Killing at Least 9
description: TOKYO  A powerful earthquake struck the southwestern Japanese island of Kyushu on Thursday, killing nine people, collapsing roads and buildings, and knocking out power, officials said.

title: Its Probably Cheaper on the Web, Adobes Online Price Index Shows
description: Is the Internet making everything cheaper?

title: Microsoft Sues Justice Department to Protest Electronic Gag Order Statute
description: Big technology companies have usually played a defensive game with government prosecutors in their legal fight over customer information, fighting or bowing to requests for information one case at a time.

title: Crabs Swarming on the Sea Floor
description: Thousands of red crabs swarmed the ocean floor off the coast of Panama.

title: Cuban Law on Cruises Prompts a Protest
description: An estimated 50 protesters rallied outside the South Florida headquarters of Carnival Corporation this week, according to The Miami Herald, decrying the coming launch of its Cuba cruises from which Cuban-born travelers are barred.

title: BP Shareholders Send a Message Protesting Chiefs Pay
description: LONDON  In a symbolic slap against high executive pay at a money-losing company, BP shareholders have voted against the $19.6 million compensation package for the chief executive, Robert W. Dudley.

title: Irans President Is Squeezed by Opposition Leaders Demand for a Trial
description: TEHRAN  An opposition leader long under house arrest has written a letter to President Hassan Rouhani demanding a public trial, putting the president in a difficult spot and highlighting a deepening rift in Irans reformist wing.

title: How Regulators Mess With Bankers Minds, and Why Thats Good
description: Bank regulators on Wednesday sent a message that big banks are still too big and too complex. They rejected special plans, called living wills, that the banks have to submit to show they can go through an orderly bankruptcy.

title: Alice Birch Speaks Softly and Writes Loud Plays
description: Arriving at the Metropolitan Museum of Art just as it opened one brisk April morning, the British playwright Alice Birch was on what she called a morbid little trip in pursuit of inspiration. Bunking on Wall Street in the run-up to her American debut at Soho Rep with Revolt. She Said. Revolt Again., this 29-year-old had journeyed uptown to do research for a play shes writing for the Royal Court Theater in London.

title: Escaped Chimpanzee Captured in Japan
description: A male chimpanzee who had escaped from a local zoo was captured by city officials on Thursday in northern Japan. Zoo officials said the primate was not hurt during his capture.

title: Close Tax Loopholes
description: To the Editor:

title: Regulating Brokers
description: To the Editor:

title: Revelations From Panama Papers Are Old News for Africans
description: JOHANNESBURG  Outsiders have long claimed the moral high ground in accusing African elites of endemic corruption.

title: Michelle Dorrance, the Tireless Ambassador of Tap
description: Michelle Dorrance talks like she dances: fast. Her sentences start in one direction, pause for a quick, somewhat related observation or a random aside  On the horizon: Eliot Feld/Michelle Dorrance collaboration. I cant wait to do that  and pick up vaguely where they left off.

title: Incense Ignited Bronx Fire That Killed 2 Girls, Officials Say
description: The mother of two young girls killed in a fire at a public housing project in the Bronx said she had just gone out to get ice cream for them and check on laundry when the blaze began, the police and her imam said on Thursday.

title: The S.U.V. Arms Race Goes Upscale
description: One of the last big profit centers for Detroits automakers, the sport utility vehicle, is under siege.

title: Jed Bernstein Steps Down as Lincoln Center President
description: After just two years in the position, Jed Bernstein is leaving as the president of Lincoln Center, the countrys largest nonprofit performing arts center. What in the world went wrong?

title: Zika Threat in Miami
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Cant We Get Rid of Mosquitoes Entirely?
description: Ask The Times, a Times Insider feature, draws on Times staff members expertise to answer questions about current events, science, sports, culture and whatever else is making headlines.

title: Poll of British Muslims Reveals Startling Views, but Some Question Methodology
description: A new poll of British Muslims revealed attitudes on homosexuality and terrorism sharply out of step with broader public opinion, but also set off a debate about the reliability of such surveys.

title: Blacks and the 1994 Crime Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Send Us the Political Ads You See on Facebook
description: The Times wants to learn more about how political campaigns are targeting voters with online advertising. Install this tool to share with us the ads you see.

title: No Time for Credibility
description: So, here we are with near-zero real interest rates on long-term government bonds; with a desperate need for infrastructure investment; with strong reason to believe that deficit spending in the current environment would actually improve the long-run fiscal picture, because the interest burden would be so low and higher growth would raise future revenues.

title: Zika Virus Can Be Transmitted Through Anal Sex, C.D.C. Says
description: The Zika virus can be transmitted by anal sex as well as vaginal sex, according to a report issued on Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: After O.J., Confirmation Revisits Another 90s Flashpoint: Anita Hill vs. Clarence Thomas
description: The 1991 Supreme Court nomination hearings of Clarence Thomas, and the public accusation by the law professor Anita Hill that he had sexually harassed her years before, popularized the phrase He said, she said. (With some help from the Kevin Bacon-Elizabeth Perkins movie of the same year.) But for every he and she in such a case, theres a they: the people who listen, who provide the soapbox, who control the microphone.

title: Nanny Accused of Killing 2 Children in Manhattan Rejects a Plea Deal
description: A nanny accused of killing two children under her care in their Manhattan apartment turned down an offer from a judge on Thursday that would have given her a prison sentence of 30 years to life in return for guilty pleas to both murders.

title: Angela Merkel, Accused of Betraying Core Values, Faces a Balancing Act With Turkey
description: BERLIN  Last September, Chancellor Angela Merkel was widely seen as an idealist, charitably welcoming hundreds of thousands of refugees to Germany in the face of stiff opposition at home and from European allies. But the influx swiftly became too much to handle.

title: Curtis Sittenfeld Is No Jane Austen, but Shes O.K. With That
description: It takes confidence  some might even say hubris  to rewrite one of the most beloved novels in the English canon.

title: In Milan, an Exhibition That Explores What It Means to Be Human
description: The annual Salone del Mobile fair, held in Milan this week, is a collection of the worlds biggest design objects in one place. But amid it all is a very different kind of show: Neo-Prehistory: 100 Verbs, which is on view at La Triennale, attempts to boil down the totality of life on earth today to its absolute essentials.

title: Battery Charge Against Corey Lewandowski, Trump Campaign Manager, Is Dropped
description: Corey Lewandowski, the campaign manager for Donald J. Trump, will not be prosecuted on a battery charge, the Palm Beach County state attorney said Thursday.

title: At the World Bank, a Shortage of Concrete (Language)
description: In his 1946 essay Politics and the English Language, George Orwell wrote that the whole tendency of modern prose is away from concreteness. He could have been writing about World Bank reports, it turns out.

title: Belgian Court Lengthens Prison Term of Jihadist Recruiter
description: PARIS  A Belgian appellate court on Thursday increased to 15 years, from 12, the sentence of a Muslim man who had been convicted of persuading dozens of young men in Belgium  including some who were involved in the terrorist attacks on Paris  to join the jihadist fight in Syria.

title: When You Dream of Provence, You Dream of This Town
description: Like a pair of navy espadrilles, Saint-Rmy  a small Provenal town an hours drive north from Marseille  has always been fashionable ... but rarely trendy. With its gurgling centuries-old fountains, winding streets and shuttered sandstone houses, its beauty is of the timeless, low-key sort, remarkable for its unselfconsciousness. Its where, looking out from the window of his asylum, Van Gogh painted The Starry Night, and not even the many fashion world denizens who have taken over the thick-walled farmhouses on the towns outer edges (Pierre Berg converted several tracts into a jungly Moroccan refuge) could disrupt its sense of serenity.

title: Fracking: Weighing Risks and Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Issues New Rules on Offshore Oil and Gas Drilling
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Thursday unveiled a final set of regulations on offshore oil and gas drilling that are aimed at preventing the kind of equipment failures that caused the disastrous 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Chinas Growing Ardor for Overseas Shopping
description: Nelson Peltz sat on the board of Legg Mason, the $3.7 billion asset management company, for five years while his hedge fund, Trian Partners, scooped up 10 percent of the companys stock.

title: Vladimir Putins Vulnerable Side Is at Fore in Call-In Show
description: MOSCOW  A somewhat humbled, or at least not swaggering, President Vladimir V. Putin held his annual, live call-in show on Thursday, with his answers to the choreographed calls intended to underscore his concern for the plight of ordinary Russians amid a second, punishing year of recession.

title: Texting in Movie Theaters? AMC Backs Off After Criticism
description: The chief executive of AMC Entertainment, which is about to become the biggest movie theater chain in the country, floated the idea of letting people text in theaters, but within a day had backed off the idea.

title: Hot or Not: How to Sell Sex With Strangers
description: Someone is not having Sex With Strangers.

title: Driven | 2016 Porsche Macan S
description: Smaller than the company's Cayenne S.U.V., the Macan proves that compact crossovers can be more than just practical transportation. They can be a thrill to drive.

title: Video Review: The Macan, a Lively Crossover From Porsche
description: When Porsche added the Cayenne sport utility vehicle to its lineup in 2003, loyalists reacted as if Beelzebub himself would ride in to usher in doomsday. Funny how it became the best-selling vehicle the company makes.

title: A Roommate Blabs About a Night Best Forgotten
description: I am a freshman in college. Last summer, my roommate and I went to a club, where I took some Molly (MDMA) and proceeded to pass out. It was terrible, but I learned a valuable lesson. Nearly a year later, my friend is still telling the story to everyone she meets. Thanks to her, practically everyone at school knows me as the girl who passed out in the club. Ive asked her nicely to stop. Her response: It was traumatic for me, too. Can this friendship be saved?

title: Harlem Man Found Guilty of Murder in 4-Year Gang War
description: A 20-year-old Harlem man was convicted on Thursday of conspiracy and murder for his role in a four-year gang war in West Harlem that was responsible for several shootings and two murders, including the death of his sister, a high school basketball star.

title: How We Live-Chat a Presidential Debate
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Nicholas Confessore, a political correspondent for The Times, describes the adrenaline rush of real-time debate and election analysis (heres tonights live chat).

title: James Levine, Transformative at the Met Opera, Is Stepping Down
description: He struggled with health problems and surgeries for years, and missed two full seasons after a serious spinal injury in 2011. But James Levine, whose name became virtually synonymous with the Metropolitan Opera since becoming its music director four decades ago, always seemed to battle back, even conducting from a motorized wheelchair in recent years.

title: Letters: Facing Dark Times
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Hopes for a Stephen Colbert Bump From a New Leader at The Late Show
description: In early February, Stephen Colbert got a valuable piece of television real estate that no other late-night host had ever received: The post-Super Bowl slot, and the benefit of a lead-in from the biggest viewing audience of the year.

title: On the Hunt for Tasty Morel Mushrooms
description: Fungiphiles rejoice. Its morel mushroom season in much of the United States, meaning its time to hunt down these tasty treasures. They look like sponges or Dali-esque brains, but for those whove ever fried them up or experienced them in pasta sauce, their unique earthly flavor cant be topped.

title: Reclaiming Territorial Waters
description: Many British fishermen see a boon in leaving the European Union: They will get Europeans out of their waters.

title: In Brexit Debate, English Fishermen Eye Waters Free of E.U.
description: BRIXHAM, England  Mike Walker, a retired fisherman here, sums up what many in this southern English port town think of the European Union.

title: Jaromir Jagr vs. Islanders: A Long, Point-Filled History
description: In his 22 N.H.L. seasons, Jaromir Jagr has played more than 1,600 regular-season games. He has played more of them against the Islanders (109) than any other team. He has more regular-season goals (61), assists (93) and points (154) against the Islanders than any other player.

title: Behave, by Andromeda Romano-Lax
description: BEHAVEBy Andromeda Romano-Lax391 pp. Soho Press. $26.95.

title: Review: Barbershop: The Next Cut: Let the Debates Resume
description: Movie sequels dont need  and frequently dont have  a good reason to exist, other than to take more money from fans. Barbershop: The Next Cut, which revives a popular comedy franchise, has plenty of commercial appeal, not least as a kind of hip-hop all-star acting revue, with Common, Tyga and Nicki Minaj joining Ice Cube and Eve, who anchored the original Barbershop. That movie was a hit in 2002, and it spawned two earlier sequels and a cable TV series. This comeback feels like the opposite of cynical, though. If anything, it seems unusually urgent. Were back at the barbershop because theres an awful lot to talk about.

title: Suit Against Maker of Gun in Newtown Massacre Can Proceed, Court Rules
description: A Connecticut judge declined on Thursday to dismiss a lawsuit brought against the maker of the assault-style rifle that a gunman used in the 2012 massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School to fatally shoot 26 people before killing himself.

title: Japanese Official Describes Earthquake
description: Japans chief cabinet secretary said a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the island of Kyushu, leveling buildings, but the nuclear reactors there are safe.

title: The Winds From Washington Chill Wall Streets Deal Making
description: On Wall Street, the phones have been a little quieter. The workload has been a little lighter. The happy hours have been starting earlier.

title: African Migrants in Italy
description: As last years stampede of Syrians through Greece and the Balkans plunged Europe into a political crisis, Italy absorbed many migrants from sub-Saharan Africa.

title: After Europe and Turkey Strike a Deal, Fears Grow That Migrants Will Turn to Italy
description: MESSINA, Sicily  The old music school is overflowing. The building is now a migrant shelter for unaccompanied minors, able to house 224 teenagers  except that it is overstuffed with 281. And it is only early April. Migrant season in Sicily is just beginning.

title: Living Near Greenery May Help You Live Longer
description: Living near greenery may help you live longer.

title: Anna Wintour, Robert De Niro and Jane Fonda at the Tribeca Film Festival
description: The First Monday in May, a documentary about the making of the China: Through the Looking Glass spring 2015 exhibition and gala at the Mets Costume Institute, had its world premiere.

title: Putins Annual Q. and A. Highlights
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke on issues including the Panama Papers, the G.D.P. and sanctions, and the Syrian campaign.

title: Mothering Sunday, by Graham Swift
description: MOTHERING SUNDAYA RomanceBy Graham Swift177 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: Pakistans Premier Leaves the Country Amid Panama Papers Scandal
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Speculation about the political fate of Pakistans embattled prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, was swirling on Thursday after he left the country in the middle of an unfolding scandal over his familys offshore wealth.

title: New York to Expand Gifted Offerings as Disparities Remain
description: The number of students who scored high enough to qualify for New York Citys gifted and talented programs rose this year, the Education Department said on Thursday. But the neighborhoods in which those children live continued along a familiar pattern: In wealthy districts, more children take the tests, and score well on them, than in districts where families are poor.

title: When the Loch Ness Monster Was in The Times
description: A ripple stirred the lore of Loch Ness this week, but it was not the monster. It was a movie prop monster. The prop sank in 1969 during the filming of The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes. An underwater robot in search of evidence of the real monster found it.

title: E-Cigarette Use by U.S. Teenagers Rose Last Year, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  E-cigarette use continued to rise among young teenagers and preteens in the United States last year, according to new federal data, but cigarette smoking overall did not increase, suggesting that, at least so far, fears that the devices would hook a new generation on traditional cigarettes have not come to pass.

title: Every Days a Holiday (or Two)
description: Call me a party pooper, but I did nothing this year to mark Pi Day. I baked neither a sweet nor a savory pie. Perhaps worse, but without deliberate offense to STEM-loving peoples, I also failed to observe Albert Einsteins birthday that day  no Instagrammed black-hole image or chummy post on Einsteins official Facebook page wishing him an HBD.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Green Room'
description: Jeremy Saulnier narrates a sequence from his film.

title: Jeremy Saulnier Narrates a Scene From Green Room
description: The members of a young punk band face off against militant neo-Nazis in the thriller Green Room, the new film from the writer and director Jeremy Saulnier. In this scene, the musicians find themselves trapped in a rock clubs green room. A murder has just taken place there, but outside, the rock concert continues. During an interview at The Times, Mr. Saulnier discussed some of his ideas behind the scene and his film. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

title: Where the Abused, and Their Pets, Can Be Safe
description: Ms. H decided she had to move out of her mothers apartment last spring after her drug-addicted sister held a knife to her throat and threatened to kill her.

title: Ruling Juror Didnt Lie, Judge Upholds Ex-Officers Conviction in Stairwell Shooting
description: Finding that a juror had not lied to get himself impaneled at the trial, a judge denied a motion on Thursday to overturn the conviction of Peter Liang, the former New York City police officer found guilty in February of fatally shooting Akai Gurley in a housing project stairwell.

title: An Artists Piercing Yet Playful Look at Race
description: A charismatic video performer and creator of metaphorically loaded paintings and sculptures, Rodney McMillian addresses the experiences of African-Americans with an imaginative, angry yet often playful spirit. Based in Los Angeles, where he teaches at U.C.L.A., hes now having a well-deserved East Coast moment, with exhibitions running concurrently in New York at MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, and at the Studio Museum in Harlem; and in Philadelphia at the Institute of Contemporary Art.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, April 16 Through April 24
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: On Instagram, a Surfers Safari
description: @evangeiselman

title: Review: An All-Vivaldi Program, With a Twist or Two
description: Robin Hood. Savings and Loans. Musicians have different terms for the practice of bending the tempo. Shorthands like these are reminders that the Italian term rubato  meaning stolen time  should not be applied in one direction only, slowing down a phrase to milk it for expression. As the example of Robin Hood shows, a thief can also give back.

title: With Czechia, Czech Republic Hopes Vowels Will Solve Name Puzzle
description: The Czechs, pushed and pulled between East and West over the centuries, have long suffered from an identity crisis.

title: Uncovering a Deep-Sea Swarm of Zombie Crabs
description: In the murky depths of Panamas Pacific coast, marine biologists witnessed what looks like a scene from The Walking Dead: Thousands of crabs marching like a zombie horde.

title: Baseball Has Yet to Deliver Greatest Tribute to Jackie Robinson
description: For me, Jackie Robinson day is a celebration of struggle and perseverance, a reminder that hope and progress in civil rights are often mistimed allies.

title: Review: The First Monday in May Goes Behind the Scenes at the Met
description: Early in this ostensible documentary directed by Andrew Rossi, a title card comes close to boasting about the access the filmmakers had to the creation of the exhibition and the attendant gala that are the films subjects. The First Monday in May refers to a day every year on which New Yorks Metropolitan Museum of Art closes to host a star-studded benefit that coincides with the opening of a special exhibition from its Costume Institute.

title: Movie Listings for April 15-21
description: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Paul Ryan on Foreign Policy Is Closer to Hillary Clinton Than Donald Trump
description: WASHINGTON  I am not a neocon, House Speaker Paul D. Ryan said on Thursday, mapping out a series of foreign policy views that separated him from virtually all of the Republicans who have sought the presidential nomination this year.

title: Review: Rio, I Love You, Stories That Make Up a Mash Note to a City
description: The assumption behind omnibus movies  features built out of shorts by various directors, generally on a common theme  is that the contributions will, on balance, add up to a satisfying experience. But this law-of-averages thinking rarely yields a full meal for filmgoers. Usually, the results are a few good shorts, a few terrible shorts and a frustrating lack of cohesion.

title: A Preserved Kayak Floats an Exhibition in Alaska
description: An oiled sealskin kayak made around 1850 by Alutiiq artisans in Alaska spent decades largely forgotten in storage at Harvards Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology. The newly restored vessel has been shipped to the Alutiiq Museum in Kodiak, Alaska, for a 10-year loan. It goes on display next Friday.

title: Review: My Big Night, a Dark Farce Juggling Behind-the-Scenes Dramas
description: The show must go on in lex de la Iglesias sprawling ensemble dark comedy My Big Night, and it does, like an express train. It begins when a camera crane fatally crushes an extra during the filming of a New Years Eve variety TV show in which dancers and singers perform before a seated audience clad in formal wear. A producers indifference and desperate haste to remove the body, avoid liabilities and proceed with shooting give you an idea of where this frenzied, Almodvaresque backstage farce is going.

title: Comedy Listings for April 15-21
description: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

title: Meeting With Merrick Garland, G.O.P. Senators Take Long Time to Say No
description: WASHINGTON  Republican senators meeting with Judge Merrick B. Garland seem to take quite a long time to simply say no.

title: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, April 16 Through April 24
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Classical Music Listings for April 15-21
description: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

title: Review: In Green Room, a Scruffy Comic Flavor Turns Tense
description: In the opening scene of Green Room, the members of the Aint Rights, a punk band from the East Coast, wake up in a cornfield somewhere in the Pacific Northwest. The driver fell asleep at the wheel, the van is out of gas, and the hassles escalate after that. A promised gig falls through, a podcast interview becomes a little awkward, and the groups corporate assets, not counting the van and the gear inside it, add up to around $25 and a few takeout containers of rice and beans.

title: Review: The Midnight Assassin Recalls Murderous Mayhem in Austin
description: Skip Hollandsworth knows his way around a crime scene. Since 1989, he has written about a wide range of subjects for  Texas Monthly, but his most memorable pieces  featuring bank robbers, disappearing teenagers, murdered prostitutes  are about the grim events that get cordoned off behind yellow tape.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for April 15-21
description: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

title: Luxe, Orange Bags for Spring
description: This season, a handful of new purses pack a bright punch.

title: Jazz Listings for April 15-21
description: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

title: Review: Recycled Jungle Book Puts a Real Boy in a Forest of Pixels
description: Disneys new take on The Jungle Book is being touted as a live-action movie, though theres scarcely anything alive in it. That goes for the gaudy and glorious flora, the gathering clouds and the wind stirring them, all of which were created, with various degrees of believability, via computers. The child playing Mowgli  the human orphan turned wolf child  is played by an actual kid, who frolics with computer-generated critters, a smart call, given that animals can be tricky to work with and that some of this menageries real-life equivalents are (sorry to be a bummer) endangered.

title: Theater Listings for April 15-21
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for April 15-21
description: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, April 16 Through April 24
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Israeli Soldier to Be Charged With Manslaughter in Shooting of Palestinian Assailant
description: JERUSALEM  Israels military on Thursday said prosecutors intended to file a manslaughter charge against a soldier who fatally shot a Palestinian assailant in the head in the West Bank city of Hebron last month as he lay on a road, wounded and subdued.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Art in review, from Times critics.

title: Review: Our Last Tango Celebrates Two Virtuosos of the Form
description: German Krals documentary Our Last Tango is a combination of things, all fascinating: a portrait of Mara Nieves and Juan Carlos Copes, a world-renowned pair of tango dancers, and their professional partnership of almost 50 years; a stylized staging of their romantic and artistic history, performed by young dancers; and a celebration of the tango itself, which continues to bewitch with its writhing, gently jagged grace and torrid suggestiveness.

title: Bernie Sanders Laces Speech With Themes of Race, and Gets Warm Reception From Activists
description: Senator Bernie Sanders wove issues of race and civil rights into his standard speech about income inequality and overhauling the campaign finance system on Thursday as he sought to win over an influential crowd of black leaders.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, April 16 Through April 24
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: The Week in Pictures: April 15
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

title: Review: San Francisco Symphony at Carnegie Hall
description: With a series of enduringly popular works like Appalachian Spring and Rodeo, the gay, Jewish, Brooklyn-born Aaron Copland practically invented the sound we think of as American. Yet the composer of Fanfare for the Common Man could also be flinty, brash and radical.

title: Review: Miami City Ballet, a Troupe at Home Outside Its Turf
description: Bold, light, immediate, intensely musical, the dancing of Miami City Ballet flies straight to the heart. This company is now 30 years old; its long been of international stature, with successful seasons at the Edinburgh Festival (1994 and 1995) and in Paris (2011).

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for April 15-21
description: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

title: For Edge in a Faster N.H.L., Players Turn to Figure Skaters
description: BUFFALO  Sam Reinhart was at a rookie showcase in Toronto two years ago, months after the Buffalo Sabres drafted him second over all. There to have his photo taken for the sports-card maker Upper Deck, he took part in a video promotion in which a figure skating coach put him and other teenage prospects through pirouettes and pairs routines while they were wearing hockey equipment.

title: Review: The Return of Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt
description: Early in the second season of Netflixs Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt comes this exchange between Jacqueline (Jane Krakowski), a financially embarrassed Manhattan socialite, and Kimmy (Ellie Kemper), her effervescent nanny and all-around helpmate.

title: Review: Lea Salonga Puts on a Show, No Need for Wailing Pyrotechnics
description: Forget the saccharine ballads wailed by Disney princesses and other kitsch associated with the Broadway singer Lea Salonga, who appeared on Wednesday evening at Feinsteins/54 Below. Those songs were bunched into a medley that she performed near the end of her show, and fans of them cheered happily.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders, Boko Haram
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Los Sures Resurrects South Williamsburg in 1984
description: White Adidas kicks, boomboxes, break dancing  the 1984 documentary Los Sures is an eye-popping New York time capsule. There are other signs of those times, too, like graffiti, boarded-up buildings and empty lots that blemish the neighborhood in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where the film takes place. This is the old Williamsburg, back in the day, before it was synonymous with white expansionism and became grist for trend stories about beards, brew pubs and organic toys for pets, specifically the Williamsburg known in Spanish as Los Sures  the Souths or Southside.

title: Review: Katherine Jenkins, a Little Bit Classical, a Little Bit Pop
description: The diluted highbrow music known as classical crossover is much more popular in Britain than in the United States, where a major promotional effort several years ago failed to establish the Welsh mezzo-soprano Katherine Jenkins as the female Andrea Bocelli. But if you dont succeed, you can try again. And on Tuesday evening, Ms. Jenkins opened at Caf Carlyle with her Viva la Diva.

title: Review: Echo Park, the Story of an Early Romance
description: Im leaving in a few weeks time, so its a kind of a no-risk situation, Alex (Tony Okungbowa) says when asking out Sophie (Mamie Gummer). Sophie replies, I dont think theres such a thing. Shes right, at least in this case, and the more involved these two become, the more bittersweet Echo Park grows.

title: Review: In Wedding Doll, Search, and Struggle, to Find Independence and Romance
description: A young woman with a mild mental disability strives for independence in Nitzan Giladys drama Wedding Doll, and strives and strives against tribulations.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Review: The Measure of a Man, a Tale of a Mans Lost Labor
description: Midway through the quiet emotional storms in the French drama The Measure of a Man, the hero, Thierry, begins working as a supermarket security guard. Its a bitter victory. There is little thats secure about the job, which requires Thierry to view not just every customer but also each employee as a potential thief. Supplemented with the trappings of the badly paid  a stifling tie, ill-fitting jacket, squawking walkie-talkie  he embodies 21st-century labor at its most heroically alienated. As he stands and watches, liberty seems a distant promise, as do equality and fraternity.

title: Finding New Orleans Flavor Without Leaving Long Island
description: For many fans of New Orleans, there is no better time to be in the Crescent City than late April. Thats when the 10-day Jazz and Heritage Festival cuts the swampy humidity with a cool blast of jazz, blues, zydeco and gospel. Food stalls serve Creole and Cajun snacks like alligator pie and fried oysters, transforming the open-air concert series into a movable feast.

title: Spare Times for April 15-21
description: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

title: Review: Colonia Looks at a Dark Period in South American History
description: Colonia is set during a dark period in South American history, the early days of Gen. Augusto Pinochets dictatorship in Chile, but it somehow manages to feel more like a Hallmark Channel romance than like a serious film.

title: Spare Times for Children Listings for April 15-21
description: The Amazing Max (Saturday and Sunday) Max Darwin, a.k.a. the Amazing Max, may come across like the M.C. at a raucous bar mitzvah party, but he does know his craft, and now hes bringing it back to New York City for another round of shows. In this hourlong magic performance, he performs feats like mind reading, making objects disappear and then reappear, and sending coins raining from various parts of the body. The show includes lots of audience participation. (Through May 1.) At 3:30 p.m., Theater at Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71st Street, Manhattan, 866-811-4111, theamazingmax.com.

title: Authentic Mexican Food Amid a Nuevo-Taco Craze
description: As Ive told friends for years, if I ever get to heaven, I hope to find that its a parking lot, right off a great surf-break beach, lined with taco trucks. If theres one cuisine I could happily munch into eternity, its Mexican street food. I have been happy about the crop of upmarket taco restaurants sprouting around my home state the past few years, with their artisanal-tequila cocktail menus and chichi ingredients (crunchy kale, slow-roasted pork belly, spice-glazed duck breast).

title: Review: 13 Cameras, Keeping a Watchful Eye and Then Some
description: Note to renters: If, at your initial meeting, your potential landlord gives you the creeps, its probably best to keep looking. That basic rule, alas, is not followed by Claire (Brianne Moncrief) and Ryan (P. J. McCabe) in the goosebump-inducing 13 Cameras.

title: Matilda the Musical to Leave Broadway in January
description: Its time to bid farewell to those Revolting Children.

title: Bernie Sanders Takes on Wall Street With Art of the Steal Ad
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has made Wall Street banks public enemy No. 1 throughout his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination, and he now comes after the financial industry in its home market  with a tongue-in-cheek tweak of Donald J. Trump  in an ad titled The Art of the Steal.

title: Before Trump Campaign, Corey Lewandowski Rode Herd on a Towns Leaders
description: To Ross McLeod, a prosecutor and selectman in the town of Windham, N.H., it was a harmless hobby: running a small fantasy football league with a handful of friends and a pot of around $200 a year.

title: Donald Trump Draws Protesters Outside Republican Dinner in Manhattan
description: Demonstrators protesting the appearance of Donald J. Trump at a Republican Party event Thursday night reached a peak of around 1,000, but their ranks thinned and a splinter group of about 100 marchers headed into Midtown Manhattan.

title: Review: In Criminal, You Must Remember This
description: Hollywood loves to muck with the human brain, and in Criminal the beneficiary is Kevin Costner, who gets to deploy a full range of tics and quirks, playing a convict neurally altered in the name of national security.

title: At the Able Baker, Sugar, Butter and a Little Nostalgia
description: I fell in love with Julies scone the minute I tasted it. It was hard on the outside, soft on the inside, not excessively sweet but shamefully rich. I had one, and then I went back the next day and had another. My scone-a-day spree at the Able Baker in Maplewood continued, as I worked my way through every one of the almost one dozen varieties (cranberry ginger, pumpkin walnut, vanilla bean, fig pine nut and cherry coconut, to name a few), each with a cup of strong cappuccino. I realized that I needed to start every morning at Julies.

title: Chicagos Racist Cops and Racist Courts
description: AS a report by a panel commissioned by Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago found on Wednesday, racism in the citys Police Department is rampant: Blacks are disproportionately subjected to traffic stops, Tasers and street stops that do not lead to arrest; they also account for an appalling 74 percent of the 404 people shot by the Chicago police between 2008 and 2015.

title: Review: The Adderall Diaries, a Sprawl of Unreliable Memories
description: A father and son duke it out over who is the bigger victim in The Adderall Diaries, Pamela Romanowskys misbegotten adaptation of the 2009 memoir by Stephen Elliott.

title: Review: Homespun Flavors at Estancia Buenos Aires, in Larchmont
description: Estancia Buenos Aires, a modest Argentine steakhouse in Larchmont, opened in August without the huffing and puffing that usually comes with social-media-fueled restaurant openings. Owned by Gerardo Pulega and Edelmira Ibarra-Pulega, it offers a welcoming air and homey cuisine that, except for an outlier Waldorf salad and an entree of orange-glazed salmon filet with couscous, honors the motherland. The basic underpinnings  red meat and red wine  will appeal to anyone on a Paleo diet.

title: Review: In An Eye for Beauty, Gorgeous People Suffer, Too
description: Ugliness is a crime against humanity.

title: Muslim Students Report Burglaries and Hate Literature at Idaho State
description: Federal officials and the local police are investigating burglaries and hate literature that appear to be directed at Muslim students attending Idaho State University in Pocatello, where tensions have recently risen over an influx of students from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.

title: Review: Above and Below a Study of People on the Margins
description: The outer limits and the lower depths loom before us in Nicolas Steiners voyage into extremes, Above and Below. Mr. Steiners tightly interconnected documentary, with transporting shots, visits people on the margins in the United States, primarily transients in Las Vegas and the California desert, but also a participant in an earnest Mars research project.

title: Review: In New York, New York, Job Opportunities Complicate a Relationship
description: New York, New York has the feel of Shanghai noir. Its tightly shot scenes never reveal much context, and the rather cryptic subtitles can lead a viewer to mistaken conclusions until the identities and motivations of the characters click into focus.

title: Review: Sing Street Is an 80s Love Affair, Hair Gel Required
description: If you were not a teenager in the 1980s, John Carneys Sing Street is likely to beguile you with the sweet, universal energy of youth. By the same token, if you were a teenager in that much-maligned decade, the movie might make you feel old and a little cranky. Dont get me wrong. As a 21st-century moviegoer, I was touched by this pop fable ofRR But as a grizzled survivor of the age of Duran Duran, I found myself picking nits about its musical choices (most of which are three or four years out of sync with the plot) and occasionally resisting its winsome, cheeky, post-punk spirit.

title: Bernie Sanders Campaign Suspends Jewish Outreach Coordinator for Vulgar Remarks About Netanyahu
description: The Sanders campaigns announcement on Tuesday that Simone Zimmerman would be its national Jewish outreach coordinator delighted her fellow left-wing Jewish political activists and encouraged their belief that public expressions of disgust with the Israeli government had edged into the acceptable mainstream of Democratic politics.

title: Solving Mysteries at the American Museum of Natural History, Smartphone in Hand
description: If you visit the American Museum of Natural History on Sunday and see young people fixated on their smartphones, dont assume that theyve abandoned science for the joys of social media. These visitors are not absorbed in Angry Birds  though they may well be investigating bobtail squids or runaway bison.

title: Review: In Sky, a Woman Takes Refuge Among Strangers
description: Nowadays, the Wild, Wild West, that barren, mythologized frontier where good guys and outlaws used to shoot it out, may not be as overtly violent and lawless a territory as depicted in countless westerns. But its modern incarnation, portrayed in the French director Fabienne Berthauds intriguing misfire, Sky, feels only marginally more civilized. Ms. Berthauds third film to star Diane Kruger, this expressionistic portrait of the American West is an oddity that only a director from another country could have conjured.

title: Sumner Redstone Wont Have to Give Deposition in Competency Suit
description: The ailing media mogul Sumner M. Redstone will not be required to sit for a deposition in the legal battle over his mental competency, a California judge ruled during a brief hearing on Thursday.

title: The Photography Show Presented by Aipad at the Armory
description: Walking through the souk of 86 stalls that constitutes Aipad, the annual show of photograph dealers, this visitor was struck (and not for the first time) by the way certain themes have persisted throughout the history of the medium. Toshio Shibatas large color C-print Okawa Village, Tosa County, Kochi Prefecture, 2007, at the Laurence Miller Gallery, depicts the red steel trusses and cream yellow concrete guardrails of a bridge thrusting into a misty green forested hillside. Almost a century and a half before, Carleton Watkins photographed a rough-hewed wooden cabin alongside the Columbia River; a superb albumen print of The Garrison, Columbia River, c. 1867, is on view at Hans P. Kraus Jr. Fine Photographs. In both pictures, the care given to the lighting and to the composition manages to transform a man-made violation into something beautiful  a reminder of the cameras insidious power to aestheticize almost anything.

title: The Eye of the Trump Hurricane
description: Finally, an enterprising news outlet has persuaded Donald Trump to talk.

title: Group Buys Mike Piazzas 9/11 Jersey and Will Make a Gift of It
description: A significant Mike Piazza jersey that the Mets managed to let slip from their possession has been purchased by three minority owners of the team who intend to have it rotated on display at Citi Field, the 9/11 Memorial Museum and the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: Reaching Peak Greek at the Met Museum
description: Seen from on high, history is a grand sorting machine, loading on events, parsing populations, dividing time into nameable, datable piles. No one captures this process more grandly than the Metropolitan Museum of Art. And in Pergamon and the Hellenistic Kingdoms of the Ancient World, which opens on Monday, April 18, it is operating in truly epical form.

title: BATS Tries Again With I.P.O. on Its Own Exchange
