description: BATS Global Markets, whose attempt at an initial public offering on its own exchange was botched four years ago, is trying again.

title: Christies Auction: a Rock, a Basketball, Hitler on His Knees
description: Maybe you were looking forward to seeing David Hammonss 2006 rock head in the Mnuchin Gallerys acclaimed exhibition of the artist and figured you had plenty of time to get there, because the show doesnt close until May 27. Or maybe the head, with its tight helmet of dark hair, was something you had already admired and were planning to revisit.

title: Ninth Democratic Debate: Analysis
Bear Stearns Emails Show Its Financing Breaking Away
description: Within weeks of the shocking collapse of Bear Stearns in March 2008, I started interviewing former executives of the firm to try to figure out what had just happened and why.

title: The End for a Cleaners Where Little but the Name Has Changed
description: Originally, the name was Chanel French Cleaners, but that first C and H had to go.

title: On Zika, Congress Is Failing to Do Its Job
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has concluded that the Zika virus causes brain damage in babies born to infected women, which adds to the growing evidence that the virus is a major public health emergency. Yet Republicans in Congress are refusing to appropriate the money needed to respond to this crisis.

title: House Democrats Call for Curbs on Required Arbitration
description: A handful of House Democrats took to the floor of Congress on Thursday to call for an overhaul of arbitration, a private justice system for resolving disputes that is often slanted against consumers.

title: The Sins of the Chicago Police Laid Bare
description: No one who is even passingly familiar with the history of the Chicago Police Department can claim to be surprised by a new report showing that the department is plagued by systemic racism and operates with utter disregard for the lives of the black citizens whom it batters, maims and kills.

title: Retirees Rally at the Capitol, Protesting Pension Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Some 400,000 retirees who worked in the trucking, parcel delivery and grocery supply industries face drastic pension cuts on July 1 as a result of a little-noticed measure attached to a huge end-of-year spending bill passed in December 2014.

title: 69 Years Later, Philadelphia Apologizes to Jackie Robinson
description: Last summer, the Anderson Monarchs, a Philadelphia baseball team that featured the Little League World Series star Mone Davis, barnstormed through the South. They played baseball, and they also toured sites significant to the civil rights movement as a nod to the teams heritage  it is named, after all, for the Kansas City Monarchs, the Negro leagues club for which Jackie Robinson once played.

title: Col Allan, Longtime Editor of The New York Post, to Retire
description: Col Allan, the longtime editor in chief of The New York Post, announced on Thursday that he would retire at the end of the month after 42 years at the News Corporation, the publications owner.

title: Clinton and Sanders Campaigns to Sue Arizona Election Officials
description: PHOENIX  The Democratic Party and the presidential campaigns of Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are expected to file a suit on Friday against officials in Arizona over last months chaotic primaries, when thousands of voters in the states most populous county waited up to five hours to cast ballots and countless others gave up or were barred because of errors and misinformation.

title: Knicks Exit, as Phil Jackson Addresses Whats Next
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  After finishing exit interviews with the last of the Knicks on Thursday, Phil Jackson ambled into the pressroom at the teams headquarters, leaned against a lectern, looked out at a flock of reporters and let out a deep breath.

title: Yahoos Suitors Uncover Few Financial Details
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As Yahoo prepares to accept first-round bids for its core Internet business on Monday, potential buyers have found themselves facing one big problem: How do you value a company with a declining business when the company appears reluctant to share vital financial details?

title: California Appeals Court Reverses Decision to Overturn Teacher Tenure Rules
description: LOS ANGELES  A California appeals court ruled on Thursday that the states job protections for teachers do not deprive poor and minority students of a quality education or violate their civil rights  reversing a landmark lower court decision that had overturned the states teacher tenure rules.

title: Fred Hayman, Whose Giorgio Boutique Led Gilding of Rodeo Drive, Dies at 90
description: Fred Hayman, whose luxury boutique, Giorgio Beverly Hills, led the way in transforming Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills into a shopping destination for the rich and famous, died on Thursday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 90.

title: Dr. Peter J. Jannetta, Pioneering Neurosurgeon on Facial Pain, Dies at 84
description: Dr. Peter J. Jannetta, a neurosurgeon who as a medical resident half a century ago developed an innovative procedure to relieve an especially devastating type of facial pain, died on Monday in Pittsburgh. He was 84.

title: Health Officials Split Over Advice on Pregnancy in Zika Areas
description: As the Zika virus bears down on the United States, federal health officials are divided over a politically and ethically charged question: Should they advise American women to delay pregnancy in areas where the virus is circulating?

title: Dilma Rousseff Targeted in Brazil by Lawmakers Facing Scandals of Their Own
description: BRASLIA  Paulo Maluf, a Brazilian congressman, is so badly besieged by his own graft scandals that his constituents often describe him with the slogan Rouba mas faz. Translation: He steals but gets it done.

title: Colombia Reports First Cases of Microcephaly Linked to Zika Virus
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombian health officials said on Thursday that they had discovered two cases of microcephaly linked to the Zika virus, the first to be confirmed in the country since the infection began to spread there late last year.

title: National Briefing
description: A parole panel on Thursday recommended parole to a former Charles Manson follower, Leslie Van Houten, more than four decades after she went to prison. The decision, on her 20th parole hearing, is subject to an administrative review by the board. If upheld it goes to Gov. Jerry Brown, who has the final word on whether Ms. Van Houten, 66, will be released. Ms. Van Houten participated in the killings of Leno La Bianca and his wife, Rosemary, a day after other so-called Manson family members murdered the pregnant actress Sharon Tate and four others in 1969. (AP)

title: Bankruptcy of TransCare Strains New Yorks Emergency Services
description: At every moment, the population explosion of New York rolls across the city in not-so-slow motion. Last year, nearly 1.7 million people called 911 for medical help, the most since humans started answering telephones. On average thats about one call every 20 seconds.

title: Despite Timing, Bernie Sanders Says, Accepting Vatican Offer Was a Must
description: Senator Bernie Sanders, in the midst of a contentious battle for the Democratic nomination, says he could not refuse an invitation to visit the Vatican and talk about the world economy and social justice  two issues at the core of his presidential campaign  even if it meant he would be out of the country for days leading up to Tuesdays crucial primary in New York.

title: Review: The Father Examines the Lions Mind in Winter
description: He is a fortress unto himself, but a fortress under siege.

title: Things With Round Numbers
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  David Steinberg sure knows how to open a puzzle in a most surprising way. I would like to personally and publicly extend my thanks to Will Shortz and Joel Fagliano for re-cluing the entry FALSIES so that we are discussing eyelashes and not, well, you know. Even if Im used to seeing cosmetic eyelashes as fake eyelashes or false eyelashes.

title: James Cross Giblin, 82, Wide-Ranging Author of Books for Children, Dies
description: James Cross Giblin, an award-winning writer of nonfiction for children, whose books ranged from topics like cutlery and why we use it, windows and why we have them, and walls and why we need them to cleareyed biographies of Hitler, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and John Wilkes Booth, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Go on the Attack in Democratic Debate
description: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders jousted in a prime time debate, trading accusations about everything from guns to investment banks. Instead of offering a column or conventional analysis, Ive collected my live tweets as the debate unfoldedand here goes!

title: Civil Complaint in Three-Quarter Houses Case
description: A civil complaint, filed by the New York State attorney general's office, seeks more than $1.9 million in damages plus penalties from a couple facing felony charges of Medicaid fraud and money laundering in connection to "three-quarter" homes they ran  unregulated flophouses that are seen as somewhere between a regulated halfway house and an actual home.

title: Canada Extends Benefits to People of Mixed Aboriginal and European Ancestry
description: OTTAWA  A unanimous ruling released Thursday by the Supreme Court of Canada opened up a wide range of benefits and rights to about 600,000 Canadians of mixed aboriginal and European ancestry, ending a dispute that stretches back to the countrys founding.

title: Yankees Offensive Malaise Puts Scrutiny on Alex Rodriguez
description: TORONTO  As baseball players age, the skills that got them to the big leagues gradually erode. Pitchers whose high heat abandons them must learn to make the ball dart and dance. Hitters whose reflexes no longer allow them to uncoil and strike like a viper must learn to make their decisions earlier, committing to swing at a fastball that may not be one.

title: Donald Trump Seeks Help With West Bank Question During Meeting With Jewish Media
description: Donald J. Trump met with roughly 30 reporters for Jewish media outlets and with Orthodox Jewish activists in his office on Thursday afternoon. It did not go entirely smoothly, according to published reports.

title: Hector A. Cafferata, 86, Dies; Given Medal of Honor for Korea Heroics
description: Hector A. Cafferata Jr., a former Marine private who received the nations highest military honor for single-handedly holding off an enemy regiment during the Korean War and safeguarding his comrades from a live grenade until he was felled by a snipers bullet, died on Tuesday in Venice, Fla. He was 86.

title: In Democratic Debate, Clinton and Sanders Spar Over Judgment
description: Senator Bernie Sanders, seizing on potential vulnerabilities for Hillary Clinton in the coming New York primary, repeatedly savaged her ties to wealthy donors and Wall Street banks during their debate on Thursday night, delivering a ferocious performance that Mrs. Clinton countered with steely confidence and her own sharp elbows.

title: First-Quarter Growth Slows a Bit in China, as Expected
description: HONG KONG  Chinas growth rate slowed as expected in the first three months of the year, but a notable pickup in debt-driven industrial activity last month probably cushioned the slowdown.

title: Former Rikers Inmate Cant Identify Officer He Believes Ordered His Attack
description: When Jahmal Lightfoot finally had the chance to confront the man who he believed had ordered his beating at Rikers Island in July 2012, he could not.

title: Stephen Currys Season: In a Word, Golden
description: The excellence of the Warriors 73 wins was embodied by their star Stephen Curry. Here are some of his notable 3-pointers from this season, when he made a record-shattering 402.

title: Walter Rosen, Longtime Steward of Juniors Restaurant, Dies at 81
description: Much of Walter Rosens life was spent on the corner of Flatbush Avenue Extension and DeKalb Avenue in Downtown Brooklyn.

title: Five Big Questions After a High-Stakes Democratic Debate
description: Did Bernie Sanders successfully paint Hillary Clinton as a pawn of Wall Street?

title: Highlights From the Democratic Debate
description: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton met in the Democratic presidential debate Thursday night in New York, where each has a major history.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Ive seen people die well and Ive seen people die in misery. I want Canadians to have access to the best care possible.

title: North Korea Ballistic Missile Launch a Failure, Pentagon Says
description: MANILA  North Korea launched a missile early Friday  apparently to mark the 104th birthday of its founding leader, Kim Il-sung, the grandfather of the current leader, Kim Jong-un. But the test was a failure, according to American and South Korean defense officials.

title: Clinton and Sanders Show Their Exhaustion
description: Whew.

title: At G.O.P. Dinner, Donald Trump Serves Heaping Helping of New York Values
description: Join us for New York primary live updates.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | shyster
description: shyster  \shis-tr\  noun

title: What to Watch Friday
description: Ellie Kemper makes a new life for herself, going against the odds in New York City, in the second season of Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt. A couple reappear after a long absence and suggest dinner in the Karyn Kusama thriller The Invitation. And Conan OBrien travels to South Korea.

title: Transcript: Democratic Presidential Debate in Brooklyn
description: Following is a transcript of the Democratic debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

title: Who Won the Debate? Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Draw Even
description: Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders on Thursday had the most contentious debate of their primary battle, just days before Tuesdays crucial New York contest. They clashed over Israel, the minimum wage, campaign finance, tax returns and Wall Street speeches. Commentators and critics largely scored the debate as even on substance, but the Vermont senator may have lost some style points for coming across as overly angry.

title: Corrections: April 15, 2016
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: The Week in Pictures: April 15
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

title: The End of Catholic Guilt
description: The comedian George Carlin used to say that he was a Roman Catholic until I reached the age of reason. For Carlin, that happened sometime in the eighth grade, when all his probing questions about faith were answered with, well, its a mystery. Of course, as a lifelong contrarian, Carlin also wondered if it was O.K. for a vegetarian to eat animal crackers.

title: End Potential Conflict of Interest in de Blasio Administration
description: A federal corruption investigation is reportedly looking into Mayor Bill de Blasios campaign fund-raising, among other things. The inquiry includes two businessmen who raised a lot of money for the mayor, several top officials of the New York Police Department and the mayors tax-exempt lobbying group, the Campaign for One New York. Where the investigation is going and what it will find is, for now, anyones guess. There are many unconnected dots.

title: What Is Inspiration?
description: For decades, Anders Ericsson has reminded us of the value of hard work. The Florida State psychologist did the research that led to the so-called 10,000-hour rule. In his informative new book, Peak, he and co-author Robert Pool downplay the importance of native-born genius (even in people like Mozart) and emphasize the importance of deliberate practice  painstaking exercises to perfect some skill.

title: The Pastrami Principle
description: A couple of months ago, Jeb Bush (remember him?) posted a photo of his monogrammed handgun to Twitter, with the caption America. Bill de Blasio, New Yorks mayor, responded with a picture of an immense pastrami sandwich, also captioned America. Advantage de Blasio, if you ask me.

title: Straight From High School to a Career
description: CANDIDATES from both parties have been talking a lot about the loss of American jobs, declining wages and the skyrocketing cost of college.

title: As Bernie Sanders Heads to Vatican, a Visit With Pope Francis Seems in Doubt
description: On the campaign trail and in Congress, Senator Bernie Sanders has frequently invoked Pope Francis, quoting his writings about the idolatry of money, sending solicitations for donations headlined Why we must listen to Pope Francis and praising the pope as a radical for speaking out with courage and brilliance about some of the most important issues facing our world.

title: News Qs | Chinese Scions Song: My Daddys Rich and My Lamborghinis Good-Looking
description: The following lesson activities are based on the article Chinese Scions Song: My Daddys Rich and My Lamborghinis Good-Looking.

title: Its Been a Long Time Coming
A Capstone, Not an End, to James Levines Career
description: In all kinds of institutions, from universities to performing arts organizations, an emeritus position is a prestigious post. This understanding has sometimes been lost in recent years during the speculation over whether, and when, James Levine might step aside as music director of the Metropolitan Opera. Music director emeritus is an honor  the capstone of a career, and hardly its finale.

title: Tiny Home Survival Checklist
description: Extreme domestic downsizing is like playing the stock market  you have to be aggressive and unsentimental. While every situation is different, rules can help sustain body and soul in cramped quarters.

title: At U.N., Ambassadors Hold Auditions for Next Secretary General
description: UNITED NATIONS  Think of these as the United Nations primaries.

title: Clinton vs. Sanders vs. Trump: Who Is the True New Yorker?
description: Ahead of the states April 19 primary, three presidential candidates have been working to highlight their New York-iness to voters. We had Matt Flegenheimer, a Times campaign reporter, assess their attributes.

title: Student Question | How Often Does Your Family Eat Together?
description: It seems that eating meals together as a family can have all sorts of benefits for families and children. Do you think thats true?

title: When It Comes to a Veil, Brides Can Take It or Leave It
description: Molly Guy, the owner of Stone Fox Bride, a SoHo bridal shop, often finds herself catering to an unconventional client, one inclined to tweak or entirely dispense with tradition  and with it the wearing of a wedding veil.

title: Inquiries Cloud de Blasios Bid to Come Off as Strong Manager Before 17 Race
description: It was not even a month ago that Mayor Bill de Blasio led a boisterous rally in Foley Square to celebrate the passage of key elements of his affordable housing plan. It was meant to be a pivotal moment in Mr. de Blasios tenure, a victory that would position him to better attend to New York Citys nuts-and-bolts needs  something of a requisite as he approaches re-election next year.

title: A Shoehorn Helps
description: Some New Yorkers care far more about location than home size. For them, a dollhouse in the desired neighborhood will do.

title: A Tiny Home by Choice in New York City
description: On the emotional fulcrum of New York City apartment-hunting, size and setting are forever in sway. Does a park view trump a guest bedroom? Is a vast kitchen worth settling blocks from a trendy thoroughfare? Usually, a compromise is struck. Unless it isnt.

title: Spains Industry Minister Steps Down Over Panama Papers Revelations
description: MADRID  The Spanish minister of industry, energy and tourism resigned Friday morning after documents in the Panama Papers linked him to offshore investments in the Bahamas, and news reports then connected him to a company in the tax haven of Jersey.

title: From Sleep to Sushi: Guidance for Confused Parents
description: Is sleep training supported by science? Can you eat sushi when youre pregnant? For a generation of parents who grew up on Google, clear answers to simple parenting questions arent always easy to find.

title: Review: Elektra at the Met Does Full Justice to Strausss Masterpiece
description: The prospect of a premiere production at the Metropolitan Opera typically generates advance speculation and high hopes among fans. But the director Patrice Chreaus production of Strausss Elektra, which opened at the Met on Thursday night, has already been deemed a landmark of contemporary opera staging.

title: Brooklyn Debate Takeaways: Sarcasm, Snideness and Smackdowns
description: The Democratic debate on Thursday night played out as a magnified version of the primary race. The personal clashes between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont were harsher. Their policy differences gaped wider. And the stakes, for both candidates, were as high as they have ever been.

title: Ask Well:  Do I Need the Shingles Vaccine if Ive Had Shingles?
description: Question:

title: Morning Agenda: Yahoos Potential Bidders Frustrated Over Lack of Figures
description: YAHOOS POTENTIAL BIDDERS FRUSTRATED OVER LACK OF FIGURES | As Yahoo gets ready to field bids for its core Internet business, potential suitors are wondering just what, exactly, is for sale,  Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. Yahoo executives have informed potential bidders about the companys  pessimistic financial outlook for this year, but they have refused to reveal projections for 2017 or answer questions about crucial parts of the business.

title: Brazils Embattled President
description: A divided country weighs the future of Dilma Rousseff.

title: Your Friday Briefing: Bernie Sanders, Facebook Messenger, The Jungle Book
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Erdogan and Merkels Comic Comeuppance
description: BERLIN  THOUGH its a fact often overlooked by the rest of the world, Germany is a funny place  seriously. Long before Jon Stewart and Samantha Bee redefined topical American humor, comedians here perfected the art of sharp political satire.

title: New York Today: A Bitter Battle in Brooklyn
description: Updated, 11:18 a.m.

title: Obama Presses for Open Market for Cable Set-Top Boxes
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday announced his support for opening the market for cable set-top boxes, singling out the devices in millions of homes as a clunky and outdated symbol of corporate power over consumers, as he introduced a broad federal effort to increase competition.

title: The Gift of a Lost Coat
description: Midseason, with plenty of New England cold stretched ahead of us, our 12-year-old daughter, Birdy, lost her winter coat. This was not a tragedy. Things are only things, after all.

title: How to Clean a Pollock Masterpiece: Very Carefully
description: DSSELDORF, Germany  Jackson Pollocks mural-size 1950 drip painting Number 32, a stark, apocalyptic composition of black industrial paint on untreated canvas, is considered one of the most radical works of Abstract Expressionism.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Preventing Blisters, Arthritis in Women and Zika
description: Take the Quiz

title: The 4.3.16 Issue
description: RE: ON PHOTOGRAPHY

title: How to Surf a Crowd
description: You have to let the fear go, says Merrill Nisker, a musician and performance artist better known as Peaches. At some point in every show, she steps off the stage into the audience. Sometimes shes upright, walking onto peoples upstretched hands; other times, she lies back, carried by the crowd. You must trust the throng, even knowing that things can go awry (once, an audience member clawed Peachess thigh with sharp fingernails). The surfer and the surfed share the same adrenaline. It is the ultimate way to connect, she says.

title: A Sudden Breach in Uganda
description: A few years ago, when I was still relatively new to the tour-guide business, a company hired me to show an American photographer around Rwanda and Uganda. Six days in, we had toured a rain forest in the southwest of Rwanda, spent two days with the mountain gorillas and crossed over the Ugandan border. Now we were in the town of Kabale, in the hills of Southwestern Uganda. Everything was going well.

title: The Pier Leaps Out
description: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: The Battle Over the Sea-Monkey Fortune
description: To hear more audio stories from publishers, like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Amy Pressman of Medallia: Bored by Yes, Inspired by No
description: This interview with Amy Pressman, co-founder and president of Medallia, a provider of customer service technology, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: A Study on Fats That Doesnt Fit the Story Line
description: There was a lot of news this week about a study, published in the medical journal BMJ, that looked at how diet affects heart health. The results were unexpected because they challenged the conventional thinking on saturated fats.

title: Democratic Debate Serves as Clear Display of Love Lost
description: The Brooklyn-based Democratic debate between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, possibly the last before the party convention in July, evoked a singular memory for some New York reporters: It was of a photograph of Edward I. Koch and Mario M. Cuomo sitting on a couch in a holding room for a mayoral debate in 1977, clearly sick of each other.

title: Poetry Pairing | viewfinder
description: Happy National Poetry Month!

title: In Paris, a Hotel with a Bargain Price and Style to Spare
description: From 23 euros (about $26) for shared rooms with bunk beds and storage lockers. Rooms with two single beds and a private terrace start at 108 euros ($123).

title: A Detroit Restaurant That Shows Michigan Pride
description: Hazel Park, a Detroit suburb, is home to a wrestling supply shop, several family dentistry practices, and numerous Greek-American diners, but until last September, it had never seen a restaurant quite like Mabel Gray. With its artfully exposed plaster walls, perfectly mismatched vintage tableware, and a seasonal menu showcasing local ingredients and whole-animal butchery, the restaurant initially appears to have been airlifted from Brooklyn. But never mind appearances: Mabel Gray is thoroughly of, by and for Michigan.

title: Among the Elephants in Thailand
description: Tim Bewer, 45, a Wisconsin native, has lived in Khon Kaen, Thailand, since 2007. Five years ago, Mr. Bewer, who contributes to Lonely Planet Thailand, and his wife, Suttawan Intarapanich, started Isan Explorer, a company that arranges private tours in the northeastern region. In 2014, the couple, inspired by the work of a Thai elephant advocate, changed the elephant portion of their tours to focus on the animals well-being. Following are edited excerpts from a conversation with Mr. Bewer.

title: Belgiums Transportation Minister Resigns Amid Outcry
description: LONDON  The transportation minister of Belgium resigned on Friday, after the publication of leaked reports from the European Commission warning of security deficiencies at Brussels Airport, the site of two deadly terrorist bombings on March 22.

title: Spanish Castles Restoration, Called Disaster by Some, Wins Prize
description: PARIS  Last month, the ancient castle of Matrera in southern Spain fell under siege by critics who mocked its unusual restoration as a barbarity. Now, an online architects community has returned fire, honoring the work this week with a preservation prize.

title: Finding a New Direction When a Plum Job Turns Sour
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: In South China Sea Visit, U.S. Defense Chief Flexes Military Muscle
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. JOHN C. STENNIS, in the South China Sea  Over the last week in Asia, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter has visited two aircraft carriers, revealed new military agreements with India and the Philippines, and generally signaled that the Obama administration had decided to lean more on military power to counter Chinas territorial ambitions in the region.

title: Tax Return Not Done? File for an Extension
description: EVEN though taxpayers have a few extra days this year to file their federal income tax returns, some still wont make the deadline. So with tax day approaching on Monday, its time to think about filing an extension.

title: This Weeks Movies | April 15, 2016
description: The New York Times film critics review The Jungle Book, Sing Street and Barbershop: The Next Cut.

title: Reclaiming Fees When Airline Luggage Goes Astray
description: Buried in the new bill reauthorizing the Federal Aviation Administration are a few sections addressing the fees that many of us pay to fly. And while the Senate and the House bills still differ a bit, one likely result is going to be this: The carriers are going to have to refund the fees you pay when your luggage isnt on your flight and you have to wait a long time to get it.

title: Taiwan Fears Fraud Suspects in Malaysia May Be Deported to China
description: HONG KONG  Officials in Taiwan raised concerns on Friday that dozens of fraud suspects from Taiwan were at risk of being sent from Malaysia to China, much as Kenya deported a similar group of suspects this week.

title: Celebrating Passover, With All the Comforts of a Resort
description: Efrem Goldberg, a Modern Orthodox rabbi in suburban Miami, jokes that for the eight days of Passover, he gets to be a visiting scholar by just staying home. Half of his congregants go away, but many who remain have family members visiting. So the synagogue stays full, but many faces are unfamiliar.

title: Losing Ground Meditates on Art as It Examines a Marriage in Peril
description: Barely released in 1982 and all but unseen for over three decades, Kathleen Collinss Losing Ground is a lively movie  as well as a ghostly one. Ms. Collins and her two male leads, Bill Gunn and Duane Jones, died long before the film resurfaced at Lincoln Center in early 2015 as part of a survey of independent African-American cinema produced in New York between 1968 and 1986.

title: Why Is This Matzo Different From All Other Matzos?
description: SEVERAL years ago, at a family Seder, I tasted a matzo I actually liked. It was misshapen and lightly burned, distinguishing it from the machine-made matzo of my youth. And this one possessed something that I had never experienced with matzo: It had flavor. What can I say? Up until that moment, the best matzo of my life was not much better than the worst matzo of my life; you could taste the struggle in every bite. For the first time I ate matzo and thought, This is delicious.

title: 1941: Roosevelt to Arm U.S. Ships
description: WASHINGTON  President Roosevelt indicated this afternoon [April 15] that American ships delivering war supplies to the British and their allies, across the Atlantic and elsewhere, including the Red Sea route to the Suez Canal, would have armed protection.

title: Ukraine Says Stolen Dutch Art Has Been Recovered
description: AMSTERDAM  Four Dutch Golden Age paintings that were stolen from the Westfries Museum in Hoorn, the Netherlands, 11 years ago were recovered by the Ukrainian secret services, the Ukrainian government has said.

title: The Times on the Air: Bad Bots, Big Banks and More
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. Below are highlights from television and radio interviews featuring Times reporters and columnists.

title: When Dividing Assets, the Little Things Matter
description: People often spend a lot of time crafting estate plans that lay out how their big assets  from cash to homes and securities  will be divided among their children, grandchildren and everyone else down the line. But they sometimes give far less thought to the other stuff  those personal effects that may have little monetary value but so much sentimental value. Yet it is the decisions about those items that often cause problems in a family.

title: A Midtown Traffic Ticket
description: Dear Diary:

title: Mitel Networks Agrees to Buy Polycom for $1.8 Billion
description: Mitel Networks of Canada said on Friday that it had agreed to buy Polycom, a telecommunications and video conferencing equipment provider, for $1.8 billion in cash and stock.

title: Chinese General Visits Disputed Spratly Islands in South China Sea
description: BEIJING  Chinas most senior uniformed military commander paid a visit in recent days to the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea, the countrys Ministry of National Defense said on Friday.

title: Hillary Clintons Message in a Jacket
description: As soon as Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont appeared onstage Thursday night for the Democratic debate, we probably should have known we were in for an evening of opposition.

title: How to Negotiate Your Rent
description: Looking to sign a new lease on a New York City apartment? Now is the time to negotiate.

title: E.U.s Five Biggest Economies Join Tax Crackdown After Panama Papers
description: LONDON  With political aftershocks still being felt after the leak of the so-called Panama Papers, the European Unions five biggest economies, including Britain and Germany, have agreed to share information on company ownership to try clamping down on tax evasion.

title: BlackRock Wields Its Big Stick Like a Wet Noodle on C.E.O. Pay
description: For several years, Laurence D. Fink, chairman and chief executive of BlackRock, the money management giant, has been on a crusade, exhorting corporations to change their short-term ways. Executives should forgo tricks that reward short-term stock traders, he argues, like share buybacks purchased at high valuations. Instead, corporate managers should focus on creating value for long-term shareholders.

title: U.S. Cites Extramarital Affairs as Misuse of Power in Sheldon Silver Case
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have evidence that Sheldon Silver, the former speaker of the New York Assembly, engaged in extramarital relationships with two women connected to his position in Albany, according to newly unsealed court documents.

title: Saudi Arabia Moves to Curb Its Feared Religious Police
description: Saudi Arabia announced steps this week to rein in its religious police, which is responsible for ensuring morality, piety and adherence with Islamic law but has become the target of mounting criticism in recent years.

title: Artist Nurtures a Creative Oasis in Conservative Saudi Arabia
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Abdulnasser Gharem has exhibited his work in world-class museums and sold pieces at auction for hundreds of thousands of dollars, and is widely considered one of Saudi Arabias leading contemporary artists.

title: How Orphaned Orangutans Messed With a Reporters Mind
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Joe Cochrane, The Timess correspondent in Indonesia, shares the personal side of reporting on endangered animals in far-flung places.

title: Microsoft Goes on Offensive Against Justice Department
description: Sometimes, you have to go on the offensive. That appears to be the thinking behind a lawsuit filed by Microsoft on Thursday against the Justice Department, arguing that the government is wrongly preventing the software giant from letting customers know when investigators armed with a court order have obtained customer data.

title: Putting Your Smartphone on a Data Diet
description: Q. Now that I know how to check my smartphones cellular data usage, what can I do to conserve more of my monthly allowance?

title: Citigroups Profit Plummets, but Beats Expectations
description: Citigroups profit and revenue plunged in the first quarter, as the bank became the latest large financial institution to report lackluster results.

title: Kiki and Herb: Kitsch, With a Whisky Chaser
description: At first glance, a Kiki and Herb cabaret show could come off as a bizarre and politically incorrect, yet addictive, mess. Kiki, with the faded glamour of Norma Desmond, sings deranged takes on Top 40 hits and slurs through tactless banter about current events. Herb, with sprayed-on gray hair and a kitschy suit, hammers a keyboard and sips Canadian Club. A medley might start with Frosty the Snowman and end with Patti Smith.

title: Five Things I Wont Miss at The Times  and Seven I Will
description: While preparing to leave the public editors office and move to Washington, Ive been getting together in recent weeks with some people Ive met while living in New York. One was Ben Smith, the editor in chief of BuzzFeed, who asked me over lunch what columns I planned to do before I left. I tossed it back to him, asking what he would like to read, and he suggested I take up what I love and what I hate about The New York Times.

title: At Debate, Hillary Clinton Leaves Questions About Approach to Banks
description: A jarring regulatory action this week against five large banks was bound to bring Wall Street to the fore in the Democratic presidential debate on Thursday. Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders differ on how to handle banks that are deemed too big to fail.

title: Why I Havent Felt The Bern
description: Todays column offers an opportunity to say, for the record, why I havent been the Bernie booster a lot of people apparently expected me to be. For the business about discounting Clinton support as coming from conservative states in the Deep South actually exemplifies the problem I saw in the Sanders campaign from the beginning, and made me distrust both the movement and the man.

title: Clinton, Sanders and the Crowd Bring the Noise in Brooklyn Debate
description: Thursday night, Democrats did what party people do in Brooklyn. They rented out a big space on the waterfront and held a rave. Along with a few rants.

title: Angela Merkel Draws Criticism for Allowing Turkeys Case Against Comic
description: BERLIN  Turkeys president found himself in choice company when he fixed upon an obscure German law to attempt to punish a popular comic who had satirized him in crude terms. The same law, dating from 1871, had also been used to silence critics of the Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi of Iran and the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet.

title: As Chinas Growth Slows, Banks Feel the Strain of Bad Debt
description: HONG KONG  For Chinese banks, the decision to lend to companies like Bohai Steel was for years a no-brainer. Lenders took heart from its state backing, which appeared as solid as the millions of tons of steel pipes that rolled off its production lines each year.

title: LVMH Executive Responds to Documentary Film
description: PARIS  Bernard Arnault, the head of the luxury giant LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, who is the subject of a satirical documentary that has been adopted by a movement protesting changes to the French labor code, spoke publicly for the first time about the film this week at a shareholders meeting.

title: Inside the List
description: Peer Review: The geobiologist Hope Jahren  her memoir, Lab Girl, hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 7  has found a larger audience than many scientists partly through her use of social media. Jahren is prolific on Twitter, and since 2013 has maintained a lively free-range blog, Hope Jahren Sure Can Write, that is nominally about interactions between men and women and academia but is more accurately, and haphazardly, about things (as she puts it on her masthead). What sorts of things? A tribute to Leonard Nimoy, for one: Nothing less than God himself ... could take Spock away from us. For another, a cheese recipe written in pitch-perfect lolcat dialect: Ferst-thing ur going store to buyz 1 gallun hole milk. And yes, theres plenty about sexism in science, including a scathing reply Jahren wrote after a male colleague challenged her work in an email he mistakenly sent to her instead of their department head. Why, she asked, are there any women in science at all? I keep asking myself. Is the price that I paid and keep paying worth it? I am sure that you believe that youve struggled during your career. ... Did you ever spend a night in a Turkish police station trying to explain the concept of rape? No? Well, I did. It can really disrupt your field season, boy howdy. She ended: You didnt ask for my advice, but I am going to give you some anyway: Learn to use your email. ... But dont be discouraged, youre way ahead of me. Youve already learned how to type out what you really think and send it out into the world. I am just now learning how to do the same.

title: Ireland vs. Empire
description: Was it needless death after all? Yeats asked that question in Easter 1916, his poem about the Easter Rising, the armed insurrection by Irish republicans against British rule. That event occurred 100 years ago this month, and a fleet of new and reissued books commemorates its centenary. Heres a look at some of the most noteworthy titles on this history shelf:

title: Corey Lewandowski Says He Reached Out to Reporter After Encounter
description: Corey Lewandowski, the campaign manager for Donald J. Trump, said on Friday that he had tried to contact the reporter who filed battery charges against him shortly after their altercation last month in hopes of clearing up the matter.

title: The Translation of Love, by Lynne Kutsukake
description: THE TRANSLATION OF LOVEBy Lynne Kutsukake318 pp. Doubleday. $25.95.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: A Woman of Property, by Robyn Schiff
description: A WOMAN OF PROPERTYBy Robyn Schiff81 pp. Penguin Poets. Paper, $20.

title: The Stopped Heart, by Julie Myerson
description: THE STOPPED HEARTBy Julie Myerson500 pp. Harper Perennial. Paper, $15.99.

title: The Long Shadow of Small Ghosts, by Laura Tillman
description: THE LONG SHADOW OF SMALL GHOSTSMurder and Memory in an American CityBy Laura Tillman241 pp. Scribner. $26.

title: Americas War for the Greater Middle East, by Andrew J. Bacevich
description: AMERICAS WAR FOR THE GREATER MIDDLE EASTA Military HistoryBy Andrew J. BacevichIllustrated. 453 pp. Random House. $30.

title: Alibaba: The House That Jack Ma Built, by Duncan Clark
description: ALIBABAThe House That Jack Ma BuiltBy Duncan ClarkIllustrated. 287 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

title: Superpowers
description: BLOOD YEARThe Unraveling of Western CounterterrorismBy David Kilcullen288 pp. Oxford University, $24.95.

title: The Butcher Bird by S. D. Sykes, and More
description: How can you top the Black Death? In her first novel, Plague Land, S. D. Sykes presented us with a disturbingly credible view of the devastating pandemic that wiped out half the population of England in the 14th century. In her sequel, THE BUTCHER BIRD (Pegasus Crime, $25.95), the plague has passed, leaving the ancient feudal system in chaos and the rule of law degenerating in the face of mob violence.

title: Paperback Row
description: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: Editors Choice
description: Nine new books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.

title: Kremlin Apologizes to German Newspaper for Wrongly Tying It to Goldman Sachs
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia misspoke when he said that the German newspaper Sddeutsche Zeitung was owned by Goldman Sachs, an American investment bank.

title: Tribeca Interview: Patton Oswalt on Nerdland
description: Chris Prynoskis animated film Nerdland, which had its premiere at Tribeca on Thursday night, follows the exploits of two Los Angeles friends, one an aspiring screenwriter (voiced by Patton Oswalt) and one an aspiring actor (voiced by Paul Rudd), both hungry for fame but lacking in talent or much of a clue. The New York Times critic Mike Hale called it a scatological Hollywood satire. The movie, written by Andrew Kevin Walker (Seven) and produced by the animation company Titmouse, takes a piercing look at celebrity-obsessed culture and those misguided souls trying to achieve some level of fame at any cost.

title: A Love at First Sight, Seen Clearly at Last
description: When Nancy Balbirer and Howard Morris met as drama students at New York University in 1983, they developed a crush on each other that almost led to romance.

title: Seeking Oyster Perfection? Steam Them
description: RICHMOND, Va.  You see raw oysters everywhere these days, as well as roasted ones and fried ones and Rockefeller ones. What you dont encounter as often, at least not in American restaurants, are oysters that have been steamed.

title: Emma Clines Brooklyn Writing Shed
description: The first-time novelist on the studio where she wrote her highly anticipated debut, The Girls.

title: A Writers Room: Emma Cline
description: The first-time novelist on the Brooklyn garden shed where she wrote her highly anticipated debut, The Girls.

title: Getting the Art Out on the Streets
description: Public art, whether the public knows it or not, is becoming more of a private enterprise.

title: Pope Francis Cites Travel Plans for Not Greeting Bernie Sanders and Others at Vatican Event
description: VATICAN CITY  Senator Bernie Sanders did not get to meet with Pope Francis inside Vatican City on Friday, but its not because the pontiff didnt want to.

title: How Not to Reform Social Security
description: Study after study has shown that one of the ways the rich are different from everyone else is that they live longer. And while there is no one cause for their increased longevity, there is one undeniable effect. Rich, long-lived people are a double drain on Social Security. They collect bigger benefits and they do so for a longer time than non-rich, shorter-lived beneficiaries.

title: Reenacting a Romance
description: Nancy Balbirer and Howard Morris, who met as drama students at N.Y.U., were married on March 25 after spending three decades as friends.

title: A $14 Million Co-op for Michael R. Bloomberg
description: Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, apparently looking to someday create a double-wide mansion for himself on the Upper East Side, paid $14,000,000 for a triplex at the co-op townhouse next to his Beaux-Arts limestone house. The transaction was one of the most expensive closed sales of the week, according to city records.

title: A Fine Line Separates Ball and Fan (and Injury)
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Target Field, home of the Minnesota Twins, is one of those wondrous new ballparks that combine modern amenities with an old-timey feel. With a capacity under 40,000, its the kind of stadium people describe as intimate.

title: Dont Denigrate Decorators
description: To the Editor:

title: Game of Thrones Creators Said to Be Considering Shorter Seasons
description: The sixth season of Game of Thrones, beginning April 24, might be the shows last full-length one, if the creators get their way.

title: Mayday on the Carolina Queen
description: The seven fishermen aboard the Carolina Queen III, a 76-foot scalloping boat that set out from Norfolk, Va., had been at sea for four days when the skies darkened off the coast of the Rockaways.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: At the Existentialist Caf'
description: This week, Sarah Bakewell discusses her new book about the existentialists; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Liesl Schillinger talks about a new biography of Blanche Knopf; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Condos in a Williamsburg Warehouse
description: Not many warehouses come with design accolades, but one of the few remaining relics of the old Brooklyn waterfront has not one, but two distinguished architects to add some prestige.

title: Why Theres Hope for the Middle Class (With Help From China)
description: America has often thought of itself as a middle-class nation  one in which most people are merely comfortable and neither very rich nor very poor.

title: At the Mets Roof Garden, Raising a PsychoBarn
description: The whir of electric drills, the sharp pop of hammer blows and the beep-beep-beep of construction equipment backing up were almost drowning out the British artist Cornelia Parker on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art last week.

title: 36 Hours in Tangier
description: The Moroccan port city that lured Paul Bowles and Jean Genet is in turnaround mode, but its classic draws  iconic cafes, long beaches  remain.

title: Prey
description: Invasive species are on the menu at the chef Bun Lais pop-up in Miami Beach.

title: Eradicating Invasive Species One Sushi Roll at a Time
description: MIAMI BEACH  Plenty of chefs have burns on their forearms, but Bun Lais battle scars did not come from hot oven racks. His were a result of an inadvertent brush with fire coral while scuba diving for ingredients off the Florida coast.

title: BATS Shares Climb in I.P.O., Marking Years Biggest Deal
description: Shares of BATS Global Markets began trading on Friday, claiming the title of the largest deal of the year so far, though the exchange operators biggest feat was avoiding technical problems like those that doomed its first attempt to go public four years ago.

title: League Will Allow Ads on Jerseys and May Reassess All-Star Game Site
description: Last month, after legislation was signed in North Carolina limiting restroom access for transgender people and forbidding local governments to create their own antidiscrimination ordinances based on sexual orientation, the N.B.A. released an official statement questioning whether it could successfully host the 2017 All-Star Game in Charlotte.

title: Candidates Make Their Case at U.N.
description: Candidates for secretary general of the United Nations pitched themselves before the General Assembly this week.

title: Smitten by Bernie Sanders, Working Families Party Cant Show It in Primary
description: Join us for New York primary live updates.

title: Choosing Between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
