description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: A New Map for America
description: THESE days, in the thick of the American presidential primaries, its easy to see how the 50 states continue to drive the political system. But increasingly, thats all they drive  socially and economically, America is reorganizing itself around regional infrastructure lines and metropolitan clusters that ignore state and even national borders. The problem is, the political system hasnt caught up.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a four-bedroom in Greenwich, Conn., and a five-bedroom in Matinecock, N.Y.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks homes are on the Upper East Side, in Midtown East, and in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Set List: Esperanza Spalding Introduces Fans to Emily
description: Esperanza Spalding has accepted that being nervous is par for the course.

title: In Venice, an Art Show to Combat Overstimulation
description: Accrochage, a new show at the Pinault Foundations palatial Punta della Dogana in Venice, was plotted by guest curator Caroline Bourgeois according to a game she set for herself: I decided only to show work that had not been exhibited since coming into the collection, she says. Secondly, work that speaks of minimal gesture; thirdly, work that questions the idea of emptiness, and finally, work that uses minimal colors  with white being the common element.

title: Fashion vs. Art
description: Fashion occupies a prime position in our culture and economy. But is it art?

title: Fashion vs. Art
description: When I first discovered the power of documentaries, one film that truly inspired me was Unzipped, a quintessential fashion documentary. To make this film, the director, Douglas Keeve, followed one of the eras most successful high-fashion designers, Isaac Mizrahi, as he planned his fall 1994 collection. Mr. Keeves romantic connection to his subject seems to inform every gorgeous black-and-white frame of 16-millimeter film. This type of character-driven story can make for a riveting movie, and as a filmmaker I am captivated by figures who can draw my cameras lens in a similarly magnetic way.

title: Taking On the Ph.D. Later in Life
description: ROBERT HEVEY was fascinated by gardening as a child, but then he grew up and took a 30-year career detour. Mr. Hevey earned a masters in business and became a certified public accountant, working for accounting firms and businesses ranging from manufacturing to enterprise software and corporate restructuring.

title: Role of Nurse Is Said to Be of Interest After Report on Doping
description: HOUSTON  After a report by Al Jazeera in December linked Peyton Manning, the Philadelphia Phillies player Ryan Howard and other top athletes to performance-enhancing drugs, United States antidoping officials set out to investigate those claims with the help of Major League Baseball and the N.F.L.

title: The Water in Your Glass Might Be Older Than the Sun
description: Every Friday, well offer a Trilobite talking point to help you bring a bit more science to your weekend conversations.

title: Popcast:Country Music Agitators
description: New York Times music critics discuss Sturgill Simpson and Merle Haggard.

title: Russian Forces Remain Heavily Involved in Syria, Despite Appearances
description: MOSCOW  Russias war in Syria is slowly fading from view here, even as events on the ground give every indication that Russian forces remain heavily engaged.

title: Higher B.M.I. in Teenagers Tied to Heart Risks Later
description: Higher body mass index in adolescence, even in the normal range, is tied to an increased risk for cardiovascular disease in adulthood, according to a new study.

title: Readers Respond: Airports That Work
description: An article last week about airport design that prioritizes lofty architectural vision over comfort, Airports, Designed for Everyone but the Passenger, struck a chord with readers, who posted more than 400 comments in response to the piece. Among the many lamenting the awful state of airports were several comments lauding airports that get it right. Edited excerpts from their praise are below.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: At the Existentialist Caf
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

title: Submit Questions for Robert Carlock of Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt
description: Robert Carlock answered the questions here.

title: The Fashion News to Know This Week
description: Schools out

title: Popcast: Country Music Agitators
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: 2 Sought by Police After Man Is Found Dead at a Manhattan Homeless Shelter
description: The 56-year-old man lay dead in his bed at a Manhattan homeless shelter on Friday with a deep cut in his neck, which was wrapped in wire. There was blood all over his mattress, and the police said they were investigating the death as a homicide.

title: U.C. Davis Learns Downside of Trying to Scrub Search Results
description: In November 2011, after a police officer pepper-sprayed students who were sitting in the quad during a protest, the University of California, Davis, had to contend with an image problem as a video  rapidly spread.

title: Spotted: Late-Blooming Urban Bird-Watcher
description: You could call me an unlikely bird-watcher.

title: A Simple Triathlon Story, Until a Reporter Went the Distance
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Sarah Lyall, a staff writer at The Times, describes how her reporting on  a Canadian triathlete suspected of cheating provided more of a story than she had anticipated.

title: First Teaser for The Birth of a Nation Is Released
description: With a sweeping aerial shot of a cotton field and the sounds of Nina Simone singing Strange Fruit, the teaser trailer for the film The Birth of a Nation has an impact from the start. The drama caused a stir at this years Sundance Film Festival, winning both the Grand Jury Prize and the Audience Award, and selling to Fox Searchlight for a record $17.5 million. Now the film is being positioned for the Oscar race with this intense teaser.

title: Taliban Attack Kunduz City, Alarming Afghans
description: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  Taliban militants on Friday attacked several districts surrounding the northern city of Kunduz, which briefly fell to them last year. But even as Afghan officials said the security forces had successfully fought off the assault, residents expressed alarm that the insurgents were again at the citys gates.

title: Ntozake Shange Archive Goes to Barnard
description: Barnard College has acquired the archive of Ntozake Shange, the feminist poet and playwright best known for the experimental play For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf, which ran on Broadway from 1976 to 1978.

title: SunEdison, Becoming So Big It Fails, Prepares for Bankruptcy
description: SunEdison, which grew from making chemicals and components for solar modules to become a giant of the renewable energy business, is preparing for bankruptcy, according to a filing with regulators on Friday.

title: Friday Night Music: The Wild Reeds at Mercury Lounge
description: Yes, its only afternoon. But Im giving a talk, then theres a reception, and anyway Im taking a mental vacation for the rest of the day. So I hereby declare it wine-and-cheese-oclock.

title: Kerry Butler on Japanese Toilets and Disaster!
description: One morning more than 30 years ago, Sister Mary Arlene, the principal of St. Frances Cabrini, a now-defunct parochial grammar school in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, commandeered the public address system on behalf of a very special student: Everyone, please pray for Kerry Butler, she urged, because today she has her final callback to play Annie on Broadway.

title: What I Love | Kerry Butler
description: Ms. Butler, a star of the Broadway spoof Disaster!, lives in a duplex on the Upper West Side with her husband, Joey Mazzarino.

title: The Director of Sing Street on His Favorite Movie Musicals
description: John Carney shares his picks, from A Star is Born to Saturday Night Fever.

title: Southern Cities Split With States on Social Issues
description: JACKSON, Miss.  It was not that long ago that Victoria Fortenberry figured she would mark her 18th birthday by getting on a bus and getting out of Mississippi. But here she was, blue-haired, tattooed and 19 years old, singing at a party for a new line of craft beer to a crowd that included her girlfriend.

title: Jose Cuervo Said to Be Making Arrangements for an I.P.O.
description: Happy hour is coming to the initial public offerings market.

title: Review: Vicky Shick at Danspace, Tough and Tender
description: Its not so much that Vicky Shick knows how to string together seemingly disparate movements  examples from her latest dance include snapping fingers, bent knees that open and shut rapidly, and a purposeful walk interrupted by a fall to the floor  but that she can shape them into a coordinated flow. Detailed and precisely rendered, her choreography has a crystalline clarity that can also, oddly, evaporate right before your eyes. Its like spotting a shell sparkling in the sand before a wave carries it back into the ocean.

title: A Party to Mark the Party of the Year
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which draws millions of visitors every year, is closed only four days out of 365: Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, New Years Day, and the first Monday in May.

title: In Milan, Fashion Brands Embrace Salone del Mobile
description: The Salone del Mobile furniture fair, which wraps up Sunday in Milan, was the biggest yet  with hundreds of exhibitors setting up all over the city. And this year, a handful of fashion brands entered the fray: some showcasing luxurious collections for the home, others unveiling fashion pieces inspired by design, and others still presenting experimental ideas not for sale. Here, some of the most interesting fashion happenings at Salone del Mobile this week.

title: Keurigs New K-Cup Coffee Is Recyclable, but Hardly Green
description: Keurig Green Mountain last year sold more than nine billion of its traditional single-serve plastic coffee pods  or K-Cups. Precisely zero could be easily recycled.

title: Housewives at 10 Years Old
description: The Bravo franchise has grown into a cultural behemoth, fueled by feuds, scandals and bad behavior. On a bus tour, fans got to interact with members of the New York cast.

title: 2016 N.B.A. Playoff Matchups
description: No. 1 Golden State Warriors vs. No. 8 Houston Rockets

title: Modern Feminists, in Their Own Words
description: These seven feminists, from Tavi Gevinson to Beth Ditto, cite the poet Eileen Myles as inspiration. T looks back on their own words on feminism and womanhood.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Eileen Myles
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the poet Eileen Myles, who shares her list exclusively with T.

title: The Poet Idolized by a New Generation of Feminists
description: For decades, it seemed as though Eileen Myles and her unflinching depictions of New York misfits and creatives would forever be relegated to the margins of the American canon. And then last year happened.

title: Egyptians Denounce President Sisi in Biggest Rally in 2 Years
description: CAIRO  More than a thousand people gathered in downtown Cairo on Friday, chanting slogans denouncing President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and protesting his decision to transfer sovereignty of two islands in the Red Sea to Saudi Arabia.

title: Citigroup Chief Faces a Predicament, Despite Recent Victory
description: Mike Corbat, the chief executive of Citigroup, is entangled in a banking Catch-22. He aced the living will and stress tests. He has also helped form an efficient operation, as shown by the banks latest quarterly results. Returns remain subpar, however. Improving on them requires leaning on tax breaks. And doing that will depend on finding more profit in tough times.

title: The Right to Privacy for Children Online
description: This week, Beyonc introduced an athleisure clothing line called Ivy Park. The brands name derives from a beloved childhood park she ran in, and from her 4-year-old daughter, Blue Ivy, a regular on her Instagram account and in her videos who also appears in the commercial, on her mothers back and both wearing Ivy Park-logo headbands.

title: An Artist at 100, Thinking Big but Starting Small
description: The painter Carmen Herrera, who turns 101 in May, was sitting in her wheelchair on a gray day last month, waiting and watching, catlike.

title: Where Berkowitz Did Time and Cagney Spent Time
description: Theres something magical about Sing Sing, the maximum-security prison that sprawls over 75 acres on a bank of the Hudson River where it widens north of the Tappan Zee Bridge  if the word magical can be used to describe a place that in the late 19th century pioneered the use of the electric chair and that today houses about 1,600 inmates, many of them convicted of rape or murder.

title: Ts New Culture Issue: Past Is Present
description: This issue of T, dedicated to culture  specifically, the culture of style  sprouted from a sentence in a book, Roomscapes, written by the Italian architect and set designer Renzo Mongiardino in 1992, a few years before he died. I think it is a mistake, he wrote, to treat ancient and modern as if a barrier divided them. The houses he created were imagined worlds full of layers  of color, pattern, artifice and history  and because they werent obviously wed to the fashions of the day in which they were made, they have succeeded at being timeless. In a sense, they feel as relevant and beautiful as ever.

title: DOT's order
description: DOT's tentative order on approving Norwegian Air's application

title: Norwegian Airline Gets Initial Approval for More U.S. Flights
description: Norwegian Air Shuttle, a low-cost European airline, won tentative approval on Friday to expand its no-frills operations into the United States.

title: Phil Sayer, Voice Behind Mind the Gap on London Underground, Dies at 62
description: LONDON  Phil Sayer, a voice actor whose admonition to please mind the gap has been heard by millions of passengers on the London Underground since 2005, died on Thursday at his home in Bolton, England. He was 62.

title: Fox Announces Date for Megyn Kellys Broadcast Special
description: Megyn Kellys coming broadcast special has a new name, a new time and a new connection to her bte noire, Donald J. Trump.

title: Whats Worse Than a Girl Being Kidnapped?
description: Abuja, Nigeria  WE were late getting to Chibok. Our driver was delayed. On the way to meet us, he explained, he had seen a mother carrying a sick child on her back and stopped to give them a lift to the hospital. By the time they arrived, the child had died.

title: New Jersey Series Frees Some Playwrights From Developmental Hell
description: Too many new plays get workshop readings but then end up lost in developmental hell and never see the light of day, Andy Donald, a producer with the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, said in a recent telephone interview.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week.

title: The Many Periods of One Artists Life
description: The art exhibition at the Long Island Museum in Stony Brook contains works that span about 80 years  and they are by one artist, who is still working. That would be Mort Knstler, 88, the subject of Mort Knstler: The Art of Adventure.

title: Review: Cecil Taylors Mysteries Dont Resolve at the 88th Key
description: First things first: The pianist Cecil Taylor, one of the great American artists of the past century, is the subject of an imaginative exhibition and residency at the Whitney Museum of American Art for the next 10 days, called Open Plan. This kind of meticulous museum treatment is unusual for a musician, let alone an improvising or living one. You should go.

title: Review: Camille OSullivan, Proclaiming Ferocious Truths at Irish Arts
description: It isnt enough to describe Camille OSullivan as merely a singer. During an appearance at the Irish Arts Center on Thursday evening, she made the cabaret and rock songs in her challenging international program a musical play, with dramatic lighting and props and a focal character, which she more than ably embodied. Tom Waits, Nick Cave, Jacques Brel and Leonard Cohen are among those whose works she inhabited with a ferocious commitment to unearthing their truths.

title: Gothic to Goth: Exploring the Impact of the Romantic Era in Fashion
description: Visitors to the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art can wander through Gothic to Goth: Romantic Era Fashion and Its Legacy and admire the array of costumes and accessories from the first half of the 19th century. They might marvel at the sumptuous dresses with complicated sleeves and impossibly small waists, the shawls and aprons hand-embroidered with intricate designs and the delicate jewelry woven from human hair.

title: Review: Les Arts Florissants in a Heady Mix of Cabaret and Miley Cyrus
description: Springtime in New York: The trees are in bloom, eyes are itching, and sheep are feeling restless. Just a few weeks ago, 100 of them stole the show at the Park Avenue Armory, where they brought a note of docile pathos to a production of Louis Andriessens De Materie. And on Thursday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, distant cousins of theirs got randy during a pastoral scene in Les Ftes Vnitiennes, mating in sometimes acrobatic positions.

title: Asparagus Is Sweetest in Spring
description: If you believe, as many do, that asparagus should be celebrated as a sure sign of spring and is best eaten only during its relatively short season, you know something about the joy of anticipation.

title: A Different Light
description: John Chiaras photographs of the city use an inverted palette: Bright sky becomes pitch black; trees glow as if lit from within.

title: Big Town, Big Camera
description: At a time when taking photographs has never been easier, John Chiara shot New York City the hard way. Mr. Chiara, 44, who lives in San Francisco, built two box cameras the size of kitchen cabinets and loaded them with large sheets of photosensitive paper that produced negatives of the colors projected on it. New York is a very challenging place to photograph, because its been photographed so much, he said. It was exciting figuring out what I had to bring to it. The results are an alternate city that evokes the chaos and monumental architecture of the real thing but invites people to meditate on it rather than rush through. I wanted it to feel like a fragment of a memory, he said. Its like the visual you get when youre staring into space, trying to reconcile what you remember with what you saw. You dont get the whole thing at once. You have moments of clarity, but its elusive. The cameras each took weeks to build; the shooting took the better part of a year. With any image, he never knew quite what he had until he saw the finished print.

title: De Blasios Investigations Chief Recuses Himself From Fund-Raising Inquiry
description: The commissioner of New York Citys Investigation Department, in an abrupt turnaround, has recused himself from a federal inquiry into Mayor Bill de Blasios political fund-raising operation, the agency said on Friday.

title: The Tragic Life of Americas First Supermodel
description: Like Helen of Troy (not the homely city in upstate New York), her visage inspired suitors and protectors, but Audrey Munson (who did hail from upstate) is more likely to be remembered as the face that launched a thousand quips.

title: Supreme Court Immigration Ruling Wont End Political Tussle
description: WASHINGTON  Inside the Supreme Courts chambers on Monday, eight justices will consider whether President Obama abused the power of his office by issuing executive actions to allow millions of undocumented immigrants to work in the country legally and protect them from deportation.

title: N.B.A. Approves Ads on Uniforms
description: The N.B.A. has approved the use of sponsorship patches on all league uniforms. Commissioner Adam Silver said use of the patches could begin with the start of the 2017-18 season.

title: Bookshelf: Poems for Kids of All Ages
description: New picture books by Judith Viorst, Julie Fogliano and Skila Brown.

title: With Spring, the Rare Spotted Salamander Emerges
description: A light rain was falling on Ellen Pehek and Susan Stanley of New York Citys Natural Resources Group where we agreed to meet at a quiet corner in Queens. Not normally an auspicious sign, the evenings wet weather was ideal for our purposes. We were here to survey for one of the citys rarest animals, the spotted salamander. Just beyond the street lamps, a rapidly darkening forest, already filled with a chorus of wood frogs and spring peepers, beckoned.

title: Review: Rhythm in Motion Explores the Many Definitions of Tap
description: Apparently, tap dance is like outer space: There are worlds waiting to be discovered. For the American Tap Dance Foundations Rhythm in Motion program, a selection of choreography showcased tap as meditation, tap that flows like water and tap as tonic for an outcast. In all, it was a night spent hoping for more and, sadly and repeatedly, settling for less.

title: A Bartender With a Magic Touch
description: The bartender delivered another round to the couple at the end of the bar, and then laid a small black mat in front of them.

title: A Hologram for the King Finds Tom Hanks in the Desert, Desperate to Sell Phantoms
description: Dave Eggers, once the wunderkind of American letters, has been writing books for close to 20 years. He has picked up a couple of screenwriting credits, including one for the movie version of Maurice Sendaks childrens classic Where the Wild Things Are, which he wrote with the director, Spike Jonze, but somehow his own novels seemed to elude the big screen.

title: Elvis & Nixon Is Based on a Strange, Real-Life Meeting
description: The photograph, one of the most requested from the National Archives, has left generations of viewers scratching their heads: President Richard M. Nixon  wearing a gray suit with an American flag pin in his lapel  and Elvis Presley  in velvet bell-bottoms and cape, an enormous gold belt buckle at his waist  shaking hands in the White House.

title: Hillary Clinton Falters on the Path to $15
description: The contest between California and New York to be seen as leaders in the Fight for $15 escalated this week when Hillary Clinton took sides, calling New Yorks minimum-wage law a model for the nation.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Bernie Sanders, Japan, Dilma Rousseff
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Path of $681 Million: From Saudi Arabia to Malaysian Premiers Personal Account
description: How did $681 million end up being deposited in the personal bank account of Malaysias prime minister, Najib Razak, last year?

title: Review: Martha Graham Dance Celebrates 90 Years
description: Compared with the mayfly life spans of most dance troupes, the endurance of the Martha Graham Dance Company suggests a geological time scale. At City Center on Thursday, this oldest of American dance groups opened its 90th anniversary season (90th!) with 90 Years in 90 Seconds, a film by Justin Scholar. Hundreds of archival images and clips flew by in chronological order: the volcanic early decades, the embarrassing later ones and then, like the humbling sliver of human history in a chart of the earths existence, the blip of the past few years and its commissioned works.

title: The Bar With a Chip on Its Shoulder
description: Lois Angone has a favorite cracked-leather bar stool at Liedys Shore Inn, the oldest bar on Staten Island. She is known as Sparkles because she sparkles. She applies glitter to her body every morning and keeps a container with more just in case.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Tiger Kills Zookeeper in Florida
description: A zookeeper performing a routine procedure in Palm Beach, Fla., was killed Friday by a Malayan tiger, a zoo official said.

title: The Night Manager Brings John le Carr Back to the Small Screen
description: Writers, like spies, tend to have trust issues, and David Cornwell, 84, has been both a writer and a spy. Under his own name, he once worked for British intelligence. As John le Carr, he has for the past half-century written labyrinthine novels about espionage and other sorts of subterfuge and imposture, all of which suggest that in this world its best to be very, very wary.

title: Group Backing Donald Trump Highlights His Role in Capturing Rapist
description: Join us for New York primary live updates.

title: How Krishna Andavolu of Viceland TV Spends His Sundays
description: Krishna Andavolu had some explaining to do after he smoked a joint. With the president of Uruguay. On television. My parents are coming to understand that the son that theyve placed their hopes and dreams in can be successful and have it be a part of his life, said Mr. Andavolu, 33, the host, on the brand-new Viceland channel, of the series Weediquette, which draws to a close this week. Between trips to explore pot culture from Eastern Congo to California, Mr. Andavolu, who previously edited a magazine about endings, Obit, spends his time in Brooklyn, where he lives in Clinton Hill with his wife, Emma Alpert, a public defender; their 21-month-old son, Kalyan; and their dog, Leela.

title: At Columbia University, Daring to Back Clinton
description: Not long ago, Shailene Woodley, who, as the star of the Divergent films is a kind of living symbol of the millennial force field, was making her way around Columbia University, canvassing on behalf of Bernie Sanders. Campaigning for the Vermont senators presidential bid at a Northeastern university  or any university, for that matter  seems a little like walking into Peter Luger to persuade people to have the steak. Regardless of the advantages that accrue to Ivy League students, and whatever privileges might have landed them there in the first place, Columbia falls within the vast psychographic jurisdiction of Mr. Sanders, enemy of the indulged and fussed-over.

title: Critic of Psychologists Role in Interrogation Is Asked to Reconsider
description: WASHINGTON  The American Psychological Association has asked the Chicago lawyer who issued a scathing report about the organizations involvement with government interrogation programs to review information that came to light after his findings were released and determine whether he should alter his conclusions.

title: Evening Hours | A Marathon of Parties
description: Celebrating the arts and benefiting social causes.

title: Lundqvist Practices, but His Status for Game 2 Is Unclear
description: PITTSBURGH  During the initial moments after he was struck in the right eye by a teammates stick Wednesday night, Rangers goaltender Henrik Lundqvist feared the worst.

title: Bill Cunningham | Dressing for Luncheons
description: Not everyone lunches at a desk. The charity lunching circus got off to a big start last week. Women wore pants and occasional spring coats and suits. Four authors signed books at a lunch for Gods Love We Deliver.

title: Hamilton Producers and Actors Reach Deal on Sharing Profits
description: The producers of Hamilton, a show that could well make hundreds of millions of dollars, on Friday bowed to pressure and said they would share some of the musicals profits with original cast members.

title: Bob Dylan-Inspired Drama Is in the Works
description: The biggest star behind a spate of new streaming television shows is no celebrity or top-flight director, but rather innovative music deals.

title: Sorry, You Cant Speed Read
description: OUR favorite Woody Allen joke is the one about taking a speed-reading course. I read War and Peace in 20 minutes, he says. Its about Russia.

title: After Devouring League, Warriors Remain Hungry
description: The Golden State Warriors have been defined by 3-pointers, artistic ball movement and underrated defense. But at their core, they may be powered by something more abstract: an ability to motivate themselves just when they are being doubted.

title: With Mike Piazza Jersey Regained, Mets Say They Have Made Procedural Changes
description: A day after three minority owners of the Mets repurchased an emblematic piece of the teams history that had somehow been sold away, the Mets themselves said they were instituting steps to make sure the same type of mistake would not happen again.

title: A Long Career in Militarys Elite Spirals Into a Killing and a Suicide
description: After two decades in the Army Special Forces, several deployments overseas and a stint in the F.B.I., Steven Bellino switched to the Air Force to become an elite pararescue lifesaver trained to jump from planes and save aircrews behind enemy lines. The motto of the rescuers is, That others may live.

title: With Gas Stations Closing, a Fuel Desert Expands in Manhattan
description: The gas station at the corner of Lafayette and East Houston Streets in SoHo is an industrial outpost in a Manhattan neighborhood of luxury lofts and even more luxurious shopping. It has existed on the corner for decades  first as Gaseteria, later as BP, but nearly always selling gas. For cabdrivers, it was a way station in an unruly city, where they could fill up, use the restroom, or kneel for afternoon prayers on one of the communal kilims the owner let them keep stowed beside the convenience mart.

title: Now Batting Third for Struggling Mets: Conforto, Not Cespedes
description: CLEVELAND  Terry Collins had to stifle a smirk. He had just written a lineup with Michael Conforto batting third  a new spot this season for a player who has been in the majors only since last July. Yes, Collins said Friday, he was confident Conforto could handle it.

title: Documentos del informe de la Inspectora General de la Polica de Honduras
description: Documentos del informe de la Inspectora General de la Polica de Honduras

title: N.B.A. Denies Anti-Lin Bias on Fouls
description: The N.B.A. issued a response on Friday to an article in The New York Times about a fan-made video that highlighted multiple forceful fouls on the Charlotte Hornets guard Jeremy Lin.

title: Stop a Pipeline for Fracked Gas
description: GENERATIONS of the Holleran family have harvested sap from trees on their land in New Milford, Pa. In early March, their small maple syrup business was nearly destroyed when armed federal marshals accompanied men with chain saws onto the family farm and used the power of eminent domain to cut down most of their maple trees.

title: Putting a Humane, Dignified Face on Refugees
description: A new exhibit on refugees features several photographers from different genres whose compelling images challenge and change how refugees have been portrayed.

title: New York City Elections Board Fixes Gaffe in Another Mass Mailing
description: The New York City Board of Elections is correcting its correction, and the cost to taxpayers is growing.

title: Sumner Redstones Total Pay From CBS Plummeted Last Year
description: The 92-year-old media mogul Sumner M. Redstone received $1.8 million in total pay from CBS Corporation in 2015, a period when his ailing health and limited involvement at the company became the subject of a court battle and the target of intense scrutiny on Wall Street.

title: Files Suggest Honduran Police Leaders Ordered Killing of Antidrug Officials
description: MEXICO CITY  More than a dozen conspirators gathered at the headquarters of the Honduran National Police just after 9:30 p.m. One of them clicked open a briefcase, and bundles of American dollars were distributed among the police officers  payment for the next days hit job.

title: Shrunken Citigroup Illustrates a Trend in Big U.S. Banks
description: Citigroup became the nations first megabank some two decades ago by expanding into new businesses while pushing to knock down barriers that limited its size.

title: Fight to Impeach Brazils Leader Tears at Fabric of Daily Life
description: BRASLIA  The wall, nearly a mile of corrugated metal, plunges down the center of the majestic lawn that faces Brazils National Congress, the modernist icon designed by Oscar Niemeyer.

title: McGraw Hill to Sell J.D. Power for $1.1 Billion
description: XIO Group, a private equity firm co-founded in 2014 by the former head of BlackRock Alternative Investors for Asia Pacific, said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire J. D. Power and Associates for $1.1 billion from McGraw Hill Financial, in what will be its biggest investment yet and its first in the United States.

title: G.O.P. Chief Discourages Rule Changes That Seem to Block Donald Trump
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Republican National Committee has privately urged members of the partys rules committee not to make changes to the guidelines governing the presidential nominating process, an effort to avoid the appearance that the party is seeking to block Donald J. Trump from becoming its nominee.

title: What Needs to Come After the New York Primary
description: Barring another Michigan-style upset, Hillary Clinton is likely to win the New York presidential primary on Tuesday. But watching her and Bernie Sanders wage the Battle of Brooklyn on the debate stage on Thursday was to hear two candidates recycling familiar themes, albeit at a higher pitch, and to see the toll that these fractious months of combat have exacted on them and their party. Democrats are now so divided and dug-in that no matter who wins the nomination, it will take a considerable effort to heal and reunite them.

title: Saudi Arabia Warns of Economic Fallout if Congress Passes 9/11 Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Saudi Arabia has told the Obama administration and members of Congress that it will sell off hundreds of billions of dollars worth of American assets held by the kingdom if Congress passes a bill that would allow the Saudi government to be held responsible in American courts for any role in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

title: Bernie Sanders Releases His 2014 Tax Returns
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont released his 2014 federal tax returns on Friday, following weeks of questioning  by his rival, Hillary Clinton, and the media  and promises that he would do so.

title: Newtown Families Get a Court Hearing
description: The long-suffering families of children murdered in the 2012 schoolhouse gun slaughter in Newtown, Conn., won fresh hope in court this week. A Connecticut state judge denied a motion to throw out their lawsuit against the manufacturers of the Bushmaster AR-15, a military-style assault rifle used to kill 20 children and six adults in the grisly siege.

title: Bernie Sanders Makes Quick Transition From Brooklyn to Rome
description: VATICAN CITY  On Thursday night, Bernie Sanders was standing under the lights in Brooklyn, being pressed by journalists and his rival at the Democratic debate, Hillary Clinton, to provide details about his often-vague policy ideas.

title: Malick Sidib, Photographer Known for Social Reportage in Mali, Dies at 80
description: Malick Sidib, whose black-and-white photographs of young partygoers captured the exuberance of newly independent Mali in the 1960s and 70s and made him one of Africas most celebrated artists after his work was shown abroad in the 1990s, died on Thursday in Bamako, Mali. He was 80.

title: Cubas Path to the Future Is Shrouded in Secrecy
description: Cubas ruling Communist Party is expected to announce a series of economic and political reforms next week that it hopes to put in place as the country prepares for the end of the Castros rule in 2018.

title: In New Filing, Apple Resists F.B.I.s Call to Open iPhone in Drug Case
description: Apple told a federal court on Friday that it should not have to help the F.B.I. unlock an iPhone used by a Brooklyn drug dealer and that the case would lead to an avalanche of similar demands if prosecutors prevailed.

title: Success of Hamilton May Have Saved Hamilton on the $10 Bill
description: WASHINGTON  For more than 100 years, women have waited for a portrait of someone of their sex at the center of a paper note, a wait that appeared to be ending when Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew announced 10 months ago that he would choose a woman for a new $10 bill in development.

title: The Case for Donald Trump
description: Clarence, N.Y.  AMERICANS are angry. I hear it from the former factory workers who lost their jobs to other countries because of bad trade deals, the veterans who wait months to see a doctor at a Veterans Affairs hospital and the small-business owners who are struggling to stay afloat because of the Affordable Care Acts crippling regulations. The professional politicians they trusted and supported have repeatedly sold out our country in favor of special interests and the status quo. Finally, millions of Americans are saying, Enough is enough.

title: Chicago Releases Video of Man Who Died in Police Custody Last Year
description: CHICAGO  A police dashboard camera video was released on Friday showing a Chicago police officer appearing to place his foot on the head of a man who died in custody last summer.

title: Trumpo, the Unfunny Marx Brother
description: Its no surprise, and no fun, hearing that our country has become a laughingstock abroad. The laughter is mixed with a dose of panic.

title: Review: A Romeo & Juliet Running Swiftly From Love to Death
description: Poor Juliet worries that her new romance is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden. Can you blame her?

title: One Taking the Big View
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  We happen to be a CHEEZ-IT intensive household, so my family was especially thrilled to see CHEEZ-ITS make its New York Times Crossword debut. But thats not the only reason I liked this puzzle by Andrew Zhou.

title: J. J. Abrams and Chris Rock: Is a Film Collaboration in Store?
description: After working together on short videos that were a highlight of the Academy Awards, J. J. Abrams and Chris Rock may collaborate on something bigger  at least if their banter Friday evening at the Tribeca Film Festival is to be believed.

title: Maryland Firefighter Dies After Being Shot Answering Medical Call
description: A firefighter in Prince Georges County, Md., died after being shot while answering a medical call on Friday night, the authorities said. A second firefighter was seriously wounded in the shooting.

title: Criticizing Israel, Bernie Sanders Highlights Split Among Jewish Democrats
description: It was the sort of question  Does Israel have a right to defend itself as it sees fit?  that had often caused candidates, especially those with designs on winning a primary in New York, to produce paeans to the strength of the Israeli-American relationship and a stream of pro-Israel orthodoxy.

title: Second Powerful Earthquake Strikes Japan
description: TOKYO  A powerful earthquake and multiple aftershocks rattled the southwestern Japanese island of Kyushu on Saturday, killing at least 23 people, according to media reports, two days after another strong quake killed nine people on the same island.

title: The Obamas 2015 Tax Return
description: The White House on Friday released the 2015 joint tax return for the president and Michelle Obama. The document suggests some planning for a future beyond Mr. Obama's White House tenure.

title: Obama Tax Return Hints at His Post-Presidency Plans
description: WASHINGTON  Even presidents dip into their savings when they are getting ready to switch jobs.

title: Cool Reception for Robinson Cano, and Even Colder Bats for Yankees
description: When Robinson Cano was introduced in the starting lineup Friday, he was vociferously jeered by Yankees fans, who were still feeling scorned from when he left after the 2013 season, absconding to Seattle for $240 million.

title: Provost Resigns Amid Sexual Harassment Case at Berkeley
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The University of California, Berkeley, announced Friday that Claude Steele, the universitys executive vice chancellor and provost for the past two years, resigned his administrative positions for personal reasons.

title: National Briefing
description: A 76-year-old man who a prosecutor says was wrongly convicted in the 1957 killing of a 7-year-old girl was released Friday after a judge vacated his conviction, meaning that one of the nations oldest cold cases to be tried has gone cold again. The man, Jack McCullough, a former police officer, was sentenced to life in 2012 in the death of Maria Ridulph in Sycamore, west of Chicago. A prosecutor found evidence last year that supported his alibi that he had been 40 miles away when she disappeared. Maria had been playing in the snow with a friend when a young man offered them piggyback rides. The friend dashed home for mittens, and when she came back, Maria and the man were gone. (AP)

title: Quotation of the Day
description: You should be selling the silverware in the dining rooms or the paperclips from the desk or the desk chairs or the whole desk.

title: Mets Escape Offensive Doldrums With Four-Homer Night
description: CLEVELAND  The feeling of scoring a run seemed intoxicating to the Metson Friday. They had done it so infrequently this season, and their eagerness worked against them. Twice against the Cleveland Indians, the Mets made the first out of an inning at home plate.

title: What to Watch Saturday
description: Confirmation revisits the 1991 Supreme Court nomination hearings in which Anita Hill accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment. Just in time for the return of Veep, Julia Louis-Dreyfus hosts Saturday Night Live. And Gugu Mbatha-Raw swaggers as a hip-hop vixen in Beyond the Lights.

title: Corrections: April 16, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Pope Francis Takes 12 Refugees Back to Vatican After Trip to Greece
description: MYTILENE, Greece  Pope Francis made an emotional visit into the heart of Europes migrant crisis on Saturday and took 12 Muslim refugees from Syria, including six children, with him back to Rome aboard the papal plane.

title: E.U. Offers to Loosen Restrictions on Iran Air
description: BRUSSELS  Almost six years ago, the European Union sharply curtailed access to its airspace for Irans aging airline fleet. But officials in Brussels say they are now prepared to loosen some of those restrictions as the easing of Western sanctions gradually allows new planes and spare parts to enter Iran after decades of isolation.

title: I Stand With the Community That Says No
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: Bernie Sanders Meets With Pope Francis
description: VATICAN CITY  For a while, Senator Bernie Sanderss Roman holiday seemed less than it was cracked up to be.

title: The Other Mapplethorpe
description: Edward Mapplethorpes tax return lists his profession as photographer/artist, but the scene in his Manhattan studio suggests that baby wrangler is more accurate.

title: Mary Beard and Her Battle Cry Against Internet Trolling
description: Mary Beard, silver-haired and red-shod, was seated in front of a packed house at Lincoln Center one recent Thursday morning, addressing an annual conference called the Women in the World Summit.

title: In Cramped and Costly Bay Area, Cries to Build, Baby, Build
description: San Francisco does not have enough places to live. Sonja Trauss, a local activist, thinks the city should tackle this problem by building more housing.

title: Family of Immigrants, Only One a Citizen, Anxiously Awaits Supreme Court Ruling
description: FAIRFAX, Va.  Jerry Pinto, an immigrant from Bolivia, has visions of opening a spacious carpentry workshop in this suburban city, with his name in bold letters over the door.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from the Ganges River to Washington Square Park.

title: Do You Think You Might Have a Connection to the 1838 Slave Sale that Kept Georgetown Afloat?
description: The New York Times would like to hear from people who have done research into their genealogical history.

title: 272 Slaves Were Sold to Save Georgetown. What Does It Owe Their Descendants?
description: WASHINGTON  The human cargo was loaded on ships at a bustling wharf in the nations capital, destined for the plantations of the Deep South. Some slaves pleaded for rosaries as they were rounded up, praying for deliverance.

title: A Little Variety
description: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES  This weeks puzzles include:

title: Kahoot App Brings Urgency of a Quiz Show to the Classroom
description: Kahoot, an online quiz system from Norway that is fast gaining market share in schools across the United States, plays out like a television game show spliced with a video game.

title: The Week in Tech: The Next Big Thing, According to Mark Zuckerberg
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mr. Manjoo is still off this week, so Quentin Hardy, a Times technology reporter, is filling in.

title: Making a Building Smoke-Free
description: Making a Building Smoke-Free

title: 1966: Students Sack Peking Embassy
description: DJAKARTA  About 2,000 screaming Indonesian Chinese sacked the Chinese embassy here today [April 14], smashing doors and windows and lighting vast bonfires of documents in the latest outburst of anti-Peking feelings. With a truck, they battered down the 15-foot red gate guarding the building and, once inside, smashed three cars, ripped the Chinese crest off the chancery, tore down the flag and replaced it with the Indonesian standard.

title: Color and Meaning
description: A mashup of illustration and literature, from the Race/Related newsletter

title: Did J.J. Abrams Offer a Clue About Reys Father?
description: The director J.J. Abrams dropped a possible hint Friday evening about the next Star Wars and who the protagonist Reys parents might be  and who they werent.

title: The Return of Elasticity Pessimism (Wonkish)
description: I talked at the Council for European Studies conference in Philly last night, and was surprised by one aspect of the discussion. As you might expect if youre into these things, my take on the euro was strongly informed by the theory of Optimum Currency Areas; I expected pushback. But I didnt realize how many people now seem to believe that real exchange rates dont matter for adjustment  that is, that even internal devaluation (downward adjustment of prices and wages relative to trading partners) isnt necessary in the aftermath of unsustainable capital inflows.

title: The Billionaire Whos Building a Davos of His Own
description: In a wood-paneled conference room at Stanford University, a score of scholars, many of them eminent and some from as far away as Johannesburg and Beijing, gathered last month to compare philosophical notions of hierarchy and equality.

title: Richard K. Ransom, Founder of Hickory Farms Specialty Foods Chain, Dies at 96
description: In 1951, finding specialty meats and cheeses could take some doing if you lived in small-town America and had no neighborhood deli. For Richard K. Ransom, this was an opportunity.

title: Variety: A Well-Paced Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  A typically elegant acrostic today, just like the HORSES in Emily Cox and Henry Rathvons puzzle.

title: A Conversation With Whales
description: They surrounded the divers and started clicking  they seemed to be saying hello. Read and then take a swim with whales in a virtual reality feature.

title: The Click Effect
description: Ive long been interested in the capacity of storytelling and journalism to transport an audience. Shooting my first documentary in North Africa 35 years ago, I used multiple projectors and screens to create an immersive experience. The approach at the time was experimental and while I moved on to more traditional storytelling in features, television and documentaries, I always held on to the idea of using immersive environments to transport viewers and allow them to experience an expanded vision of the world.

title: Grumbling About Socialism, the Yankees Profit From It
description: Socialism wafts in the spring wind.

title: Wielding a Soldering Gun to Give Panes Their Brains
description: Q. What does SageGlass do, and what is your role there?

title: Bernie Sanderss Campaign Past Reveals Willingness to Play Hardball
description: During the 1986 race for governor of Vermont, Bernie Sanders bristled at the popularity of the Democratic incumbent, Madeleine Kunin. Mr. Sanders, who was running against her as an independent, saw himself as a leader, and viewed Ms. Kunin as a lightweight.

title: Families of Americans Held by Allies Say U.S. Is Keeping Its Gloves On
description: CAIRO  In the United Arab Emirates, a Libyan-American father and son detained since 2014 on political charges said security agents tortured them in prison, with beatings and electric shocks.

title: Dilma Rousseffs Former Supporters in Brazil Express Disillusionment
description: BRASLIA  They are at once ubiquitous and invisible here, the street cleaners, landscapers, hotel maids and traffic police who make sure Brazils meticulously designed capital stays true to the national flags slogan of order and progress.

title: Kobe Bryants Finale a Triumph of Volume Over Value
description: It would perhaps be forgivable for anyone glancing at the box score of Kobe Bryants final N.B.A. game on Wednesday to assume his point total was a typographical error. Somehow, a 37-year-old player closing out his 20th season, who had not scored more than 38 points in a game since November 2014, dropped 60 points on the Utah Jazz.

title: Farmers in Arid India Share Camps With Their Cattle
description: KHILAD, India  The cattle camp, on a dusty back road lined with thorny babul trees that seem to thrive no matter how weak the rains, is just about impossible to miss.

title: At the Boston Marathon, Leading the Way for Women Fifty Years Ago
description: In 1965, the year I first ran the Boston Marathon, there were no women in the field of about 400 participants. On Monday morning, more than 13,000 women will start the 120th Boston Marathon.

title: John Ferrone, Editor of Eclectic Stable of Writers, Dies at 91
description: John Ferrone, an editor who shepherded Alice Walkers Pulitzer Prize-winning novel The Color Purple into print, encouraged Anas Nin to publish her erotic fiction, and served as James Beards dining and cooking companion and literary executor, died in Old Bridge, N.J., on April 10. He was 91.

title: Mets Jacob deGrom to Stay in Florida With Sick Newborn
description: CLEVELAND  The Mets placed starter Jacob deGrom on family medical leave Saturday because of complications with his newborn son.

title: More Than 40 in Japan Are Confirmed Dead in Earthquakes
description: MASHIKI, Japan  The death toll from two powerful earthquakes and a series of aftershocks on the Japanese island of Kyushu reached 41 on Saturday, the authorities said, as rescue workers searched for survivors under collapsed buildings and mountains of earth displaced by landslides.

title: Stephen Currys 3-Point Record in Context: Off the Charts
description: This chart contains 752 lines  one for each N.B.A. player who finished in the top 20 in 3-point attempts made in each season since 1980. Sitting atop it is the Golden State Warriors Stephen Curry, who finished the regular season with a record 402 3-pointers.

title: Animal Cruelty or the Price of Dinner?
description: THIS month a man in Orlando, Fla., dangled a dog by the scruff of its neck over a second-floor balcony, threatening to drop it 12 feet to the ground.

title: When an Olympian Goes to College, Riches Stay Out of Reach
description: MESA, ARIZ.  In the third grade, a music teacher inspired Katie Ledecky to take piano lessons. She showed an innate talent for the chords, picking them up quickly. Her formal lessons were phased out in the eighth grade as her swimming took off. Roughly five years later, no one is questioning Ledeckys harmony with the water. She has developed into the best female distance freestyler in history and a legitimate quadruple Olympic gold medal threat this summer in Rio de Janeiro.

title: Trump Family Values
description: DONALD TRUMP gazed upon his infant daughter, Tiffany, and wondered about the kind of future shed inherit, the sort of person shed grow up to be.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Disposable Workers
description: Readers discuss the culture and lack of job security in tech companies today.

title: Immigration Politics at the Court
description: On Monday, the Supreme Court will hear oral arguments in United States v. Texas, one of the most flagrant examples in recent memory of a naked political dispute masquerading as a legal one.

title: Jill Twiss
description: Jill Twiss is an actor and comedy writer, most notably for Last Week Tonight With John Oliver.

title: Public Editor No. 5 Is Yesterdays News
description: FASTEN your seatbelts, goes the line from All About Eve, accompanied by a flash of those famous Bette Davis eyes. Its going to be a bumpy night.

title: Syrias Future: A Black Hole of Instability
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  NOOR, who is a commander in a pro-government militia near Damascus, thinks that President Bashar al-Assad will prevail in Syrias civil war. But even so, he thinks it will take his country a generation to recover. After we finish this war, well spend another 10 years cleaning up the thugs and warlords on our own side, he told me when I met him in the Damascus suburb of Jaramana, in an apartment overlooking a highway where rebels and government forces clash nightly.

title: How Getting High Made Me a Better Caregiver
description: Santa Barbara, Calif.  IM 74 years old, and I have smoked marijuana almost every day since dinosaurs roamed the earth in the early 70s. When my awareness is heightened, Im on my game  the best I can be at thinking creatively, making decisions, focusing on my work, seeing the big picture ... and caregiving.

title: Why Americans Cant Vote
description: The state of the nations underfunded, patchwork election system and obsolete balloting machinery may not arouse voters the way candidates can with charges of rigged elections. But voters in Arizona who lined up for the states presidential primaries last month learned just how difficult and unfair voting can be even without criminal malfeasance.

title: Plenty of Passengers, but Where Are the Pilots?
description: DELAYS or cancellations because of bad weather or mechanical problems are exasperating but common occurrences in air travel, but increasingly, passengers arent making it to their destinations for yet another reason: not enough pilots. The gate agent may not tell you thats why youre grounded, but a dearth of qualified pilots is disrupting, reducing and even eliminating flights.

title: Trumpism and Clintonism Are the Future
description: No matter who wins the New York primaries on Tuesday or which candidates end up as the presidential nominees of the two major parties, one thing is already clear: Trumpism represents the future of the Republicans and Clintonism the future of the Democrats.

title: Tweaking Genes to Save Species
description: Boulder, Colo.  BIOTECHNOLOGISTS have engineered the mosquito that spreads the Zika virus to pass a lethal gene to its offspring. Another team of researchers has devised a way to spread sterility through the mosquito population, using a technique called gene drive to wipe out the offending insects.

title: How New York Values Trump
description: OF all the attacks that Donald Trump has faced, Ted Cruzs line that Trump embodies New York values has probably stirred the most sustained controversy.

title: Nera White, Hall of Fame Basketball Star of 1950s and 60s, Is Dead at 80
description: Nera White, who as a Tennessee farm girl powered the first womens national basketball dynasty and became the games first female superstar, a dominance that led her into the Basketball Hall of Fame as one of the first two women to be enshrined there, died on Wednesday in a hospital in Gallatin, Tenn. She was 80.

title: Hillary Is Not Sorry
description: WASHINGTON  ITS hard not to feel sorry for Hillary Clinton. She is hearing ghostly footsteps.

title: A Challenge to Polands Anti-Democratic Drift
description: The conflict between the European Union and Polands right-wing government went up a notch on Wednesday when the European Parliament passed a resolution calling on Polands rulers to stop defying the countrys top court.

title: Reggie Miller: Sharpshooter. Analyst. Coach?
description: Would Reggie Miller follow in the footsteps of the former TNT commentator Steve Kerr and move downcourt a few seats to coach someday?

title: 9 Guantnamo Prisoners From Yemen Are Sent to Saudi Arabia
description: WASHINGTON  The United States on Saturday transferred nine Yemeni detainees from its wartime prison at Guantnamo Bay to Saudi Arabia, completing a long-sought diplomatic deal ahead of a planned visit to Riyadh by President Obama in the coming week.

title: On the Trail: The Week of April 10
description: Candidates traversed New York state and beyond, holding rallies and holding babies.

title: Dodgers Pitcher Takes a Big Step Up
description: As Ross Stripling prepared for this season, his goal was not to make the Los Angeles Dodgers rotation and allow no hits in his first major league start.

title: Is That Even a Thing?
description: Speakers and writers of American English have recently taken to identifying a staggering and constantly changing array of trends, events, memes, products, lifestyle choices and phenomena of nearly every kind with a single label  a thing. In conversation, mention of a surprising fad, behavior or event is now often met with the question, Is that actually a thing? Or When did that become a thing? Or How is that even a thing? Calling something a thing is, in this sense, itself a thing.

title: Bangladeshi Editor, 81, Is Accused in Plot to Kill Leaders Son
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  The Bangladeshi police arrested a prominent magazine editor on Saturday, accusing him of being involved in a plot to kill the son of the prime minister. The arrest was the latest in a string of criminal proceedings against journalists in the country.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On Wage-Gap Issues, Sports Can Learn From the Tech Industry

title: German Comic Who Lampooned Erdogan to Extend Break From TV Show
description: BERLIN  The satirist whose crude lampoon of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey touched off a furor over free speech in Germany announced Saturday that he and his team would take a break from their satirical TV show until May 12.

title: Speaker David Gowan Reshapes Arizona House, From the Carpets on Up
description: PHOENIX  When lawmakers in the Arizona House of Representatives went looking for a new speaker in late 2014, they turned to David M. Gowan, an unassuming Republican legislator whom colleagues on both sides of the aisle saw as someone they could work with.

title: Panthers Hit the Road for a Homecoming Game
description: SUNRISE, Fla.  When the puck drops Sunday for the start of the first Stanley Cup playoff game ever played in Brooklyn, the Florida Panthers could feel more at home than the Islanders.

title: Student Sues Police Over Baton Encounter in Brooklyn High School
description: An 18-year-old Brooklyn high school student has sued the New York Police Department after he was struck with a baton at least twice by an officer in an episode captured on a cellphone video.

title: Clutch Hitting Remains Elusive as Yankees Fall to the Mariners
description: For the first four innings against the Seattle Mariners on Saturday, the Yankees were handed some ingredients to break a three-game losing streak. C. C. Sabathia had a shutout brewing while the Mariners ace, Felix Hernandez, was uncharacteristically wild, walking five batters.

title: Expanded Worldview
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  If you like new toys as much as I do, you probably had a lot of fun the first time you encountered GOOGLE EARTH. The part I liked best was finding my HOUSE (which was a bit creepy at first), and then whooshing outward from my BLOCK to a view of the entire planet.

title: Donald Trump, in Upstate New York, Tries Another Label for Hillary Clinton
description: As he barnstormed in upstate New York on Saturday, Donald J. Trump came up with a new moniker for Hillary Clinton and strongly suggested that some delegates were getting a payoff to back certain candidates.

title: U.S. Plans to Step Up Military Campaign Against ISIS
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  The Obama administration is preparing to broaden its military campaign against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria by increasing the number of Special Operations forces who advise Syrian rebels, and it is also considering the addition of Army attack helicopters to the fight against militants in Iraq.

title: Rangers Surge to Defeat Penguins
description: PITTSBURGH  With a thrilling burst of goals, the Rangers defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 4-2, on Saturday to even their Eastern Conference first-round playoff series at one game apiece.

title: Ral Castro Urges Cubans to Remain Alert to U.S. Efforts to Alter Communist System
description: MEXICO CITY  President Ral Castro of Cuba on Saturday offered a somber assessment of his nations economic advances and warned that the United States  despite the historic thaw in relations  was still intent on changing Cubas communist system.

title: University Scrutinizing Sheryl Swoopess Coaching
description: Sheryl Swoopes, one of the most accomplished athletes in womens basketball history, will be investigated over accusations that she mistreated players at Loyola University Chicago, where she recently completed her third season as the womens basketball coach.

title: Russian Enclave Seen as a Fault Line of East-West Tensions
description: KALININGRAD, Russia  The maritime museum in this Russian exclave on the Baltic Sea caps each summer with its international Water Assembly, an antic parade of small historical vessels from around the Baltics, their crews wearing period costumes as they sail the Pregolya River.

title: Matt Harvey Dominates, for a While, Then Falters Again in the Sixth
description: CLEVELAND  To the first three hitters on Saturday, Matt Harvey pitched with the fury of an overpowering closer. He struck out the side against the Cleveland Indians, needing only 10 pitches to do it. So much, it seemed, for those troubling early signs of a more hittable Harvey.

title: Calls for Shipping and Aviation to Do More to Cut Emissions
description: Even though commercial aviation and ocean shipping are significant sources of greenhouse gas emissions, they were excluded from the Paris climate treaty, to be signed by more than 100 countries this week at the United Nations in New York.

title: Stephen Curry Leaves With Mild Injury, but the Warriors Fare Well Without Him
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  After completing the best regular season in N.B.A. history and establishing themselves as solid favorites to win a second straight championship, the Golden State Warriors faced the perceived nuisance of a first-round playoff series against Houston, with observers wondering if the Rockets even stood a chance.

title: Man Critically Injured in Fall From Manhattan Hotel
description: A man was critically injured when he fell from the 10th floor of an Upper West Side hotel on Saturday afternoon, the police said.

title: John Kasichs Big New York Challenge: Saving Room for Dessert
description: Gov. John Kasich was ready for dessert. But first, he clarified his plan of attack.

title: Race for Latest Class of Nuclear Arms Threatens to Revive Cold War
description: The United States, Russia and China are now aggressively pursuing a new generation of smaller, less destructive nuclear weapons. The buildups threaten to revive a Cold War-era arms race and unsettle the balance of destructive force among nations that has kept the nuclear peace for more than a half-century.

title: The Other Mapplethorpe
description: For the past 20 years, Edward Mapplethorpe, inheritor of his brothers camera, has been taking unexpectedly edgy  yes  baby photos.

title: Los Angeles Joins Debate on Force After Police Killing of Homeless Man
description: LOS ANGELES  When rioters exploded into the streets here a quarter-century ago, angry that the police officers who had been caught on tape beating Rodney King would escape criminal punishment, this city became a national symbol for police violence run amok.

title: In Hillary Clinton Ad, a More Direct Swipe at Donald Trump
description: Donald J. Trump has dominated this presidential campaign, but until now, his name has never been uttered in a paid ad by a Democratic candidate.

title: Outlander Season 2, Episode 2: The Wounds We Carry
description: Sex in pop culture often lacks variety. Usually its only tenor is unadulterated lust and pleasure or on the opposite end of the spectrum, disappointment. But in real life, sex has incredible variety. It can start out tentative or coy then sway into outright passions. Lovers can pause for laughter or switch positions when something is uncomfortable. Nothing in life, especially sexual encounters, is one note. One of the greatest strengths of Outlander is its keen, honest understanding of sex between men and women filtered through the relationship of Claire and Jamie. Their sexual chemistry has proved to be a cornerstone of their relationship providing a window into their loyalty for one another. While last weeks episode curiously didnt touch on Jamies abuse and how it currently shapes their relationship with much depth, it takes center stage in Not in Scotland Anymore.

title: Man Sought in Homeless Shelter Death May Have Slashed Cabdriver, Police Say
description: A man wanted for questioning in the death of a man in a Manhattan homeless shelter may be connected to the slashing and attempted robbery of a livery-cab driver on Saturday, the police said.

title: Ecuador Earthquake Kills at Least 77
description: QUITO, Ecuador  A 7.8-magnitude earthquake shook the central coast of Ecuador on Saturday, killing at least 77 people, officials and news reports said. The effects could be felt as far away as the capital, Quito, which lies some 105 miles from the epicenter.

title: Donald Trump Warns of Rough July at Republican Convention
description: Amping up his heated feud with the Republican National Committee, Donald J. Trump warned the party of a rough July at the convention as he railed Saturday against the way delegates were selected in places like Colorado, where he was outmaneuvered by Senator Ted Cruz.

title: In Campaign and Company, Ivanka Trump Has a Central Role
description: It was a night to celebrate strong women. Amy Schumer was the host, Caitlyn Jenner was honored and the guests included Arianna Huffington, Madeleine Albright and the actress Reese Witherspoon.

title: Scoring Drought Ends, but Red Bulls Lose Again
description: Although the Red Bulls got a reprieve from the shutouts that have piled up this season, they fell to last place in the Eastern Conference with a 2-1 loss to the host Colorado Rapids on Saturday.

title: The Battle for New Yorks Key Voting Blocs in the Primaries

title: The Most Powerful Republican Voters in the Country Are in the Bronx
description: Party rules mean that Republicans who live in the most liberal areas end up with the most influence per person.

title: 1891: German Silver for the German Emperor
description: BERLIN  All Berlin is laughing at a story for which the Vossische Zeitung is responsible. Last year the Czar presented to the German Emperor a magnificent troika, together with three Russian horses and a Russian coachman. The equipage excited great admiration in the German capital, no portion of it more than the splendid silver harness, which, it was said, had cost no less a sum than 20,000 roubles, or considerably over 3,000 sterling.

title: Your Weekend Briefing

title: Nico Rosberg Rises Above Chaos to Win Chinese Grand Prix
description: SHANGHAI  While the reigning world champion, Lewis Hamilton, had another discouraging result early in the Formula One season, his Mercedes teammate, Nico Rosberg, extended his dream start with a third victory in a row.

title: A New Alternate-Side Trick
description: Dear Diary:

title: Humanitys Future  Fragile or Hyperconnected, or Both?
description: In an Op-Ed article this weekend,Parag Khanna, a Singapore-based analyst of geopolitical and economic trends,proposes a shift in the United States from state-focused policies and politics to regional planning:

title: 1941: Roosevelt Tells Press He Wants No Censorship
description: WASHINGTON  President Roosevelt, contradicting persistent reports that his Administration is planning some form of compulsory censorship of press and radio, gave assurance today [April 17] that freedom of speech and freedom of the press are not in danger in the United States. As far as I am concerned, the President promised, there will be no government control of news unless it be of vital military information.

title: Fry Cook, D.J., Janitor: Next Baltimore Mayor Had to Start Somewhere
description: A Baltimore storytelling group asked mayoral candidates to introduce themselves to voters by talking about their first jobs.

title: He Said His Car Had Been Stolen; the Police Say He Was Doing the Stealing
description: On April 1, police officers from the 108th Precinct were called to an address in Woodside, Queens, by a man named August Watkins. He reported that his car had been stolen. The timing of his call would become an issue in the days that followed.

title: 2016s Other Big Question Mark: The Senate
description: There is a second critical contest in Americas 2016 elections: the battle for control of the Senate.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Man Killed in Police Shooting in Queens, Authorities Say
description: New York City officers shot and killed a 32-year-old man in Queens in the early hours of Sunday after the police said he reached for a gun in his waistband during a chase.

title: Scenes of Ruin After Ecuador Earthquake Kills Hundreds
description: QUITO, Ecuador  The strongest earthquake to strike Ecuador in decades left the Andean nation traumatized on Sunday, with collapsed buildings in a swath of destruction stretching hundreds of miles.

title: What to Watch Sunday
description: Girls wraps for the season with a doubleheader. The Good Wife comes full circle as it nears the end of its run. And give Love a chance.

title: Axl Rose to Join AC/DC on Tour
description: On Saturday night, Guns N Roses brought out the AC/DC guitarist Angus Young at Coachella. Soon, the exchange will be reversed: Axl Rose, the Guns N Roses lead singer, will take up frontman duties for AC/DC on its world tour next month.

title: Disneys Savvy Marketing of The Jungle Book
description: All of this, honestly, is one big magic trick.

title: College Student Is Removed From Flight After Speaking Arabic on Plane
description: A college student who came to the United States as an Iraqi refugee was removed from a Southwest Airlines flight in California earlier this month after another passenger became alarmed when she heard him speaking Arabic.

title: Israel Will Never Give Golan Heights to Syria, Netanyahu Vows
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel led a cabinet meeting in the Israeli-controlled portion of the Golan Heights on Sunday, calling on the world to recognize Israeli sovereignty over the conquered territory and vowing that Israel would never give it back to Syria.

title: Jungle Book Captivates Moviegoers and Captures Box Office
description: Mowgli lit a box office wildfire over the weekend.

title: Are Earthquakes in Japan and Ecuador Related? The Science Says No
description: Earthquakes of magnitudes exceeding 7.0 struck Japan and Ecuador just hours apart on Saturday. Are the two somehow related?

title: Bronx Needle Exchange, Once Dismissed, Finds Acceptance
description: When Joyce A. Rivera decided in 1990 to confront the AIDS epidemic that had claimed her brothers life, she teamed up with unlikely allies: two drug dealers in the South Bronx. First, she educated them on how dirty needles and unprotected sex spread H.I.V., which causes AIDS. Then, she wound up distributing clean syringes to their customers in Mott Haven.

title: A Mockingbird Reopens in Alabama, and Drama Plays Out
description: MONROEVILLE, Ala.  The play unfolded here Friday at the Old Monroe County Courthouse pretty much as it has for the past 27 years. Atticus Finch defended Tom Robinson. The gospel choir sang. Scout used a slingshot to keep the boys in line and her curiosity to pose tough questions.

title: New Sense of Fragility in Japanese Town Struck Twice by Quakes
description: MASHIKI, Japan  People here said they had known that a network of fault lines ran under their town like veins. But no major earthquake had struck in anyones lifetime. Even in Japan, the most seismically unstable country in the world, that fact had apparently created a false sense of security.

title: Vineyard Theater Announces Season
description: John Kanders newest musical, Kid Victory, will make its New York debut in September as part of the Vineyard Theaters 2016-7 season.

title: In Doha, Major Oil Exporters Fail to Agree on Production Freeze
description: DOHA, Qatar  Officials from 18 oil-producing nations failed on Sunday to reach a deal to freeze oil production at current levels.

title: Labor Protesters to Resume Guggenheim Demonstrations
The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 3
description: Top contenders for the 142nd running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of preference, with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Churchill Downs has adopted a points system to determine the Derby field, with points being earned by the top four finishers in designated prep races. The odds are from the Churchill Downs futures pool, and the records are starts-win-place-show.

title: Bernie Sanders Courts Black Voters at Church Service in Harlem
description: After weeks of hosting packed rallies around New York State, Senator Bernie Sanders on Sunday decided to do something ahead of Tuesdays primary that his Democratic rival had already been doing for weeks: He spoke at a predominately black church service.

title: Ted Cruzs Conservatism: The Pendulum Swings Consistently Right
description: On perhaps the defining issue of the 2016 Republican primary, Senator Ted Cruz falls well to the right of Ronald Reagan, who supported granting legal status to millions of undocumented immigrants.

title: Donald Trump Says Rigged Convention Should Not Be Met With Violence
description: Donald J. Trump said on Sunday that he hoped the Republican National Convention doesnt involve violence as he pressed his case that the system is rigged against him.

title: Brazils Lower House of Congress Votes for Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff
description: BRASLIA  Brazilian legislators voted on Sunday night to approve impeachment of Dilma Rousseff, the nations first female president, whose tenure has been buffeted by a dizzying corruption scandal, a shrinking economy and spreading disillusionment.

title: Review: Mary Page Marlowe Traces a Womans Evolution in Phases and Fragments
description: CHICAGO  Its pretty fragile. Those words, spoken by the title character in Mary Page Marlowe, the exquisite new play by Tracy Letts having its premiere at the Steppenwolf Theater here, refer to a quilt in need of some delicate dry cleaning. But they resonate with many meanings in Mr. Lettss haunting, elliptical drama about the evolutions, reversals and resurrections in a womans life.

title: For the Mets, Its Just Sunny Enough in Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND  The Mets arrived here with no series victories, a slumbering offense and a rookie starter, Steven Matz, with a 37.80 earned run average. They left with two wins in three games, a new No. 3 hitter and the dazzling version of Matz on display.

title: In the Second Season of 12 Monkeys, Time Traveling Grows More Complex
description: The Syfy series 12 Monkeys, very loosely based on the 1995 movie of the same title, starts its second season on Monday. As you might guess, whatever faint traces of the film that remained when the television show started are now just memories.

title: Tech Companies Face Greater Scrutiny for Paying Workers With Stock
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For the last few years, LinkedIn, the professional social networking company, has doled out increasingly large amounts of stock to pay its workers.

title: Heng on North Koreas Defectors
description: In April, thirteen employees of a North Korean restaurant abroad sought political asylum in South Korea.

title: Review: Black Hole Blues Recounts the Quest to Find the Cosmic Kazoo
description: Just two months ago, scientists announced that they had heard, for the very first time, the sound of two black holes colliding in outer space.

title: Yankees and Alex Rodriguez End Skids in Win Over Mariners
description: If Manager Joe Girardis temperament is a weather vane for the Yankees fortunes, then his recent testiness  with a few dashes of sarcasm  may explain how the first two weeks of the season have unfolded.

title: Chocolat, a Biopic in France, Stirs a Discussion About Race
description: PARIS  The clown known as Chocolat, a former Afro-Cuban slave, was a fixture of Belle poque Paris. Toulouse Lautrec painted him  often in ugly caricature as a monkey  the Lumire Brothers filmed him and Jean Cocteau and Colette wrote about him. The first black performer to become a major popular hit in France and a key figure in its awakening as a multicultural nation, he died in poverty in 1917 and his memory faded.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of April 18
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Miami City Ballet, Dancing Balanchine, Raises the Bar in New York
