description: As Miami City Ballet  both heroic and sweet  went on dancing last week at the David H. Koch Theater, the extraordinary achievements of this company (founded 30 years ago) became newly clear. Of all the ballet troupes who have visited the Koch in recent years, none looks so truly and completely a company. None feels so effortlessly right for New York. None seems so satisfying a continuation of several trains of choreographic thought already known in this city. None gives us such warmth and energy.

title: Review: Knightlife Pokes Fun at Ballet With Silliness and Sophistication
description: In dance, as in life, youth has its privileges: There are things you can get away with for only a limited time. An older group of dancers, for instance, probably couldnt have pulled off Ethan Stiefels Knightlife, the comic ballet that opened a three-day run of American Ballet Theaters Studio Company at the Joyce Theater on Friday.

title: A Mahler Mini-Festival in New York
description: Mahlers big salute to spring in Das Lied von der Erde (The Song of the Earth) is decidedly backhanded.

title: Dungeons & Dragons: Satanic Panic
description: Dungeons & Dragons, introduced in 1974, attracted millions of players, along with accusations by some religious figures that the game fostered demon worship and a belief in witchcraft and magic.

title: When Dungeons & Dragons Set Off a Moral Panic
description: Going back at least to the 1690s, when the elders of colonial Salem, Mass., executed 20 women and men for supposedly practicing witchcraft, there have been Americans who find the devils hand in all manner of human activity.

title: Moolah
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  One of the nicest things about this job is the chance to welcome new constructors when their puzzles are published. Its always fun to see a new byline, and another nice thing, if they submit additional puzzles, is that I get to watch them grow as constructors.

title: After Long Silence, Indonesia Allows Talk of Anti-Communist Atrocities
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  When Putu Oka Sukanta was awakened by knocking on his door late one night in October 1966, he says, he instinctively knew who was there.

title: Civilian Casualties in Afghan War Are Unabated in 2016
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  With nearly 2,000 civilians killed or wounded and more than 80,000 people displaced this year already, the Afghan conflict continues to affect lives in record numbers, the United Nations said on Sunday.

title: Under English Garden, Unparalleled Remains of Roman Villa
description: LONDON  The geraniums grew in an oblong stone vessel, and no one ever thought much about it. But when Luke Irwin, a rug designer in the county of Wiltshire, England, hired workmen to lay electric cables under his yard, so that his son could have light in a barn when the family played table tennis, they uncovered an intricate mosaic floor of red, blue and white tiles only 18 inches down.

title: Nets Hand Reins to Kenny Atkinson, a Hawks Assistant
description: Working quickly to establish a new foundation, the Nets hired Kenny Atkinson, an assistant coach with the Atlanta Hawks, as their head coach on Sunday. Terms of the deal were not released.

title: Spare a Swipe? New York City Eases Rules for a Subway Request
description: It is New Yorks own version of hitchhiking: asking for a swipe of a strangers MetroCard.

title: Wall Street Veterans Bet on Low-Income Home Buyers
description: As the head of Goldman Sachss mortgage department, Daniel Sparks helped make the bank more than a billion dollars betting against the market as housing prices began to crash in 2007.

title: Brazilian Tennis Players Success Follows a Childhood of Obstacles
description: When Gustavo Kuerten, the three-time French Open champion, refers to a one-in-a-hundred-million chance of making it in professional tennis, he is not referring to Novak Djokovic or Serena Williams, who have combined for 32 Grand Slam titles.

title: Presidents and Kings
description: The leaders of the United States and Saudi Arabia have enjoyed close relations for more than 70 years.

title: New York Wineries Hope Palates Warm to Cold-Hardy Grape Varietals
description: EASTON, N.Y.  Gerry Barnhart named his new winery Victory View Vineyard because when he looks west from the top of a slope on his property, he can see the site where, in 1777, the Battles of Saratoga were fought.

title: Deadly Attacks in Ethiopia Leave Victims Wondering Why
description: GAMBELA, Ethiopia  In a bright green hospital room buzzing with flies, an older mans eyes glazed over with pain. His hand was pressed to his collarbone, where blood seeped through a white bandage.

title: Focus on Chief Justice as Supreme Court Hears Immigration Challenge
description: WASHINGTON  Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. twice voted to save President Obamas health care law, infuriating his usual allies on the right. Now, conservatives are nervous that the chief justice will disappoint them again in a challenge to another major Obama initiative, this one on immigration.

title: Found Alive, Soldiers Are Told: You Owe Us for Burials
description: BEHSUD, Afghanistan  The first time Noor ul-Haq died, his Afghan Army outpost was completely cut off by the Taliban on a bleak southern battleground. Hundreds of insurgent fighters swept in, and all that was left for the government to do was ship the corpses home.

title: An Old Alliance Faces New Pressures as Obama Heads to Saudi Arabia
description: WASHINGTON  Over the last seven decades, photographs of American presidents side by side with the kings of Saudi Arabia have provided visual evidence of an enduring, strategic alliance between the United States and the oil-rich kingdom in the Middle East.

title: Flyers Are Adamant That Soft Goal Wont Spell Doom in Playoffs
description: VOORHEES, N.J.  With arms crossed and a black baseball cap propped backward on his head, Philadelphia Flyers goaltender Steve Mason wearily took a few more questions Sunday about how he could have been beaten by a measly tip-in from, yes, 101 feet away.

title: Prep Schools Wrestle With Sex Abuse Accusations Against Teachers
description: BOSTON  Phillips Exeter Academy, an elite New Hampshire boarding school whose prominent graduates include Daniel Webster and Mark Zuckerberg, disclosed last month that it had forced out a popular teacher in 2011 because of sexual misconduct in the 1970s and 80s.

title: For Yankees, Pursuit of Titles Requires Tough Decisions
description: I still have the baseball that Bob Watson, then the Yankees general manager, signed for me in October 1996 after the Yankees had defeated the Atlanta Braves to win the World Series, ending an 18-year World Series drought.

title: New York Elections to Replace Silver and Skelos Offer Intrigue and Incivility
description: The voice on the phone had a reminder for the voters of the South Shore.

title: Obama Heads to Europe, Its Stability and His Priorities in Question
description: WASHINGTON  For much of his time in the White House, President Obama has labored to pull the United States out of the Middle East so he could pivot to more promising horizons in Asia. Now, as he winds down his presidency, it is Europe, another place where Americans have deep ties and a long history, that is exerting an unwelcome pull.

title: Donald Trump Assails Rigged Delegate System, Saying He Chooses Not to Exploit It
description: Join us for New York primary live updates.

title: Immigrants, the Poor and Minorities Gain Sharply Under Affordable Care Act
description: LOS ANGELES  The first full year of the Affordable Care Act brought historic increases in coverage for low-wage workers and others who have long been left out of the health care system, a New York Times analysis has found. Immigrants of all backgrounds  including more than a million legal residents who are not citizens  had the sharpest rise in coverage rates.

title: Quakes Aftershocks Come to Ecuadoreans in Queens
description: When news of the worst earthquake to strike Ecuador in four decades reached Corona, Queens, on Saturday night, the house of Assemblyman Francisco P. Moya there turned into a de facto Ecuadorean embassy.

title: Apple to Testify Again, and VW Due Date Nears
description: This is what to expect from the week ahead:

title: Even Before He Hit the Track, American Pharoah Offered a Glimpse of Magic
description: The McKathan brothers knew their horses. They might as well have been foaled in a stall themselves, seeing as how they spent the better part of their lives with runners in their backyards. Their father, Luke, trained horses at the long-gone Seminole Downs in Central Florida before deciding to chase bigger purses at racetracks from Florida to California. He did all right on the grits-and-hard-toast tracks of West Virginia and later at Tampa Bay Downs.

title: Sperm Donors Profile Hid Mental Illness and Crime, Lawsuits Say
description: When Angela Collins and her partner wanted to have a child, they reached out to a sperm bank in Georgia to look for potential donors. They thought they had found the perfect match in Donor 9623, described as a man with an I.Q. of 160 who was healthy and working toward his Ph.D.

title: Media Websites Battle Faltering Ad Revenue and Traffic
description: The business of online news has never been forgiving. But in recent weeks, what had been a simmering worry among publishers has turned into borderline panic.

title: For News Outlets Squeezed From the Middle, Its Bend or Bust
description: Earlier this month, a couple of inventive young go-getters at BuzzFeed tied enough rubber bands around the center of a watermelon to make it explode. Nearly a million people watched the giant berry burst on Facebook Live. It racked up more than 10 million views in the days that followed.

title: Discord Grows Among the Parties Over Greek Debt Talks
description: WASHINGTON  Executives of the International Monetary Fund mutter darkly about Greeks tapping their phones in Athens. Greek government officials accuse the fund of torpedoing their economy via tough austerity measures.

title: Seventh Generation Taps Maya Rudolph for Its Biggest Campaign Yet
description: WHEN Seventh Generation began selling environmentally sustainable products almost three decades ago, it was dedicated to the relatively few consumers who were interested in recycled toilet paper and paper towels. These days, green is mainstream, and companies like Walmart and Clorox promote their natural lines.

title: Vinyl Season 1 Finale: As Confused as Ever
description: Vinyl ends its first season the same way it began: with dialogue name-checking Lester Bangs, a violent death and a 1973 New York Dolls concert. The final episode splits its time between two plots. In one, the Nasty Bits finally get their showcase gig opening for the Dolls. In the other, Richie gets further entangled with the mob boss Corrado Galasso  which proves to be more hazardous than the time an entire building collapsed on him.

title: Amazon Challenges Netflix by Opening Prime to Monthly Subscribers
description: SEATTLE  Amazon is introducing new options to subscribe to its Prime membership service on a monthly basis, a change that could make the companys video service a tougher competitor to Netflix.

title: Connecticut Chooses to Cut Jobs Over Increased Taxes in Budget Crisis
description: Like some other states, Connecticut is facing a budget shortfall. And in part because of its shrinking finance sector and dependence on personal income taxes for revenue, state lawmakers, a majority of whom are Democrats, are finding themselves in a fiscal pickle.

title: Girls Finale: Is It Just Us, or Did the Show Get Better?
description: HBO aired the final two episodes of the fifth season of Girls on Sunday, which found Hannah (Lena Dunham) bonding with her college classmate and frenemy Tally (Jenny Slate), Marnie (Allison Williams) trying to understand her romantic impulses toward Ray (Alex Karpovsky), Shoshanna (Zosia Mamet) embracing her role as a marketer, and Jessa (Jemima Kirke) and Adam (Adam Driver) trying to make sense of their budding relationship. Amanda Hess, a staff writer, Margaret Lyons, the TV critic for Watching (the Times newsletter), and Jenna Wortham, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, discuss the entire season, and where the show might be headed in its sixth and final season.

title: Defensemans Overtime Goal Gives Islanders Edge in Series
description: There was another first at Barclays Center on Sunday night: an N.H.L. playoff game.

title: In London, Undressed Unveils the History of Underwear
description: LONDON  Enter any clothing store these days and you are likely to find yourself faced with the G.L.R.: the Great Lingerie Resurgence. White paneled silk slips trimmed with whispers of black lace at Cline, scallop-edged organza shorts and chemise tops at Dior and a seductive mishmash of boudoir and boardroom in the form of peek-a-boo bralets and power suiting at Givenchy and Balenciaga  we are in an underwear-as-outerwear moment.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | comeuppance
description: comeuppance \()km--pn(t)s\ noun

title: Corrections: April 18, 2016
description: NATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The law has clearly reduced broad measures of inequality.

title: What to Watch Monday
description: Paula gives Rebecca a tongue-lashing in the season finale of Crazy Ex-Girlfriend. Anthony Melchiorri tackles a hostel for the first time in Hotel Impossible. And Democrats follows efforts to create a democratic constitution in Zimbabwe.

title: North Korea May Be Preparing Another Nuclear Test, South Says
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Park Geun-hye of South Korea reported unspecified signs on Monday that North Korea may be preparing for another underground nuclear test in defiance of United Nations sanctions.

title: On Crime Bill and the Clintons, Young Blacks Clash With Parents
description: Rufus Farmer, 33, was tired of all the ways he saw black men being mistreated by the nations law enforcement system  from the police officer who once berated him for crossing the street to the mandatory prison sentences that sent so many of his peers away.

title: Putting a Humane, Dignified Face on Refugees
description: Refugee, migrant, asylum seeker: The words evoke images of uprooted people constantly on the move. Just do a Google search for refugee, says Omar Victor Diop, a photographer from Dakar. There are far more pictures of refugees on boats or trains or who jump a fence.

title: How a $15 Wage Affects the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: What Iran Needs to Fix
description: Since concluding the nuclear deal with the United States and other major powers last July, Iran has yet to realize the expected economic benefits. The Iranians are frustrated, but to a large extent have themselves to blame.

title: The Causes of Shorter Life Expectancies in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Geographys Role in the Life Expectancy of the Poor
description: An important new study shows that the poor in some cities, like New York and San Francisco, live longer than those with similar incomes in places like Detroit and Oklahoma City. The findings could help local and state governments figure out what they can do, or do better, to help people live longer and healthier lives.

title: Rigors of Study Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Africas Climate Stress
description: To the Editor:

title: Like Us, Animals Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: On Immigration, Law Is on Obamas Side
description: THE legal controversy surrounding the Obama administrations immigration enforcement policies will soon come to a head when the Supreme Court justices hear the case United States v. Texas on Monday. Texas claims that the presidents executive decisions lack legal sanction by Congress and have injured the state.

title: Housing for Ex-Offenders
description: To the Editor:

title: Sanders Dismisses the Deep South
description: Bernie Sanders had an odd, and for me, unsettling comment at the Democratic debate in Brooklyn on Thursday night.

title: Robber Baron Recessions
description: When Verizon workers went on strike last week, they were mainly protesting efforts to outsource work to low-wage, non-union contractors. But they were also angry about the companys unwillingness to invest in its own business. In particular, Verizon has shown a remarkable lack of interest in expanding its Fios high-speed Internet network, despite strong demand.

title: The Perils of Being a Black Philosopher
description: This is the second in a series of dialogues with philosophers on violence for The Stone. This conversation is with George Yancy, a professor of philosophy at Emory University and author, editor, co-editor of many books, including Look, a White!  Brad Evans

title: Transgender Bathroom Hysteria, Contd.
description: After the withering backlash against North Carolina for passing a discriminatory law against gay and transgender people last month, it would stand to reason that lawmakers and governors in other states would think twice before peddling bills that dictate which restrooms transgender people can use.

title: Have Comment Sections Failed?
Volatility Returns to Oil Market After OPEC Deal Fails
description: Its back to Square 1 for the oil markets.

title: E.L.L. Practice + Prompt | 2016 Summer Olympics
description: Note: We invite any English-language-learner student 13 years or older to post comments in response to the writing prompts in this post.

title: News Qs | Earthquakes Shake Ecuador and Japan
description: The following lesson activities are based on two articles: More Than 40 in Japan Are Confirmed Dead in Earthquakes and Earthquake in Ecuador Kills Hundreds.

title: What Should We Expect From the Supreme Courts Showdown Over Immigration?
description: This morning, the United States Supreme Court will hear arguments in United States v. Texas, a challenge to President Obamas attempts to grand relief from mass deportation to undocumented immigrants. Emily Bazelon, a staff writer for the magazine, and Eric Posner, a professor at the University of Chicago Law School, have been exchanging emails about whats at stake in the case and how the court might approach its decision.

title: Lyrid Meteor Shower Is Spectacular, Albeit Obscured
description: More than 2,700 years ago, Chinese astronomers observed a night in which stars fell like rain. Today, we call this celestial display the Lyrid meteor shower. The annual light show began Saturday, peaks this Friday, and ends April 25.

title: Chinas Vaccine Scandal Threatens Public Faith in Immunizations
description: HEZE, China  First the news rippled across China that millions of compromised vaccines had been given to children around the country. Then came grim rumors and angry complaints from parents that the government had kept them in the dark about the risks since last year.

title: Obama Immigration Plan Seems to Divide Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday seemed sharply divided during an extended argument over a challenge to President Obamas plan that would shield millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation and allow them to work in the country legally.

title: Avoiding the Dreaded Middle Seat May Now Cost You
description: As flying goes, the only thing more uncomfortable than sitting next to a couple having a spat on an airplane, Maury Rogoff learned, is sitting between that couple  especially when one partner prefers bare feet.

title: Among Travelers and Commuters, the Homeless Stop In and Stay
description: Wilson Silva said he knew the homeless situation at Pennsylvania Station had grown out of hand when he found a man in raggedy clothing sleeping on a couch inside the shop he manages, Drago Shoe Repair, in the rail terminals upper level.

title: Our Woman in New York: Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders on Friendly Turf
description: Maggie Haberman, a New York Times political correspondent, has devoted her journalistic career to two irresistible subjects: politics and New York City. At age 7, her first byline appeared in The Daily News; it has now been published in all three New York dailies.

title: Student Question | Should We Be Privy to the Lives of Celebrities Children?
description: Blue Ivy, North West, Max Zuckerberg  the children of celebrities are often in the public eye, to the delight of their parents fans.

title: Debunking the Vipers Strike
description: Rattlesnakes are part of the venomous viper family, thought to have the fastest strikes of any snakes. That is, until researchers decided to run a few experiments.

title: Vipers Arent the Only Kings of the Quick Strike
description: Vipers were thought to have the fastest strike of all snakes until researchers at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette decided to test two different kinds of vipers along with the nonvenomous rat snake.

title: The Universe in Your Hand and Seven Brief Lessons on Physics
description: Have you heard the joke about the elderly rabbi who tries to settle a bitter dispute between two men? The rabbi listens to one mans case and pronounces him right. Then he hears the second mans case, and concludes the second man is right. At this point his eavesdropping wife steps in and points out that both men cant possibly be right. To which the rabbi replies, And you are right as well!

title: Michael Kinsleys Old Age: A Beginners Guide
description: OLD AGEA Beginners GuideBy Michael Kinsley160 pp. Tim Duggan Books. $18.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | April 18, 2016
description: Updated: April 22, 2016

title: School Athletes Often Lack Adequate Protection
description: With all the attention on national rules to prevent and properly treat injuries to professional and college athletes, it may surprise you to learn that there are no nationwide guidelines to protect high school athletes from crippling or fatal injuries.

title: Your Monday Briefing: Bernie Sanders, Dilma Rousseff, Ecuador
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Amber Heard Wont Be Jailed Over Bringing 2 Dogs to Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The actress Amber Heard avoided jail time after a court appearance on Monday over allegations that she had illegally brought two dogs into Australia last year, violating the countrys quarantine laws, while visiting her husband, the actor Johnny Depp.

title: New York Today: Primary Preview
description: Updated, 10:04 a.m.

title: Wine From the Edna Valley With a Label From Jacques Ppin
description: Wholesome Wave, a nonprofit organization founded by the chef Michel Nischan to make healthful, affordable food available to underserved neighborhoods, is selling wine as a fund-raiser. Mr. Nischan had his friend the chef Jacques Ppin paint the label for the wine, which is being produced by One Hope, a winery in the Edna Valley of California. The 2012 pinot noir with scents of blueberry and lilac is complex and robust. It is making its debut at a benefit for the organization honoring Mr. Ppin on Wednesday in New York: One Hope 2012 Edna Valley Reserve Pinot Noir, $75, onehopewine.com/shop/2012-jacques-pepin.

title: La Caravelle to Be Resurrected, in a Fashion
description: La Caravelle, one of New Yorks classic haute-cuisine restaurants, closed in 2004. But for two days in May it will live again, as Rita and Andr Jammet, below, who owned it for almost half of its 44-year history, recreate the dining experience (though not quite the setting and maybe not the boldface clientele) at Chefs Club by Food & Wine. The event was suggested by Dana Cowin, the former editor in chief of Food & Wine magazine, who is now the creative director of Chefs Club. The three-course menu, prepared by the Caravelle alumni Tadashi Ono, Cyril Renaud and Laurent Richard, along with Chefs Club chefs, will include La Caravelles crab salad, quenelles de brochet, chicken in Champagne cream sauce and crme brle with raspberries: May 10 and 11; $110, not including beverages, tax or tip; La Caravelle at Chefs Club by Food & Wine, 275 Mulberry Street (Houston Street), 212-941-1100, chefsclub.com, prepaid reservations from chefsclubnyc.tocktix.com.

title: The Dogs That Don't Belong to Anyone
description: We asked Times readers on many continents  both English and Spanish speakers  to share some of their experiences with street dogs, village dogs and other dogs sometimes called strays.

title: The World Is Full of Dogs Without Collars
description: MONTAGUE, Mass.  Think of all the dogs out there: labradors and poodles and labradoodles; huskies and westies and dogues de Bordeaux; pit bulls and spaniels and lovable mutts that go to doggy day care.

title: Where Have All the Ear Infections Gone?
description: One way I knew my pediatrician was a good doctor was that he resolutely refused to diagnose anearinfection in my youngest child.

title: An Education in Basque Cuisine
description: I have to love a cookbook that starts with recipes for mayonnaise. And Alexandra Raij and her husband, Eder Montero, go well beyond mayonnaise to explain Basque cuisine. (He is the Basque side of the equation.) Txangurro, the deviled crab meat gratin that is served everywhere in the region but is often disappointing, was a winner here, despite the demanding preparation of a couple of ingredients. (You can work around them.) There was nothing demanding, though, about the excellent rice studded with cockles, the butterflied trout slipcovered in ham and given a splash of garlic and parsley oil, and the springtime lamb meatballs tucked among peas. For dessert, the notion of marinating fresh pineapple in sherry is a keeper: The Basque Book Alexandra Raij with Eder Montero and Rebecca Flint Marx (Ten Speed Press, $29.99).

title: New York Restaurateurs in the Big Easy
description: A little piece of New York is thriving in New Orleans. Mani Dawes, below right, an owner of Ta Pol in Chelsea, and her husband, Sean Josephs, below left, who owns Maysville in the Flatiron district, have relocated their family to the Big Easy. Easier indeed: Ms. Dawess mother is there to help with babysitting. In a neighborhood west of the Garden District (I thought it was somewhat remote, but locals say not) they have opened a handsome sibling for Maysville, also with a bourbon focus and named for the founder of Maysville, Ky., a port town on the Ohio River. Burnished wood, marble and cast-iron arches that could evoke New York as much as New Orleans set the stage for a menu of oysters (raw, grilled, fried and served on vintage oyster plates), red snapper tartare, smoked trout and grilled pork: Kentons, 5757 Magazine Street, New Orleans, 504-891-1177, kentonsrestaurant.com.

title: Chickys, a Specialty Grocery in Bedford-Stuyvesant
description: Its no surprise that organic produce, artisanal cheeses and grass-fed meats are infiltrating the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick. The latest is Chickys, established by Tara Oxley, who owns the restaurant Eugene & Company just down the block. Products and ingredients come from Murrays Cheese, DeBragga meats and Greenpoint Fish & Lobster Company. Prepared food to take home is made by Jeff Shields, the chef at Eugene & Company: Chickys, 406 Tompkins Avenue (Hancock Street), Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, 718-975-7646.

title: Noshing at the Columbus Circle Subway Station
description: More than 90,000 commuters a day pass through the Columbus Circle subway station. As of April 19, those who have a few moments to linger, or are even just looking for lunch, can buy dumplings, minidoughnuts, vegan cookies, grilled cheese, a bottle of wine or a Bolivian turnover like the saltea made just for this location. More than 30 shops and kiosks, about half of them offering something to eat or drink, fill the 325-foot-long concourse on the stations mezzanine level just south of the turnstiles. Above right, food from Ellarys Greens. Susan Fine, the developer, made a point to seek out local entrepreneurs. A lot of them are taking a big risk, she said. Greyston, the social service organization that makes baked goods in Yonkers, will have its first store in the mall: TurnStyle, Columbus Circle station, turn-style.com.

title: Argentine Teams Frequent-Flier Miles Cant Buy It Wins
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand  Los Jaguares Coach Ral Prez is quickly finding out about the need to rest and rotate players as his Argentine team circles the globe in its first Super Rugby season.

title: Union Seeks Higher Tariffs on U.S. Imports of Raw Aluminum
description: HONG KONG  An American labor union is pushing the United States to impose broad, steep tariffs on aluminum imports using a little-used but wide-ranging trade law that has riled the countrys trading partners in the past.

title: Morning Agenda: Crude Plunges After Oil Exporters Fail to Agree
description: CRUDE PLUNGES AFTER OIL EXPORTERS FAIL TO AGREE  | Oil took a tumble and stocks slid across Asia and Europe after talks about freezing oil production at current levels came to nothing,Stanley Reed and Andrew E. Kramer report in The New York Times.

title: Parrots: The Highlight Reel
description: We asked readers to show us why parrots are more than just a pretty bird. Out of hundreds of submissions, these are some of our favorites.

title: Parrots: The Highlight Reel
description: In March, Natalie Angier reported some of the latest findings about parrots, natures most colorful birds in more ways than one. Along with the article, we asked readers to submit videos of their feathered friends showing what makes them unique.

title: Campaigns Are Long, Expensive and Chaotic. Maybe Thats a Good Thing.
description: The election of a president of the United States isnt just democracy in circuslike action. It also may be, at its core, the most elaborate and expensive recruitment and hiring process that mankind has ever created.

title: Candidates Make Their Final New York Appeals
description: Join us for New York primary live updates.

title: Chinese Housing Market Shakes Off a Slump
description: HONG KONG  Chinas slowdown, which has cast a shadow over the global economy and worried investors around the world, stems in part from a deep slump in its crucial property market.

title: Bernies Israel Heresy
description: In New York, no less, days before a primary, a candidate for the Democratic Party presidential nomination declares that Israel used disproportionate force in Gaza in 2014, that we are going to have to treat the Palestinian people with respect and dignity, that the United States has to play an evenhanded role and that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is not right all the time.

title: Why Medical Devices Arent Safer
description: Things sometimes go wrong with airbags, food and drugs, prompting recalls. It can also happen with medical devices, though youd think lifesaving devices like heart defibrillators or artificial hips would be closely monitored.

title: Indonesia Rules Out Criminal Inquiry of Anti-Communist Purges
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesias security minister said on Monday at a symposium devoted to the mass atrocities committed half a century ago during anti-Communist purges in the country that the government had ruled out a criminal investigation of the period but would consider an unprecedented expression of regret to victims and their families.

title: Chinese Parents Outraged After Illnesses at School Are Tied to Pollution
description: BEIJING  Chinese families were in an uproar on Monday after a report in the state news media revealed that nearly 500 students at a school in eastern China had developed illnesses, a few as severe as leukemia, possibly because of pollution at a nearby field.

title: A Professional Foe of Climate Campaigners Gets His Big-Screen Moment
description: Production note: Im traveling overseas for a week, so comment moderation, sadly, will be spotty.

title: Twitters Chief in China Raises Eyebrows Over Military Past and Rsum
description: On the day Twitter named Kathy Chen as its new chief for China, she turned to the service to introduce herself to its vast and voluble user base.

title: The Royal (Clothes) Tour of India
description: The seven-day British royal tour of India and Bhutan, which ended on Saturday, was an opportunity for many things, including benign national outreach and a show of good will between countries with a complicated history, as well as multiple photos featuring Prince William and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge (the former Kate Middleton) on safari and at the Taj Mahal.

title: Origin of Trumpism
description: To the Editor:

title: 1941: St. Pauls Is Bombed
description: LONDON  St. Pauls Cathedral, mother church of the British Empire, suffered a direct bomb hit on the north transept in a recent German air raid, it was revealed today [April 18] by officials who removed a ban on publication of news of the damage. The bomb destroyed the saucer dome of the transept, dropped into the inner portico and tore tons of masonry out of the floor, leaving a gaping hole to the crypt. Almost every pane of glass, some dating from the time of Sir Christopher Wren, St. Pauls designer, was blown out. New York Herald Tribune, April 19, 1941

title: Shareholder Value as the Culprit
description: To the Editor:

title: Teenager Is Accused of Live-Streaming a Friends Rape on Periscope
description: When an Ohio teenager witnessed her 17-year-old friend being raped, according to officials, she not only failed to help the victim, she pointed her phone and streamed a live video of it on the Periscope app.

title: How Many Eggs Does a Chicken Lay in Its Lifetime?
description: Q. How many eggs does a chicken lay in its lifetime?

title: Amid Ethnic Conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh, an Oasis Thrives
description: STEPANAKERT, Azerbaijan  On a crystalline spring morning, Iosif Adamyan sipped coffee on the veranda of his guesthouse, overlooking a pear orchard in bloom and, in the distance, a range of snowy mountains.

title: Tech Companies May Face a New Cost to Paying in Shares
description: Tech companies may have to take stock of giving stock.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Banker Brother of Malaysian Premier Steps Aside From Posts Amid Inquiry
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Malaysias billion-dollar political scandal claimed another casualty on Monday when the prominent banker Nazir Razak announced that he would temporarily step aside while his bank examined his handling of nearly $7 million he received from his brother, Prime Minister Najib Razak.

title: Putting Faces to Names in the iPhone Contacts App
description: Q. How do I add a photo to someones address file directly in my iPhones Contacts app?

title: When Lies Are Allowed in a Business Deal
description: The French philosopher Ren Descartes wrote that all deception or fraud involves some imperfection. How much imperfection is required to be convicted of the federal crimes of mail and wire fraud has been clarified, at least a little bit, by recent appeals court decisions recognizing that some lying is acceptable, and even expected, in the business world.

title: Challenge to Google Books Is Declined by Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday refused to revive a challenge to Googles digital library of millions of books, turning down an appeal from authors who said the project amounted to copyright infringement on a mass scale.

title: Fear the Walking Dead Season 2, Episode 2: The World Said Enough
description: Some people, after seeing Jaws, never swam in the ocean again. Some, after seeing enough depictions of the zombie apocalypse, got serious about their What If? plan. Emergency kits with water rations went into both cars and under beds. Families were emailed about disaster plans.

title: Wardrobe for a Royal Tour
description: As expected, the clothes worn by Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, during a recent visit to India and Bhutan drew lots of attention.

title: Once Again, Raptors Are Scrambling After an Opening Loss
description: After one game was in the books in each of the N.B.A. first-round playoff series, there were few surprises. Seven of the eight home teams won, many by comfortable margins.

title: A Bus Tour of The Real Housewives
description: Here's a Snapchat tour of sites frequented by the women in The Real Housewives of New York.

title: When a Senator Passes Judgment on a Chief Justice
description: WASHINGTON  The other day, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, decided to lecture Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.

title: Game of Thrones Has Moved Past Its Blueprint, and Thats a Good Thing
description: On Sunday, April 24, Westeros  or at least its frequent visitors  will be liberated. With Season 6, HBOs fantasy saga Game of Thrones will move past the story line of A Song of Ice and Fire, the uncompleted series of George R. R. Martin novels that it is based on.

title: Goldman Prize For Six Bottom-Up Environmental Leaders
description: Production note: Im traveling overseas for a week, so comment moderation, sadly, will be spotty.

title: China Cracking Down on Children on Reality TV
description: Children can be cute, giggly and prone to tantrums. But according to Chinas top broadcast regulator, what they can no longer be is featured on Chinese reality television.

title: 1966: Moscow-Paris Stowaway Dies
description: PARIS  The body of a stowaway was found today [April 18] in the landing-gear well of a plane arriving from Moscow. The man, about 24, had apparently died of exposure. The finding touched off speculation that the man was a political refugee who had sneaked aboard in Moscow.

title: The Most Important Primary Is ... Wait, Indiana?
description: Join us for New York primary live updates.

title: Tribeca Interview: Viola Davis and Catalina Sandino Moreno
description: In Custody, which had its premiere Sunday at the Tribeca Film Festival, the children of a young Colombian-American mother (Catalina Sandino Moreno) are put into protective custody after one child arrives at school with cuts and bruises. Viola Davis plays the judge who hears the case in family court. But the film, written and directed by James Lapine (the stage veteran whose credits include Sunday in the Park With George), doesnt leave the drama in the courtroom. It also explores the home lives of both the mother and the judge, telling their stories from complex perspectives.

title: Britons Will Be Poorer if They Leave E.U., Government Asserts
description: LONDON  The British government outlined the central argument on Monday it hopes will persuade voters to stay in the European Union, publishing a detailed economic analysis finding that Britons will be poorer if they quit.

title: Appeals Court Affirms Landmark N.F.L. Concussion Settlement
description: PHILADELPHIA  Nearly three years ago, the N.F.L. and lawyers for thousands of retired football players agreed on a deal to compensate all former players who had neurological diseases linked to repeated hits to the head, helping the league to move on from one of the most contentious issues facing the nations most popular sport.

title: A Fierce Toast From Alice Feirings Drinking Horn
description: There are certain criteria for guests invited to dinner at Alice Feirings railroad one-bedroom, fourth-floor walk-up in a former tenement on Elizabeth Street in Manhattan.

title: Tenants Thwarted Donald Trumps Central Park Real Estate Ambitions
description: Madelyn Rubinstein moved to New York City from Long Island in 1985 with big dreams of making it as a professional pianist.

title: U.S. Comes Up Short on Corporate Transparency
description: PARIS  Journalists have done their job, again, with another enormous leak of documents outing a global list of rich and powerful people who hid their wealth in offshore companies.

title: Quick Recipes for Slow Food
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Bus Bombing in Jerusalem Wounds 21
description: JERUSALEM  A bomb exploded on a bus in Jerusalem on Monday, wounding about 21 people and feeding a sense of vulnerability among many Israelis after months of simmering violence.

title: Court of Appeals Opinion
description: The 69-page ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit on the settlement between the N.F.L. and potentially thousands of retired players regarding repeated head hits on the field.

title: Jo Boaler: Mathematical Mindsets
description: The thingI love about Numberplay the bitthat really defines it is that its not about correct answers. Instead, its about insight and exploration. During our weeklong discussion, didwe discover something new maybe a nice visual or analogy? Did we come up with a nice twist on the problem something a bit different (and more interesting) than the original challenge? And did we bring out the best in each other?

title: Earthquake Leaves a Trail of Destruction in Ecuador
description: PORTOVIEJO, Ecuador  The rumbling had ended and the rubble had settled, and Manuel Zambrano, 21, took stock of his situation: Somehow, he was alive.

title: Honesty Tops Any Checklist When Looking for an Adviser
description: Now that more financial professionals are going to have to act in their customers best interest, where can you actually find someone who will really, truly, for sure do that?

title: Chappatte on Clinton, Sanders and the Battle for New York
description: New York voters head to the polls on Tuesday.

title: Les Liaisons Dangereuses Is Coming to Broadway
description: The Tony-winning actors Janet McTeer and Liev Schreiber will be the latest scheming aristocrats sparring over love and revenge when a British production of Les Liaisons Dangereuses transfers to Broadway.

title: A Parisian Editors Best Natural Beauty Advice for Spring
description: Clmence von Mueffling, 37, is a third generation beauty editor. Born in Paris, she was introduced to body creams, toners and fragrances at an early age  both her mother and grandmother served as beauty editors at Vogue Paris from the late 50s through the early 90s. I remember them telling me that there was a code among the women who worked there  they were all incredibly elegant and polished, says von Mueffling. Still, she didnt immediately pursue the same career path: Instead she spent nearly five years on the marketing and communications side at brands like Clarins and Dior before moving to New York in 2007 and assuming the beauty editor role at Casas & Gente, an interiors and lifestyle magazine thats since folded. But her six-year stint there sparked the idea to start a magazine-like website, Beauty and Well Being, which von Mueffling launched in 2014.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: College Admissions Frenzy
description: To the Editor:

title: Notable Deaths 2016
description: Remembering Nancy Reagan, David Bowie, Harper Lee, Merle Haggard, Anita Brookner, Clyde Lovellette, Anne Jackson, Monte Irvin, Maurice White, Umberto Eco and others who died this year.

title: Surprise Surge Completes Ethiopians Boston Marathon Sweep
description: At the 15-mile mark of the womens race at the 120th Boston Marathon on Monday, the pack had dwindled to four runners. Atsede Baysa of Ethiopia was not one of them. At 22 miles, she was 37 seconds behind.

title: Houston Submerged by Two Feet of Rain Overnight
description: Dozens of water rescues played out in the Houston area overnight Sunday after a powerful line of thunderstorms unleashed as much as two feet of rain, forcing much of the city to tread water.

title: Israelis Find New Tunnel From Gaza Into Israel
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military said on Monday that it had discovered and neutralized a tunnel running from the Gaza Strip into Israeli territory for the first time since a cease-fire ended 50 days of fighting in the Palestinian coastal territory in the summer of 2014.

title: Morgan Stanleys Weak Quarter Bodes Poorly for Full Year
description: Morgan Stanley is already waiting for this years Godot.

title: Daniel Rose, an American in Paris, Comes Home to Cook
description: Ask Daniel Rose a question, and hell respond with a question of his own.

title: General Mills and 7-Eleven Join the Venture Capital Crowd
description: At first glance, the maker of Cheerios and Cocoa Puffs might not fit the image of a cutting-edge venture capital investor.

title: A Path to Clean Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: Crazy Ex-Girlfriend: Everything It Promised, and Then Some
description: Ive had this experience more often as a TV critic than I care to remember. A new batch of fall pilots arrives. Most are forgettable. One of them stands out, fresh, risky, experimental. Funny. Delightful, I write in my notes. Totally going to get canceled!

title: At Last, New Yorks Turn to Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Obamacares Striking Effect on Americas Least Fortunate
description: Republican lawmakers, particularly in the House and in state governments, have been adamantly opposed to the Affordable Care Act, the 2010 health reform law often referred to as Obamacare. Perhaps thats because the legislation has helped millions of poor people, minorities and immigrants get health insurance.

title: 1972 | A Pulitzer for the Pentagon Papers? Not So Fast.
description: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times.

title: Salone del Mobiles Most Inviting Design Element: Food
description: Amidst the overwhelming sea of design installations at Salone del Mobile, how do you get people to pause long enough to appreciate anything during this extravaganza? Invite them to eat.

title: U.S. to Send Military Advisers Closer to Front Lines of ISIS Fight in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  President Obama will send American military advisers closer to the front lines of the conflict against the Islamic State in Iraq, part of a series of measures that will escalate the United States military campaign to defeat the extremist group.

title: Bernie Sanders Gets the Celebrity Treatment in Midtown Manhattan
description: In a city packed with celebrities, Senator Bernie Sanders strutted around Manhattan on Monday causing some chaos as screaming fans, selfie-snapping supporters and surprised workers mobbed him.

title: Donald Trump, Ted Cruz and the Stakes on the Republican Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Hope for Reversing Type 2 Diabetes
description: Many experts believe Type 2 diabetes is an incurable disease that gets worse with time. But new research raises the tantalizing possibility that drastic changes in diet may reverse the disease in some people.

title: The Best Sellers: Filed Under Sports
description: The best-selling sports books in March 2016, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

title: In Towering Redwoods, an Abundance of Tiny, Unseen Life
description: More people are likely to have reached the summit of Mount Everest than have been to the top of an old-growth redwood tree, which helps explain why we know little about the biodiversity these giants harbor.

title: Alexis Rockman Bridges the Gulf Between Art and Science
description: In 1959, the British writer C.P. Snow complained that scientists and artists lived in two cultures and that the gulf between them was one of mutual incomprehension.

title: What You Should Watch This Week: The Night Manager and Better Call Saul
description: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next several days.

title: Having a Mentor Is So Important: On Brett Ratners Instagram
description: Welcome to Social Capital, a series devoted to analyzing the social-media presences of celebrities.

title: Europe Tried to Rein In Google. It Backfired.
description: Google is a top target for European regulators and privacy watchdogs, who openly fear and distrust its dominance. The American tech giants search engine alone gobbles up roughly 90 percent of the European market.

title: Man Arrested on Charges of Improperly Obtaining Handgun Licenses
description: A member of a volunteer security force in Borough Park, Brooklyn, was charged on Monday with offering bribes to New York Police Department officials to obtain handgun permits  the first arrest directly linked to the widening  federal investigation into police corruption and Mayor Bill de Blasios fund-raising efforts.

title: Burundi Is Torturing Prisoners in Crackdown on Dissent, United Nations Says
description: GENEVA  Burundis security services are torturing and illegally detaining increasing numbers of people, the United Nations said on Monday, reinforcing international alarm over the governments ferocious crackdown on political opponents.

title: The Lumineers Cleopatra Debuts at No. 1, No Ho Hey Required
description: Four years ago, the Lumineers, an earnest indie-folk band from Denver, scored a left-field pop hit with the song Ho Hey, which went to No. 3 with help from its placement on TV shows and commercials.

title: 2 Captured Russian Men Sentenced to Prison in Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  A Ukrainian court sentenced two Russian men to 14 years in prison on Monday for fighting against Ukraine as active-duty soldiers in the Russian military, a central issue in the separatist war in southeast Ukraine.

title: Argentina Re-Enters International Bond Markets
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentina returned to global bond markets on Monday after a 15-year hiatus, unveiling the biggest sovereign issuance by an emerging-market nation in two decades as the government ends a prolonged feud with hedge funds in New York.

title: In IVF, Questions About Mosaic Embryos
description: The couple wanted a baby boy, but the male embryo they had chosen  the only one available after an expensive round of in vitro fertilization  received a troubling test result.

title: Do Honeybees Feel? Scientists Are Entertaining the Idea
description: Bees find nectar and tell their hive-mates; flies evade the swatter; and cockroaches seem to do whatever they like wherever they like. But who would believe that insects are conscious, that they are aware of whats going on, not just little biobots?

title: 2016 Pulitzer Prizes: A.P. Wins Public Service Award; Hamilton Is Honored
description: The Associated Press won the Pulitzer Prize for public service on Monday for a series that exposed slavery and vicious abuse in the Southeast Asia fishing trade, leading to the release of 2,000 captives and broad reforms in the United States and overseas.

title: Tiny Motor Powers a New Threat to Cycling Races
description: A grueling cycling race is somewhat less grueling if your bike is a motorcycle. Understanding this, some cunning cyclists may be turning the sport into Nascar on two wheels by surreptitiously giving their bikes a motorized boost.

title: Atop the Met, a Haunting House
description: Cornelia Parkers Transitional Object (PsychoBarn), which opens Tuesday on the roof garden of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, proves that this British sculptor best known for squashing and exploding things is much better at building them.

title: Republican Consultant Cheri Jacobus Files Libel Suit Against Donald Trump
description: A longtime Republican consultant who has been harshly criticized by Donald J. Trump filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit on Monday accusing him and his campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, of making false statements that harmed her professionally and personally.

title: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europes refugee crisis.

title: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europes refugee crisis. The Timess team was comprised of Mauricio Lima, Sergey Ponomarev, Tyler Hicks and Daniel Etter. This is the newspapers fourth photo Pulitzer in the past three years.

title: Old Houses From Canada Find a Home in Washington State
description: FRIDAY HARBOR, Wash.  Here in the San Juan Islands of northwest Washington State, where a severe shortage of affordable housing threatens the economy and the community, a small nonprofit group has found an unlikely way to help anchor families that are struggling to stay  by lifting up unloved houses in Canada, hoisting them onto barges and hauling them to where they are needed.

title: AIDS Treatment in Haiti Promising for Developing Nations
description: One of the first groups of H.I.V. patients in a poor country to get free AIDS drugs has about the same survival rate as their closest counterparts in the United States, according to scientists at Weill Cornell Medical College.

title: Hillary Clinton Pushes Bill to Allow Families of Terror Victims to Sue Foreign Governments in U.S. Courts
description: Hillary Clinton on Monday reiterated her support for legislation that would allow the families of victims of terrorist attacks, such as the ones on Sept. 11, 2001, to hold foreign governments accountable in American courts, putting her on the opposite side of President Obama on a bill that is popular with New Yorkers.

title: Eileen Myles | A Reading of Her Poem Milk"
description: Tavi Gevinson, Hari Nef, Beth Ditto and others read the feminist poets 1997 work, the meaning of which she explains in this video.

title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
description: A foreign correspondent for about 15 years, Alissa Rubin is known for descending deep into some of the worlds scariest conflicts and returning with rare, often poignant glimpses into the plights of soldiers, survivors and victims.

title: 2016 Pulitzer Prize Winners
description: The Pulitzers are in their centennial year, and the winners announced on Monday reflected in part the changes sweeping the media landscape. Here is the full list.

title: Reality vs. Ideology on Immigration at the Supreme Court
description: As she often does, Justice Sonia Sotomayor got to the human heart of a complicated legal dispute at the Supreme Court Monday morning, in United States v. Texas, one of the most politically explosive cases to reach the justices in years.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Operations Against ISIS
description: The Department of Defense has identified 13 American service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State militant group. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: 3 Things The Times Looks for in a Pulitzer Nominee
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Glenn Kramon, a former assistant managing editor at The Times, demystifies the Pulitzer nomination process.

title: IBM Results Show Progress in Cloud and Data Analysis
description: IBM delivered a quarterly performance that shows the steady headway it is making in new businesses led by cloud computing and data-analysis software, like its Watson artificial intelligence technology.

title: Review: Arcane Collective Turns a Beckett Trilogy Into Physical Theater
description: A man in a ratty trench coat and a bowler hat slowly extracts a smooth pebble from his mouth, and then another and another and another. He holds the stones hes been sucking in his right hand, but with his left, he finds more stones in one of his pockets. What to do with those? Thus ensues a little comedy in the transfer of stones between cupped hand, pocket and mouth, a little routine about desire and dissatisfaction and existential absurdity that evokes the laughter of self-recognition.

title: Beyond the Trump Show? Two Political Plays in Chicago Give It a Try
description: CHICAGO  Nobody would argue that this election cycle has been short on political theater. Granted, much of it could be compared to the kind of theater that sends you fleeing at intermission. But of drama, yes, there has been plenty.

title: A Peppy Track by Atlantas Buzziest Female Musicians  and Best Friends
description: On a recent night at New Yorks Soho House, D.J. Speakerfoxxx and Bosco performed a handful of tracks off their new Fools Gold mixtape, Girls in the Yard. The songs are vivacious and fun: It is impossible not to bounce and body roll while they play. But equally infectious is their pure, unadulterated affection for one another, as collaborators and close friends: Throughout the performance, the duo grinned at each other as they tossed out lyrics and danced.

title: Virtual Reality Movies Add Dimension to Tribeca Festival
description: During two hours in the Virtual Arcade at the Tribeca Film Festival you can swim with whales, ride a dragon, become a rabbit, fly by Pluto and dodge spurts of blood unleashed by a machete attack. More exciting than any of those individual experiences, however, is the sense that youre in a room full of possibilities and of creative people still in the early stages of figuring out what those possibilities are.

title: Review: Gabriel Miss and Guillermina Quiroga Tango With Passion and Laughter
description: Tango, with the dramatic proximity it gives two dancers from brow to instep and its dramatically weighted walk, can be the most sexually charged of dance forms. Its romantic, smoldering and very often tragic  as if destiny were steering the couple. But Gabriel Miss, who has been coming regularly to New York since 2008, is all laughter and song. On Saturday night, he was chuckling boyishly around the Dardo Galleto Studios as he prepared the recordings to which he was to dance.

title: Review: Salut Salon Mixes Whimsy and Virtuosity
description: In a classical-music-comedy market (yes, there is one) buoyed by social media, the German female quartet Salut Salon has developed a loyal following. The groups performance style mixes the virtuosic silliness perfected by the duo Igudesman & Joo with the high-octane performance style of the rock-cover specialists Two Cellos, but adds lavish doses of whimsy and sex appeal. A video clip of the violinists Angelika Bachmann and Iris Siegfried, the cellist Sonja Lena Schmid and the pianist Anne-Monika von Twardowski engaged in competitive instrumental acrobatics during a medley of Vivaldi, Mozart and Weill has drawn over 20 million clicks on YouTube.

title: Mark Bradford Will Represent U.S. at Venice Biennale
description: Mark Bradford, the highly regarded abstract painter, has been chosen as the United States representative to the next Venice Biennale, opening in May 2017. The United States pavilion, with Mr. Bradfords work, will be organized by Christopher Bedford, director of the Rose Art Museum at Brandeis University, which was chosen by the Department of States Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs to be the commissioning institution for the exhibition.

title: Filming Turns the Boston Marathon Finish Line Into a Set
description: BOSTON  Hours before the first runners crossed the finish line of the Boston Marathon on Monday, a uniformed police officer ambled near the blue and yellow marker across Boylston Street. He seemed at first glance unremarkable, barely distinguishable from the legions of law enforcement officers keeping watch over New Englands biggest sporting event.

title: Review: Christiane Karg and Yo-Yo Ma Revel in the Classics
description: Weill Recital Hall

title: Review: A Dizzying and Dense Portrait From Nora Chipaumire
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Toward the end of Nora Chipaumires Portrait of Myself as My Father on Saturday, the dancer Shamar Watt stood face to face with Ms. Chipaumire, who was carrying a third performer, Pape Ibrahima Ndiaye, on her back.

title: Review: David Meanss Hystopia, Not Your Average War Novel
description: Hystopia, David Meanss dark acid trip of a novel, reads like a phantasmagorical  and sometimes pretentious  mash-up of David Foster Wallaces Infinite Jest, Charlie Kaufmans screenplay Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind and Michael Herrs Vietnam classic, Dispatches.

title: Photography Pulitzer: Thomson Reuters Coverage of Migrant Crisis
description: Thomson Reuters and The New York Times shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europes migrant crisis.

title: Review: CWs Containment Joins the Killer-Virus Bandwagon
description: When the global pandemic comes it wont be pretty, but at least well know exactly how events will proceed. Well know this because of the  sorry  epidemic of virus shows and movies in recent years, which are all beginning to feel more or less the same.

title: Review: Le Carrs The Night Manager, With Amoral Arms Dealing
description: The novels of John le Carr are steeped in shadows and ambiguity. So its a little disconcerting that The Night Manager, the first television adaptation of a le Carr novel in 25 years, is so bright and straightforward and that, despite a few nasty but necessary killings, its so clear who were supposed to root for. If TV shows had jaws, this ones would be square.

title: Panel Would Make Insurers Help Contain Rising Drug Costs
description: WASHINGTON  An influential federal advisory panel is calling for Congress to force private insurers to rein in rapid increases in prescription drug costs  by cutting some Medicare payments to insurance companies while shielding older Americans from higher out-of-pocket expenses.

title: Michael Friedman to Be Artistic Director of Encores! Off Center
description: Michael Friedman, the composer and lyricist behind Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson, will be the next artistic director of Encores! Off Center, a City Center program that every summer presents concert performances of musicals previously staged Off Broadway and beyond.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: You Dont Like the Girls in Girls? Thats Its Genius.
description: Normally, youd be confused. Why would HBO lower the curtain on Season 5 of Girls with two episodes on Sunday rather than the usual one at a time? Why not give the shows 10 episodes a full 10 weeks? But there are the mysteries. Then there are the realities.

title: Pulitzer for Feature Photography, Jessica Rinaldi
description: Jessica Rinaldi of The Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story about a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Ecuador, Immigration, Dilma Rousseff
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Ad Agencies Need Young Talent. Cue the Beanbag Chairs.
description: At the headquarters of the McCann agency in Manhattan, the battle for the future of the advertising industry is being waged with piped-in electronic music and employee-brewed beer.

title: United States Artists Picks Up $20 Million in Funding From Ford, Others
description: The Ford Foundation, other philanthropic groups and some private donors have given nearly $20 million to United States Artists, an organization that makes grants to artists.

title: Netflixs Forecast for Growth Disappoints Wall St.
description: Netflix is now available in most countries around the world, putting more pressure on the company to continue its fast-paced growth abroad as well as at home.

title: Farmers Markets Go From Sidewalk to Hotel Lobby
description: The hottest attraction at your hotel may be its farmers market. Properties around the country are increasingly hosting markets featuring local vendors. Most are open to the public, but a few, like the quarterly market at the Rosewood CordeValle in San Martin, Calif., are exclusively for hotel guests.

title: Donald Trump Tries to Show Support of Blacks at a Chaotic Gathering
description: Donald J. Trump met Monday at Trump Tower with select members of a recently formed diversity coalition, the brainchild of his companys adviser, Michael Cohen, who called on longstanding relationships with some black pastors to form a group to rebut questions about Mr. Trumps attitudes about race.

title: Obama Calls on Putin to Help Reduce Violence in Syria After Peace Talks Stall
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama had an intense conversation with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday in which he expressed concern on the eve of his visit to the Middle East and Europe about the fragile Syrian peace talks and increased violence in Ukraine, White House officials said.

title: Jacob deGrom Looks to Rejoin Mets
description: PHILADELPHIA  Mets starting pitcher Jacob deGrom moved closer to returning to the team when his newborn son was released from the hospital.

title: Tosca Pauses When a Diva Misses Her Cue on Vienna Stage
description: Was it a stunning diva moment or an innocent mishap?

title: L Train Tunnel Repairs Wont Start Until 2019
description: Amid growing concern about a lengthy closing of the L train tunnel between Manhattan and Brooklyn, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Monday that a shutdown would not start until early 2019.

title: Global Debate Over War on Drugs Heads to U.N. General Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS  Canada has promised to legalize marijuana. Mexicos highest court has allowed some citizens to grow cannabis for personal use. Colombia has reversed its decades-long policy of aerial spraying against coca, the raw ingredient in cocaine.

title: Yemen Peace Effort Falters as Houthis Refuse to Attend Talks
description: AL MUKALLA, Yemen  Peace talks aimed at ending Yemens civil war that were set to begin on Monday faltered before they could start, when delegates representing Yemens Houthi rebels refused to attend.

title: A New York Primary That Actually Matters
description: Arthur: Hi, Gail. I hope you enjoyed our week off. Although American politics almost ground to a halt last week because we didnt do The Conversation.

title: At Last, a Box Henry Threadgill Fits Nicely Into: Pulitzer Winner
description: Henry Threadgill, who on Monday was awarded this years Pulitzer Prize for music, is a composer and bandleader of intense, unyielding originality, nobodys idea of a compromise. An alto saxophonist and flutist with a distinguished career in the post-1960s American avant-garde, he has amassed a body of work with its own functional metabolism, perpetually humming in a state of flux. He has certain affinities with, but no particular allegiance to, the jazz tradition.

title: Labor and Love in Californias Farmlands
description: Mimi Plumbs rediscovered images of California farmworkers in 1975 chronicle the excitement, and struggle, of ordinary people caught up in the union movement.

title: Rangers Welcome Sight of Ryan McDonagh in Practice
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Much to Coach Alain Vigneaults surprise, the Rangers captain Ryan McDonagh practiced fully on Monday, wearing a white jersey that meant he was not off limits and gripping a stick with a right hand that was broken two weeks ago.

title: Theranos Under Federal Criminal Investigation, Adding to Its Woes
description: Theranos, the embattled blood-testing laboratory, said on Monday that federal officials were conducting a criminal investigation into the company, adding to a series of questions from officials about its inner workings.

title: Absences Weigh on Jets as They Gather
description: When Coach Todd Bowles addressed the Jets on Monday, his first time speaking to them since they left team headquarters dazed and numb the day after a season-ending loss ended their playoff hopes, he stood before a group yoked by uncertainty as much as optimism.

title: Doris Roberts, Mother on Everybody Loves Raymond, Dies at 90
description: Doris Roberts, the Emmy-winning character actress best known for her role as Ray Romanos tart-tongued, interfering mother on the hit CBS series Everybody Loves Raymond, died on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 90.

title: New York City Council to Review 5 Bills Reining In Three-Quarter Homes
description: Five bills will be introduced in the New York City Council on Wednesday that aim to tackle the problem of unregulated flophouses catering to addicts, people with mental illnesses and others who are trying to avoid homeless shelters.

title: Bill Campbell, Coach of Silicon Valley Stars, Dies at 75
description: Bill Campbell, one of the most influential background players in Silicon Valley, who was known as coach there for his work advising technology industry stars like Steve Jobs at Apple and Larry Page at Google, died on Monday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 75.

title: Michigan Governor to Drink Flint Tap Water for a Month
description: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan, facing persistent criticism of his handling of the water crisis in Flint, on Monday took home five jugs of filtered tap water from the city and said he planned to drink it and cook with it for at least the next month.

title: Harold Wood, Westchester County Legislator and Justice, Dies at 96
description: Harold L. Wood, the first black member of the legislative body of Westchester County, N.Y., and later the first black State Supreme Court justice in the county, died on Thursday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 96.

title: Obama Will Meet With Gulf Leaders. Heres a Probable Agenda.
description: President Obama will meet with leaders from the Gulf Cooperation Council this week in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

title: Obama to Visit a Saudi Arabia Deep in Turmoil
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  The images of the past year have been deeply unsettling for the people of Saudi Arabia, long accustomed to oil-fueled prosperity and regional clout: militants firing at communities along the countrys southern border; protesters storming the Saudi Embassy in Tehran; civil wars raging in three nearby states.

title: Cuomo and de Blasio Campaign Hard for Hillary Clinton Despite Complex Ties
description: Join us for New York primary live updates.

title: Already Troubled Pipeline Deal Gets Hung Up on Basic Provision
description: One of the messiest mergers in recent memory reached new levels of messiness late Monday.

title: Facing Impeachment, Dilma Rousseff Fights for Political Survival
description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil is likely to be kicked out of office based on allegations that she used money from state banks to balance the budget. But that fundamental issue appeared almost an afterthought as lawmakers in the Chamber of Deputies cited a litany of grievances before resoundingly supporting a motion to impeach her by a vote of 367 to 137.

title: Hillary Clinton, Candidate and Sundae Namesake
description: Victory sure tastes sweet.

title: Potential G.O.P. Convention Fight Puts Older Hands in Sudden Demand
description: The last time Stuart Spencer courted delegates at a Republican National Convention, in 1976, he kept a roll of quarters in his pocket for when he had to run to the pay phones and call in reports to President Gerald R. Fords campaign headquarters.

title: Pressure on Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton to Shine at Home
description: After a week of canvassing matzo factories, cheesecake bakeries, hot-dog stands and pizza shops, the presidential candidates put local delicacies aside on Monday and told New Yorkers what they were really hungry for: votes.

title: From Swipes to Taps: A Look at the End for MetroCards
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority outlined plans on Monday for a new fare payment system to replace the MetroCard. A look at what New York City subway and bus riders could expect from the proposed change:

title: Vote to Impeach Rousseff Prompted Cheers, But Wont End Turmoil in Brazil
description: BRASLIA  To those unfamiliar with the cacophonous tenor of Brazilian politics, the legislative session on Sunday night that approved the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff could have been mistaken for a soccer match.

title: Carnivals Maiden Voyage to Cuba Draws Ire and Bias Charges
description: MIAMI  When two Cuban-Americans here recently tried to book a trip on Carnival Cruise Lines maiden voyage to Cuba  the first American cruise ship to visit in at least 50 years  the result was not what they had in mind. It turns out Cuban law prohibits people born on the island from traveling there by ship, and Carnival rejected their reservation.

title: Richard Smith, British Painter Who Turned Toward Pure Color, Dies at 84
description: Richard Smith, a British painter whose idiosyncratic explorations of form and color embraced both Pop Art and Color Field painting, making him one of the most distinctive, indefinable artists of the 1960s and 70s, died on Friday in Patchogue, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 84.

title: Vehicle in Convoy of U.S. Ambassador to U.N. Kills Boy in Cameroon
description: MOKOLO, Cameroon  As the convoy barreled through a village in northern Cameroon on Monday, a 7-year-old boy darted to the road, excited to see the chain of white S.U.V.s carrying Samantha Power, the first cabinet-level American official to visit the country since 1991.

title: National Briefing
description: Fluctuations inside a huge tank of radioactive waste raised concerns on the Hanford Nuclear Reservation, and workers prepared Monday to pump out the area of the leak. A federal contractor said the amount of waste that has been leaking between the two walls of the underground tank for several years grew substantially over the weekend. None of the waste appears to have escaped into the environment, the contractor, Washington River Protection Solutions, said. But workers were trying Monday to determine why the waste that leaked between the tank walls rose by about eight inches on Sunday, then dropped by half an inch. Hanford, near Richland, for decades made plutonium for nuclear weapons, including the atomic bomb dropped on Nagasaki, Japan. Workers are preparing to pump the waste back inside the tank. It is Hanfords oldest double-shell tank and since March was being emptied of its 750,000 gallons of radioactive waste because of the leak. Less than 100 gallons of waste was estimated to have leaked into the gap between the walls in recent years, drying in three separate patches. But Hanford officials said that on Sunday an alarm sounded after the waste level rose.(AP)

title: Top Donald Trump Campaign Aide Quits in Shakeup
description: The national field director for Donald J. Trumps campaign  who is a loyalist to Corey Lewandowski, the embattled campaign manager  resigned in a letter to Mr. Trump on Monday afternoon.

title: Review: The Dingdong Offers Frothy Lingerie and Frisky Behavior
description: A slammed door is as essential to a French sex farce as fizz to Champagne, cream to a chocolate clair, rose to a Chanel perfume. But in the opening moments of Mark Shanahans occasionally hilarious and mostly harmless The Dingdong, presented by the Pearl Theater Company, poor Lucy Vatelin (Rachel Botchan) just cant get her door closed. Much as she prods and pulls, theres a lecher in the way.

title: Youve Been Warned
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Easily the most useful advice Ive ever gotten was when I visited a bird sanctuary in Africa, where the avian population soars above you, flying from tree to tree in a stunning and colorful replica of a misty rain forest. The first thing the helpful tour guides tell you, after Please apply this bug spray to your skin so that you dont get malaria is Whatever you do, dont look up. The birds will come down to you when they visit the feeders.

title: Stephen Currys Ankle Finally Gives Warriors Cause to Worry
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Most of the announced crowd of 19,596 fans attending Game 2 of the playoff series between the Golden State Warriors and the Houston Rockets wore golden-colored T-shirts reading Strength in Numbers. But the motto written on the Warriors latest marketing giveaway carried deeper meaning Monday night.

title: Man Arrested in Fatal Stabbing at Manhattan Homeless Shelter
description: After a three-day search, the police on Monday arrested a 53-year-old man who is suspected of fatally stabbing a fellow resident at a Manhattan homeless shelter and then slashing a cabdriver in the neck the next day.

title: Zika Virus Campaign Planned by New York City
description: New York City announced plans on Monday to combat the spread of Zika virus, a largely mosquito-borne disease that has spread rapidly in the Western Hemisphere and raised concern that it may cause birth defects in infants if their mothers are infected during pregnancy.

title: Election Choices From the Editorial Board
description: Here are recommendations in Tuesdays primary races and two special elections. The polls in New York City will be open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

title: Ex-Inmate Describes Rikers Beating as Open Season for Guards on Trial
description: As Jahmal Lightfoot tells it, Rikers Island correction officers pummeled him without any words  or any mercy  as he curled up into a fetal position inside a cell to shield himself from their repeated blows.

title: Donald Trump Invokes Memories of  7-Eleven?
description: Join us for New York primary live updates.

title: A House-Cleaning or a Coup?
Mets David Wright May Rather Be in Philadelphia Whenever He Can
description: PHILADELPHIA  David Wright has made a living hitting in Citizens Bank Park.

title: Experiment on Queens Waterfront Would Mix Manufacturers and Dwellers
description: Across New York Citys 520-mile shoreline, shimmering towers are replacing docklands and warehouses and factories. In barely a decade, On the Waterfront has given way to Miami Vice. But as these areas foster much-needed housing and a renewed connection to the water, much of their character, traditions and jobs are lost.

title: Better Call Saul Season 2 Finale: The Ultimate Betrayal
description: There was a death in the Season 2 finale of Better Call Saul, an unceremonious shot to the head that felled a hapless truck driver employed by the cartel. But Id argue that the real brutality came from the white-collar side of this two-pronged tale. The up-close depiction of brothers locked in a bitter psychological war can be far harder to watch than murder.

title: 2 Die in Fires in Queens and Brooklyn
description: Two people were killed in fires in Brooklyn and Queens on Monday, the authorities said.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | primordial
description: Q.

title: Voting on European Integration: A Long History of Skepticism
description: In past decades, when faced with plebiscites on whether to embrace further European integration, voters across the Continent had a habit of slamming on the brakes  though in several instances they later changed their minds.

title: The New York Primary
description: Candidates look to sway voters in New York.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: But I remembered the 33 trapped miners in the mine in Chile, and thought that if they could survive so many days, I could do it, too.

title: Corrections: April 19, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: John le Carr returns to the small screen after a lengthy absence with The Night Manager. Scientists try to figure out if fame got to Shakespeares head in Shakespeares Tomb. And Containment goes a long way to make a familiar point.

title: Q. and A.: Ning Zhu on the Guaranteed Bubble in Chinas Economy
