title: Investors Question Financial Sense of Abbott-St. Jude Deal
description: St. Jude is the patron saint of lost causes. Investors seem to be taking Abbott Laboratories $25 billion deal to buy St. Jude Medical in that spirit. Abbotts market capitalization tumbled over $5 billion on Thursday after it announced the purchase of the medical devices company. The companys problem is that the transaction looks to be destroying value.

title: Europes Case Against Google Might Help Rivals More Than Consumers
description: In a persistent (and thus far fruitless) effort to hobble giant American technology companies, the European Union has again taken aim at Alphabets Google search engine.

title: When an Expansion Dream Fizzles, Brooklyn Calls
description: When she tired of her rented five-story walk-up in Manhattan, Ava Volandes spent two years hunting for a one-bedroom co-op to buy. In 2002, she bought a one-bedroom in a postwar tower on East 17th Street near Gramercy Park for around $350,000.

title: Retired N.F.L. Players Appeal Ruling on Concussion Settlement
description: Nearly a dozen retired N.F.L. players have asked the entire United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit to consider hearing their arguments against the settlement between the league and thousands of former players who said the N.F.L. hid the dangers of concussions.

title: With Iraq Mired in Turmoil, Some Call for Partitioning the Country
description: With tens of thousands of protesters marching in the streets of Baghdad to demand changes in government, Iraqs Shiite prime minister, Haider al-Abadi, appeared before Parliament this week hoping to speed the process by introducing a slate of new ministers. He was greeted by lawmakers who tossed water bottles at him, banged on tables and chanted for his ouster.

title: The Idea of Trumps Electability
description: This weeks Campaign Stops column tries to reckon with an important part of the Trump surprise, which is the willingness of Republican primary voters who are plugged-in, high-information, politically-savvy voters by the standards of the country as a whole to support a candidate who is neither ideologically reliable norobviously electable. The ideological part is fairly easy to understand: Trump represents (among other things) arevolt of ideologically-heterodox Republicans against the partys litmus tests, which lots of people saw coming even if we didnt imagine would take this form or rope in quite this much support. But the electability issue is trickier to parse: No Republican (or Democratic) primary in generationshas produced a nominee with anything like Trumps unfavorable ratings or long general-election odds, and you would think the combination of eight years of Obama and the hated Hillary waiting in the wings would have concentrated voters minds on that, ah, problematic aspect of Trumps candidacy.

title: How Do You Move a 70,000-Pound (Dead) Whale?
description: A 70,000-pound whale just washed up dead on the beach. What do you do?

title: Why Is Productivity So Weak? Three Theories
description: More than 151 million Americans count themselves employed, a number that has risen sharply in the last few years. The question is this: What are they doing all day?

title: The Day Princes Guitar Wept the Loudest
description: On March 15, 2004, George Harrison was posthumously inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. As part of the ceremony, an all-star band performed While My Guitar Gently Weeps, Mr. Harrisons best-known Beatles song. The group featured Tom Petty and two other members of the Heartbreakers, as well as Jeff Lynne, Steve Winwood, Dhani Harrison (Georges son) and Prince, himself an inductee that year. Marc Mann, a guitarist with Mr. Lynnes band, played Eric Claptons memorable solo from the album version of the song. But Prince, who essentially stood in the dark for most of the performance, burned the stage to the ground at the songs end.

title: Kristen Griest on Course to Become First Female Army Officer Trained to Lead Troops Into Combat
description: Capt. Kristen Griest was among the first women to ever graduate from the Armys elite Ranger school, and after Thursday, she will become the first woman able to lead an infantry unit into combat.

title: N.F.L. Players' Petition for Concussion Settlement Hearing
description: The petition filed on behalf of nearly a dozen retired N.F.L. players asking the Third Circuit Court of Appeals to consider hearing their arguments against the concussion settlement.

title: How Majority Rule Might Have Stopped Donald Trump
description: Cambridge, Mass.  DONALD TRUMP has won Republican primaries in 23 states to date  far more than any of his opponents. Yet in the first 17 states he won, several of the other major candidates might well have beaten him in a one-on-one contest.

title: Boehner Insults. Cruz Responds.
description: Speaking at Stanford University, former Speaker John A. Boehner offered cutting remarks about the Republican candidate Ted Cruz. Mr. Cruz responded in Indiana by saying he had never worked with Mr. Boehner.

title: Q. and A. With Jason Bateman: A True Child of Hollywood
description: Believe it or not, Jason Bateman, at 47, has been on our screens for 35 years. Starting out on TV shows like Silver Spoons, he became the rare child star to forge a successful adult career. Hes perhaps best known as Michael Bluth on Arrested Development, but he has also starred in films like Horrible Bosses and Juno, and directed movies, too (the dark spelling bee comedy Bad Words.)

title: Ted Cruzs Alliance With John Kasich Hits New Low Point
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind.  Four days ago, the star-crossed, state-splitting alliance of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and Gov. John Kasich of Ohio made its debut.

title: Albums That Look Backward: The Range, Father, Parker Millsap
description: POTENTIAL

title: Bookshelf: Baseball
description: New picture books include You Never Heard of Casey Stengel?!

title: A Mod Little Birdhouse, and a Huge Pigeon Project
description: Every commission by the New York-based nonprofit Creative Time is, in some sense, fleeting. Since its inception in 1973, the organization has funded site-specific works for spaces around the city, often on a blockbuster scale  its much-talked-about projects have included Doug Aitkens sleepwalkers projections at MoMA in 2007 and Kara Walkers A Subtlety... at Domino Sugar Factory two summers ago  whose limited-time-only nature was part of their draw. But this spring, Duke Rileys project Fly By Night is fleeting in a rather more literal sense. On weekend evenings from May 7 through June 12, Riley will release a giant flock of pigeons, numbering in the thousands and outfitted with tiny LED-lit leg bands, to circle the East River in graceful formation and create a kind of undulating constellation.

title: Lizards, Too, May Sleep in Stages
description: Horses snooze in their stalls. Fish take their 40 winks floating in place. Dogs can doze anywhere, anytime. And even the lowly worm nods off now and then.

title: Kesha Will Release a Song, With Dr. Lukes Approval
description: Kesha  the pop singer whose career has stalled amid a drawn-out contract dispute with her longtime producer Dr. Luke that has rattled the industry with its claims of rape and abuse  will release her first song in years on Friday. And its Dr. Luke-approved.

title: Review: Graham Swifts Mothering Sunday, a Haunting Day Forever Relived
description: Graham Swifts slim new novel begins with that familiar fairy-tale conjuring spell Once upon a time, and if that werent enough of a giveaway, the books epigraph comes right out with a Cinderella reference: You shall go to the ball!

title: The Cast of The Good Wife on Favorite Moments From the Show
description: SCENE After learning that Alicia (Julianna Margulies) is having an affair with Will (Josh Charles), the other name partner in her law firm, Diane confronts him on the roof of their office building in this Season 3 episode and orders him to break it off.

title: Whispers of Louis Kahns Vision at the Yale Center for British Art
description: NEW HAVEN  After a decade of planning, eight years of renovation and a 16-month closure, the Yale Center for British Art  one of the half-dozen or so masterpieces designed by the Philadelphia architect Louis Kahn during the last 15 years of his life  reopens to the public on May 11. And for those who have loved this award-winning museum since it first opened in 1977, showcasing Paul Mellons superb collection of British art, the good news is that you can barely see the difference.

title: Review: In Keanu, Key & Peele Break Baddish for a Beloved Kitty
description: The absurdist kick in Keanu, the first movie to showcase Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele together, has a tiny tail and squeak. Beloved of crime lords and doofuses alike, Keanu the kitten shows up early, padding underfoot through one of those artfully staged drug labs  armed guards, white powder, ominous lighting  thats soon lit up with the sights and sounds of heavy artillery. Much like the Buddhalicious star hes named for, Keanu slips unscathed through the fast-and-furious raining bullets, miraculously dodging death as a heavenly chorus lays down an apocalyptic track. Kitten has skills.

title: 3 Tied to San Bernardino Gunman Are Indicted
description: LOS ANGELES  The investigation into the San Bernardino massacre produced criminal charges on Thursday against the brother of one of the attackers and two other people  not for contributing to the mass shooting, but for their roles in a sham marriage designed to skirt immigration laws.

title: Muslims in Brussels
description: To the Editor:

title: Labour Party Suspends Former London Mayor Over Hitler Remarks
description: LONDON  A dispute over accusations of anti-Semitism within the ranks of Britains Labour Party escalated on Thursday as the party suspended Ken Livingstone, a former mayor of London, over remarks suggesting that Hitler had at one point supported Zionism.

title: Expand Pipeline Capacity
description: To the Editor:

title: Nigerias Rights Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: The Most Creative Descriptions of Ted Cruz (So Far)
description: Lyin Ted feels almost tame.

title: Saturated Fat Is Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: Marijuana and Opioids
description: To the Editor:

title: Missing Money, a Vicious Attack and Slow Healing for a Charitys Leader
description: D. Alexandra Dyer felt as though her face were on fire.

title: Nicholas Kristof: Three Decades of International Reporting
description: Three decades of international reporting have provided Nicholas Kristof with his fair share of stories.

title: Becoming Irrelevant: My Recent Adventures With Trump
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Susanne Craig, a metro reporter, describes a series of phone calls she had with Donald J. Trump concerning her recent coverage of his aircraft.

title: Latest Turns on the Campaign Trail
description: To the Editor:

title: The Money Issue
description: In search of the middle class.

title: Remembering Brooklyn Priest Who Took On City, and Ears of the Police
description: One tough Brooklyn priest was the subject of the days Mass, the Rev. Brian Jordan said, as he started his homily in the chapel of St. Francis College in Downtown Brooklyn, where he is the chaplain.

title: N.F.L. Draft: Sometimes You Get Manning, Sometimes Ryan Leaf
description: In the N.F.L. draft on Thursday night, the top two players are expected to be quarterbacks, Jared Goff of California and Carson Wentz of North Dakota State.

title: Carl Icahn Says He Has Sold His Stake in Apple Over China Concerns
description: Carl C. Icahn has sold his 45.8 million Apple shares since the start of the year, telling CNBC on Thursday that he was concerned about Chinas policies regarding the technology giant while still calling the stock cheap.

title: This Is Your Brain on Podcasts
description: Listening to music may make the daily commute tolerable, but streaming a story through the headphones can make it disappear. You were home; now youre at your desk: What happened?

title: With Errant Twitter Post, Ed Balls, a British Politician, Spawned a Holiday
description: LONDON  It was one of the most celebrated Twitter posts in British political memory, one that has been retweeted tens of thousands of times, spawned an unofficial national holiday and inspired tributes in everything from verse to baked goods.

title: Anatomy | The Man Who Knew Infinity
description: Matthew Brown narrates a sequence from his film.

title: Matthew Brown Narrates a Scene From The Man Who Knew Infinity
description: The story of a mathematical partnership is told in the film The Man Who Knew Infinity, written and directed by Matthew Brown. It looks at the early 20th-century collaboration between Srinivasa Ramanujan (Mr. Patel), a shipping clerk who was in truth a mathematical genius, and G. H. Hardy, a lecturer at Trinity College at Cambridge University.

title: Review: Rainer Werner Fassbinders Intense World and His Films
description: Id like to be for cinema what William Shakespeare was for theater, Marx for politics, and Freud for psychology, the German director Rainer Werner Fassbinder is quoted as having said in the Danish director Christian Braad Thomsens documentary study, Fassbinder: To Love Without Demands.

title: Review: Ana Moura and Buika Negotiate Between Roots and Rules at Carnegie
description: The Spanish singer Buika followed the Portuguese singer Ana Moura on Tuesday night in a double bill at Carnegie Hall, and during Buikas set you could see something that doesnt happen all that often: audience members walking out.

title: Review: In Viva, a Star Is Waiting to Be Born
description: An exhilarating hybrid of Social Realism and feel-good aspirational entertainment, Paddy Breathnachs Viva is an oddity by its very pedigree: an Irish movie set in Havana, where it was filmed with a keen eye to that citys dinginess in tropical light. It infuses a too-familiar story with so much heart that you surrender to its charm and forgive it for being unabashedly formulaic. Even its one big plot twist is hardly a surprise. At the same time, its portrait of Havana, an impoverished city of crumbling architecture, has a gritty neorealist pungency.

title: Amazons Cloud Business Lifts Its Profit to a Record
description: SEATTLE  Amazon delivered a blowout quarter on Thursday, joining Facebook as one of the rare bright spots in a technology sector that has recently produced a string of disappointing earnings reports.

title: Why Mayor de Blasio Is Facing So Many Investigations
description: Since the Office of the Mayor of New York was established in 1665, many of the 109 men who have served in that post have attracted their share of scrutiny from commissions, constables and prosecutors.

title: Review: Viktoria, a Familys Atmospheric Voyage Through Change in Bulgaria
description: Eastern Bloc decrepitude has rarely looked as lovely as it does in Maya Vitkovas Viktoria, an offbeat allegorical satire that devolves into a cinematographer show reel. Shot in extra-wide screen by Krum Rodriguez, its story begins at the dawn of the 1980s in Bulgaria, where a girl is born without a bellybutton to a morose young woman against the backdrop of an infantilizing government.

title: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, April 30 Through May 8
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: As Sharks Buckled, Goalie Martin Jones Announced His Arrival
description: LOS ANGELES  Two years of waiting for redemption came down to one moment for the San Jose Sharks.

title: Review: Transfixed, a Real-Life Love Story, With Complications
description: You may need to adjust your definition of normal after seeing Transfixed. In this tender documentary, the loving couple at its center seems fairly ordinary  theyre dealing with money woes, weight gain, an impending marriage  until you step back and see that their other struggles also make them unique.

title: Words Can Never Hurt Me? Bah!
description: I have Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder and was prescribed Adderall, which has some side effects, including loss of appetite. My college roommate, who is one of my best friends, has made numerous comments about how lucky I am to be taking it because I dont feel hungry and eat less. I know these comments come from insecurity. They started right before spring break, when she was wishing for a better body. Still, I have had a long struggle with A.D.H.D., and these comments hurt. What should I do?

title: N.F.L. Draft 2016: Heres What Happened
Congress Opens the Door to Drafting Women
description: An influential congressional committee has taken another step towards sanity and equality in military policy by voting to require women to register with the Selective Service, making them eligible for the draft if another one ever is required.

title: Review: Sacrifice Yields Corpses and Clichs
description: While the line Its quiet  too quiet is never spoken in Sacrifice, this thriller trades heavily on a hoary genre convention. Directed by Peter A. Dowling, who also adapted the screenplay from Sharon Boltons novel, the movie features a physician, Tora Hamilton (Radha Mitchell), who moves from New York to the Shetland Islands in Scotland after a miscarriage. Her supportive partner, Duncan (Rupert Graves), hails from there, and with the help of some local residents, they intend to mend their hearts by adopting a baby in this pastoral setting.

title: Review: Ratchet & Clank, a Stale Tale Based on a PlayStation Game
description: Watching the generic computer-animated Ratchet & Clank, youre flooded with reminders of familiar characters. The hero Ratchet  a lombax, a frisky creature with big ears and eyes, who aspires to join the Galactic Rangers, protectors of the galaxy evoking the Green Lantern Corps  has the small physique and intent expression of an evolved Sonic the Hedgehog. His brainy sidekick, the robotic Clank, resembles a diminutive take on the title character from The Iron Giant; his voice could be a bookwormish twist on Marvin the Martians.

title: Routine Parts of de Blasios Day Arent Routine as Inquiries Swirl
description: He arrived through a back entrance, heading to the fourth floor for a prearranged event  on time, it might have been noted.

title: Review: Emanuel Ax Weathers Beethovens Emotional Storms at Carnegie Hall
description: Describing a pianists performance as unhinged might seem like an unlikely compliment. But the adjective could be applied in the most flattering terms to Emanuel Axs engrossing interpretation of Beethovens Pathtique Sonata on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: Review: Avishai Cohen Kicks Off Tour With a Set Both Turbocharged and Ghostly
description: During a mesmerizing stretch of Avishai Cohens first set at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night, his band fell quiet and he pointed the bell of his trumpet into the belly of the clubs piano. As he played a slow cadenza in a controlled high register, each note arriving as a clarion event, the sympathetic vibrations of the piano soundboard produced a shimmer of ghostly overtones, and a sort of pressurized hush.

title: Good for Porzingis? Then Carmelo Anthony Is Good for the Knicks
description: Jeff Van Gundy was speaking in his characteristically outspoken role as a television commentator, not as a reported candidate for the remaining N.B.A. head coaching vacancies, excluding the one in New York. He was in no way endorsing Phil Jackson as an accomplished Knicks president or Carmelo Anthony as a championship-level franchise player.

title: Review: Jay Armstrong Johnson and Friends Wax Ebullient
description: The musical-theater world has always exhibited an enthusiastic community solidarity. But among Broadway aspirants in their 20s and early 30s, theres an ebullient joie de vivre that has less to do with shared dreams of stardom than with generational camaraderie. That mood pervaded Wednesdays opening night performance of Jay Armstrong Johnsons cabaret show at Feinsteins/54 Below, a sprawling musical potpourri that involved well over a dozen musicians, backup vocalists and guests.

title: Review: Pali Road Blends Romance and Suspense
description: Pali Road is a decent romantic thriller with an uncredited co-star: the state of Hawaii, where it was filmed. The acting is on the wooden side, but the scenery is gorgeous.

title: Review: New York Philharmonic Presents a World Premiere
description: When the New York Philharmonic awarded the first Marie-Jose Kravis Prize for New Music to Henri Dutilleux in 2011, it became a gift that would keep on giving. Dutilleux, who was then 95 and died in 2013, decided to share the $200,000 proceeds with worthy younger composers of his choosing, in effect commissioning them to write for the Philharmonic.

title: Review: Papa: Hemingway in Cuba, a Mild Voyage With the Old Man and the Kid
description: At first, it strains credulity. In the late 1950s, just as rebellion is smoldering in Cuba, a reporter in Miami is laboring over a letter to his literary idol. Then, before you can say The Old Man and the Sea, the reporter, Ed Myers (Giovanni Ribisi), is whisked away to Cuba for a fishing trip with his hero, Ernest Hemingway. His adventure begins on a dock as Papa himself floats into view, commanding the flying bridge of his boat like a Roman charioteer.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, April 30 Through May 8
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Mothers Day Is a Goopy, Glossy Sentimental Mess
description: The unofficial conclusion of an unofficial trilogy of holiday-themed multistar comedy vehicles directed by Garry Marshall, Mothers Day has its perfunctory heart exactly where any experienced viewer would expect it to be. That is, in a fantasy world where, among other things, one older mothers lifetime of bigotry can be cured by half an afternoon spent with a mixed-race child.

title: Review: Exploring Domestic Drudgery in Play, Thing
description: In January, the choreographer Heather Kravas presented her aggressively stringent solo dead, disappears, in which she walked on her toes with her head covered by a garbage bag, urinated in a bucket and beat a pillow, duct-taped to a chair, with a pole. For her new play, thing, she extends her passion for repetitive movement and simple props with more dancers  six in total  who execute three independent, converging duets. It has a twin theme. The pillow is back, but this time there are two.

title: Review: Dough, a Sweet but Pat Tale of Bridging Religious and Racial Differences
description: Take an aging white Jewish baker, add a young black Muslim immigrant, and what do you have? The ingredients for a pleasant but pat story in which bridges are built across religious, racial and generational divides in a way that happens far more often in feel-good movies than in real life.

title: Picturing America in the Selfie Age, at the Whitney
description: A year ago, the Whitney Museum of American Art inaugurated its new downtown home with a permanent-collection showcase called America Is Hard to See. Its successor, the even more immediately engaging Human Interest: Portraits From the Whitneys Collection, is now on view. Astutely geared to the selfie age, it might well have been subtitled Americans Are Strange to Look At, which, in the 250 images here, we sure are: funny-strange, beautiful-strange, crazy-strange, dangerous-strange, inscrutable-strange.

title: The Week in Pictures: April 29
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

title: Obamas Visit Casts Brexit Vote in Stark Relief
description: LONDON  For travelers returning to London from distant places struggling for bare-bones survival, the portals of passport control sometimes resemble what a British writer likened to the looking glass in Lewis Carrolls fable of Alice.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, April 30 through May 8
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Bourek, About a Group of Drifting Souls
description: Bourek, which takes its title from a flaky Mediterranean pastry, is described in the publicity notes, somewhat optimistically, as a comedy. Viewers, however, are unlikely to be more than marginally amused by its fair-to-middling acting, enervated plot and forcibly diverse group of drifting souls gathered on the fictional Greek island of Khronos.

title: Dark Money and an I.R.S. Blindfold
description: It is plainly illegal for foreigners to contribute to American political campaigns. But reform groups are warning that the ban would be gravely undermined by a little-noticed bill advanced Thursday by Republicans on the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: The Bad-Ass Librarians of Timbuktu, by Joshua Hammer
description: THE BAD-ASS LIBRARIANS OF TIMBUKTUAnd Their Race to Save the Worlds Most Precious ManuscriptsBy Joshua Hammer278 pp. Simon & Schuster. $26.

title: Review: The American Side, a Hard-Boiled Noir Set in Buffalo
description: Judging from The American Side, detectives who say things like thats a gene pool screaming for chlorine and theres a joker in every deck have spent the past several decades hiding in Buffalo  not an obvious graveyard for the spirits of Raymond Chandler and Mickey Spillane.

title: Review: A Beautiful Planet Shows a Dazzling Earth From Space
description: You already know the big scenes will be awe-inspiring in A Beautiful Planet  how can your eyes not bug out when given 3-D views of Earth, taken from space, on a stories-high Imax screen? Whats surprising is how enjoyable the small moments are in this documentary, filmed aboard the International Space Station.

title: MetLiveArts Series Features Podcaster as Artist in Residence
description: Podcasts have become fixtures of commutes and working hours, but theyre entering museums, too. Nate DiMeo, creator of the podcast The Memory Palace, will be the 2016-17 artist in residence at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Ted Cruz, Donald Trump, N.F.L.
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: In Older Than Ireland, Centenarians Recall Early and Latter Days
description: A terrible beauty is born, Yeats wrote in his poem Easter 1916, about Irelands fight for independence from the British. But the 30 centenarians facing the camera in Alex Fegans delightful documentary Older Than Ireland are simply beautiful: frail, yes, but wise, wry, flinty, funny and sometimes very tender. All were born before the Easter Rising, an event widely celebrated this year that sparked the explosion in patriotism that ultimately led to the founding of the Irish Republic.

title: Review: Ingenious Versatility in the Whitneys Open Plan
description: For the last two months, the Whitney Museum of American Art has been highlighting the genius of the spacious fifth floor in its grand new downtown Renzo Piano building. The method of illumination is Open Plan, a rapid succession of five very different exhibitions ranging from four to 17 days long. In each case, an artist, working closely with a Whitney curator or curatorial team, was given the run of the space, unfettered by interior walls.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Review: The Man Who Knew Infinity Gives a Mathematical Genius His Due
description: Its time for Dev Patel to add fresh paints to his palette. This talented actor  who got his feature start in Danny Boyles Slumdog Millionaire  has largely specialized in handsome, earnest and well-meaning characters (in both Best Exotic Marigold Hotel movies and the canceled HBO series The Newsroom). Now comes The Man Who Knew Infinity, Matthew Browns respectful and, yes, earnest biopic about the early-20th-century mathematician Srinivasa Ramanujan, who found the divine in integers. Ramanujan, who was mentored by the Cambridge professor G. H. Hardy, eventually became the first Indian to hold a fellowship at Trinity College.

title: Theater Listings for April 29-May 5
description: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

title: My Grandfather Was a Famous Artist. He Also Made Greeting Cards.
description: TWO brawny construction workers perch on a plank dangerously suspended hundreds of feet off the ground in Men of Steel, a print that hangs in an exhibition at New York Universitys Grey Art Gallery. The men are heroic figures intent on their task  bolting a horizontal beam to a column.

title: Review: Sex, Death and Little Subtlety
description: Sex, death, sports and feminism animate Alps, an ambitious exhibition by Andra Ursuta occupying the New Museums fourth floor. Despite the potential metaphorical heat, these themes are muffled by a heavy-handed, academic intellectualism.

title: Comedy Listings for April 29-May 5
description: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

title: Bernie Sanders, Shifting Tone, Takes On Democratic Party
description: Senator Bernie Sanders spent Thursday afternoon laying out in more detail than usual his views for shaping the Democratic Partys agenda and the need for elected officials to focus on achieving progressive political goals.

title: Unpaid Annual Taxes Rise to $458 Billion, I.R.S. Reports
description: WASHINGTON  Potentially giving congressional Republicans new ammunition in their crusade against the Internal Revenue Service, the agency on Thursday said that annual unpaid taxes had increased to nearly half a trillion dollars.

title: Review: LAttesa (The Wait) Turns Life Into a Ghost Story
description: LAttesa (The Wait), Piero Messinas debut feature, is an elegant melodrama of maternal grief with overtones of horror, a psychological rather than a supernatural ghost story. Set in Sicily around Easter, the film partakes freely of religious imagery to add gravity and mystery to its domestic tale of loss, longing and deceit. The landscape  volcanic rock and quiet forests surrounding a sparkling lake  is captured in long, wide takes, a beauty surpassed only by close-ups of the two lead actresses, Juliette Binoche and Lou de Lage.

title: Movie Listings for April 29-May 5
description: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.

title: MoMA Galleries to Change Their Focus
description: The Museum of Modern Art is changing things yet again. After reinstalling the fourth-floor permanent collection  devoted to works from 1940 to 1980  MoMA, beginning in June, will radically rework its second-floor contemporary galleries by dividing them into three distinct spaces, each with a major installation from the collection focused on a single artist.

title: Review: Kidman and Bateman Face Childhood Scars in The Family Fang
description: The drama of the gifted child is, at least in movies, a gift that keeps on giving. Thats particularly true in American independent cinema, with its stories of suffering children, monstrous mothers and abusive fathers. There are moments when it feels as if the movie youre watching was written on a laptop propped up by a Syd Field screenwriting book and The Drama of the Gifted Child, Alice Millers 1979 book about children and parental narcissism. Act 1: Set up the wound. Act 2: Confront the wound. Act 3: Resolve the wound.

title: Dressed to Kill: The Power of Leopard Prints
description: For three decades, the burlesque performance expert Jo Weldon has studied why people wear clothes made of leopard patterns. She has concluded that in the last few centuries spotted-cat motifs have been used to attract attention and exude power, ferocity, independence, sophistication, sensuality and sometimes outright debauchery.

title: Impurity in the Pursuit of Salvation Is No Vice
description: David Roberts continues his carbon tax series. First he argued that such a tax isnt the be-all and end-all of climate policy; he concludes with a discussion of the political economy, and argues that a carbon tax should be sold as part of a package, with the revenue dedicated to things like clean energy promotion.

title: Classical Music Listings for April 29-May 5
description: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

title: Returning to Their Cuban Roots
description: For decades, many exiles refused to set foot on Cuba while the Castros were in power. Increasingly, though, their children want to explore their roots and play a constructive role in a homeland that loomed large during their upbringing but was relatively inaccessible until recently.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, April 30 Through May 8
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Eugene Von Bruenchenhein, King of Lesser Lands
description: Eugene Von Bruenchenhein (1910-1983) made doughnuts in a Milwaukee bakery. Otherwise he lived and worked in an enchanted world of art and fantasy that he ruled with his wife, Marie, in a small, clapboard house. There he produced a large and varied oeuvre of paintings, drawings, sculptures and photographs that remained unknown to all but his family and friends until a few months after his death. Now hes considered one of Americas great self-taught artists. This inspiring exhibition at Andrew Edlin samples his diverse efforts.

title: Review: David Claerbouts Video Art via Video Games
description: Video games emerged in the early 1980s, a decade after video art, but the games impact on the form has been moderate, compared with their powerful influence on feature filmmaking. David Claerbout, though, is among the artists who have adopted gaming techniques, which you can see clearly in Light/Work, this Belgian-born artists first exhibition at Sean Kelly.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for April 29-May 5
description: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

title: Review: Ryan Nord Kitchen: Small Abstracts, Big Impact
description: Modernism has a substantial tradition of small abstract paintings  paintings that normal people, those lacking private museums or vast real-estate acreage  can live with. This tradition includes many artists, among them, Paul Klee, Wassily Kandinsky (late), Alice Trumbull Mason and Myron Stout. The painter Bill Jensen revived it in New York in the early 1970s, as did, it seems, the Belgian Raoul De Keyser in Europe. Some current practitioners include Tomma Abts, Ann Pibal, EJ Hauser and Etel Adnan.

title: Review: Special Correspondents Stars a Fumbling Ricky Gervais
description: Maybe youve been waiting for Ricky Gervais to write and direct a completely conventional comedy, the kind that begins with slow-motion nighttime pans of the New York skyline and ends with the nebbishy hero and his nerdy love interest walking off toward the horizon. In that extremely unlikely event, youll want to check out Special Correspondents, available Friday around the world on Netflix.

title: Jazz Listings for April 29-May 5
description: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

title: Baltimore Police Wound Costumed Man After TV Station Standoff
description: The police on Thursday shot and wounded a costumed 25-year-old man after a standoff at a Baltimore television station, where the man said that he was carrying a bomb and demanded that a message be broadcast. The police opened fire on the man, officials said, because he refused to comply with the instructions of officers.

title: Lincoln Center Drafts Children as Detectives for Its Meet Me at the Fountain Series
description: An internationally renowned soprano is about to make her operatic debut at Lincoln Center. But a determined enemy of artistic excellence wants to destroy her voice. He would render her singing so awful that youd probably rather listen to Gilbert Gottfried.

title: Review: Attraction and Repulsion in Les Vaisseaux
description: troits Sont les Vaisseaux, the title of Kimberly Bartosiks new dance, means Narrow Are the Vessels in French. And the ground-level studio of Gibney Dance: Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center, where the work made its debut on Wednesday, is indeed a narrow space. Entering it, audience members brush past the pieces two striking performers, Joanna Kotze and Lance Gries, who are never farther than a few steps from the ring of seats and often close enough to touch.

title: Dance Listings for April 29-May 5
description: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

title: Two Momentous Occasions in New York History
description: It was April 30, 1939, a sunny Sunday, and New Yorkers were out in force for two history-making occasions.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for April 29-May 5
description: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

title: Review: Tillies Brings Farm to Table in Short Hills
description: Luckily for all, reviewers get to return to a restaurant before they render a verdict.

title: Spare Times Listings for April 29-May 5
description: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

title: Review: Nikkei of Peru Offers Dishes Inspired by a Japanese Diaspora
description: Some younger readers will find it hard to believe, but there was actually a time when sushi restaurants were considered exotic and chic. By now, though, the formula has grown tired: the black-lacquered furniture, the kitschy music, the watery miso soup (free!), the obligatory tuna roll. Its a blueprint in need of a swift kick.

title: Spare Times for Children Listings for April 29-May 5
description: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

title: Review: In Mount Kisco, Kebabs With or Without the Shish
description: After a complete renovation of an old corner spot in Mount Kisco, the Turk restaurant has emerged, adding a menu of kebabs and other Middle Eastern items to the citys roster of international cuisines.

title: Review: Harlan Publick in Norwalk Offers New Tastes With an Old Flavor
description: Although the building housing Harlan Publick, off Washington Street in Norwalk, is relatively new, its interior has the feel of an old brewery, with its exposed pipes and high industrial ceilings.

title: Obama Lobbies for an Appreciation of His Legacy
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama eases into the stocktaking stretch of his presidency, he has begun to unburden himself to select journalists. But the presidents tone is less reflective than frustrated that the American public does not see his achievements the way he does.

title: National Briefing
description: The longtime girlfriend of the Boston gangster James Whitey Bulger was sentenced on Thursday to an additional 21 months in prison for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating whether other people had helped him while he was a fugitive. The woman, Catherine Greig, 65, was already serving an eight-year sentence for helping Mr. Bulger while he was a fugitive. She spent 16 years on the run with him before they were captured in Santa Monica, Calif., in 2011. Prosecutors said Ms. Greig refused to answer questions before the grand jury even after she was given immunity and was ordered to testify. Mr. Bulger, 86, is serving a life sentence after being convicted in 2013 for playing a role in 11 murders. (AP)

title: Robert Linton, Steadfast 80s Wall Street Banker, Dies at 90
description: Robert E. Linton, a prominent Wall Street executive who led the swashbuckling investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert in the years before it imploded in scandal but who was largely untainted himself, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Iran Hints at Retaliation Over U.S. Use of Seized Assets
description: Iran escalated its invective against the United States on Thursday over the court-ordered use of nearly $2 billion in seized Iranian central bank assets to compensate American victims of terrorist attacks overseas, calling the action an outrageous robbery and threatening unspecified retaliation.

title: Rams Select Jared Goff With No. 1 Pick in N.F.L. Draft
description: CHICAGO  The Los Angeles Rams chose quarterback Jared Goff of California with the first overall pick in the N.F.L. draft, the latest move by a team trying to re-establish itself in Southern California after two decades in St. Louis.

title: Obama-Netanyahu Rift Impedes U.S. Offer of Record Aid Deal for Israel
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has proposed granting Israel the largest package of military aid ever provided by the United States to another nation, but he and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu remain deeply at odds over a figure for the assistance despite months of negotiations.

title: The Chrysler 200, Symbol of a Comeback, Slowly Fades Away
description: DETROIT  IT was the car that symbolized Chryslers comeback from bankruptcy, and the star of its iconic Super Bowl ad five years ago that played up vehicles imported from Detroit.

title: Street Homelessness Fell 12% in New York City, Survey Finds
description: Citing progress in moving homeless people off the street and into shelters, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday that an annual survey had found a 12 percent drop in the number of people living without shelter in New York City compared with 2015.

title: University in Turmoil Over Scalia Tribute and Koch Role
description: WASHINGTON  For years, students and faculty at George Mason University paid little attention as Charles G. Koch and other conservatives helped transform their once sleepy commuter school in the suburbs of the nations capital into a leading producer of free-market scholarship. The effort, after all, was focused on a few specific departments like economics and law and attracted little attention outside conservative circles.

title: Video Review: Hyundai Elantra Offers Fewer Curves, but a Better Ride
description: AROUND six years ago, Hyundai figured a 10-year warranty was not enough to attract shoppers and conjured up daring design for more attention. Sonata was the first to get the Fluidic Sculpture makeover, but the fifth-generation Elantra ended up being the swoopiest of the fleet. Hyundais newest gamble? Toning down those curves.

title: Faulting de Blasio for Walking a Beaten Path in Elections
description: Bill de Blasio, currently in the Pigpen phase of his mayoralty, with clouds hovering everywhere he goes, did not lay the pipes that carry unlimited cash to candidates for the State Legislature.

title: Out of Office, Ex-Speaker John Boehner Gleefully Releases Mute Button
description: WASHINGTON  John A. Boehner never minced words as House speaker, but he usually leveled his insults behind closed doors. Now a private citizen, Mr. Boehner is going public, and the results can be spectacular.

title: Suit Accuses New York Times Executives of Bias
description: Two women filed a federal lawsuit on Thursday against The New York Times, its chief executive and its chief revenue officer, saying that the company has been engaging in deplorable discrimination.

title: Company Behind American Idol Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: Core Media Group, the company behind the television shows American Idol and So You Think You Can Dance, filed for bankruptcy protection on Thursday.

title: Julie Johnston Takes On the World, and the Fight Over Pay
description: Julie Johnston had made only a dozen appearances for the United States womens national team when she started its opening game at the Womens World Cup last summer. She wound up starting all seven as the Americans won the title. Less than a year later, Johnston is a world champion, an Olympic gold medal favorite and as much of a fixture on the national team as Carli Lloyd, Alex Morgan and Hope Solo. Johnston, who turned 24 earlier this month, spoke with The New York Times on Thursday about equal pay, the responsibilities that fight entails and her future on the team.

title: Donald Trumps Gender-Based Attacks on Hillary Clinton Have Calculated Risk
description: With the nation on the verge of a presidential election between the first woman to lead a major party and an opponent accused of misogyny, Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump are digging in for a fight in which he is likely to attack her precisely because she is a woman.

title: Ford Doubles Profits for the Best Quarter in Its History
description: The combination of low gasoline prices and record auto sales in the United States is making for good times in the auto industry, and nowhere is that more evident than at Ford Motor.

title: Health Care Companies See Scale as the Only Way to Compete
description: A spate of deals on Thursday showed that health care companies are convinced, regardless of tax benefits, that bigger is not only better, it is necessary.

title: Jason Terrys Last Lesson in Chemistry for Distracted Rockets
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Jason Terry had learned enough from 114 career playoff games and had seen enough in 17 N.B.A. seasons to know that his teammates could use a motivational boost against the Golden State Warriors. More than anything, he realized that he and his teammates had nothing to lose  nothing, that is, except another game.

title: DreamWorks Animations Hits  and Misses
description: DreamWorks Animation is selling itself to Comcast, putting an end to an independent creative endeavor that brought Shrek, Kung-Fu Panda and Madagascar to the big screen  but also had its share of flops.

title: New Jersey Representative, Citing Fraud, Calls on Congress to Investigate FEMA
description: WASHINGTON  A representative from New Jersey called on Thursday for a congressional investigation into the Federal Emergency Management Agencys flood insurance program, alleging that wrongdoing by the agency had prevented thousands of victims of Hurricane Sandy from receiving the payouts they were entitled to in order to rebuild.

title: Jenny Diski, Author Who Wrote of Madness and Isolation, Dies at 68
description: Jenny Diski, a British writer who channeled the turmoil of her early years, which included suicide attempts and confinement in mental hospitals, into a stream of richly observed and mordant novels, memoirs and essays, died on Thursday at her home in Cambridge, England. She was 68.

title: Willie L. Williams, Head of 2 Police Forces in Turmoil, Dies at 72
description: Willie L. Williams, the first African-American to lead the police forces in Philadelphia and Los Angeles, cities in which hostilities between the police and black citizens had recently flared into violence, died on Tuesday at his home in Fayetteville, Ga. He was 72.

title: Laremy Tunsil Falls in N.F.L. Draft After Apparent Drug Video Surfaces
description: It was the bong hit that sent N.F.L. teams running.

title: Review: Shuffle Along Returns to Broadways Embrace
description: So just what is it, this tart and sweet, bubbly and flat, intoxicating and sobering concoction being dispensed from the stage of the Music Box Theater? Shuffle Along, which opened with a whoop and a sigh on Thursday night, has been suffering from an identity crisis in the weeks leading up to the announcement of the Tony Award nominations.

title: Shot Putters Supply
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Now this is a fun way to enter our solving weekend. This Times debut puzzle by Andrew Kingsley has some great stuff in it. The price you will have to pay to see that great stuff is that you will have to be more careful and think more about what you enter.

title: White Powder Mailed to Donald Trumps Campaign Office Deemed No Threat
description: A white powder that was discovered at the campaign office of Donald J. Trump at the Trump Tower in Midtown Manhattan on Thursday night was not a threat, the authorities said.

title: Planned Parenthood Gunman Mentally Unfit for Trial, Experts Testify
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo.  Robert L. Dear Jr. thought the feds had been after him for 20 years, cutting holes in his clothes and planting a listening device in his pickup truck. He believed President Obama was the Antichrist, and that the Planned Parenthood center he admitted firing on in November was the most evil place in the world.

title: Better New York Team? Numbers Say Mets
description: The 2015 baseball season began amid speculation that the Mets would actually outperform the Yankees, which is not something that happens that often.

title: Student Journalists Get Obama Access That Professionals Might Envy
description: WASHINGTON  For most journalists who cover the White House regularly, the chance to question President Obama comes rarely, and the opportunity for a one-on-one interview with him almost never.

title: Vijay Mallya, Indian King of Good Times, Dethroned by Debt
description: NEW DELHI  Three months before he left India with $1.4 billion in unpaid bills hanging over his head, the man who called himself the King of Good Times gave a party for himself.

title: In Eli Apple, Giants Add a Defensive Force With 10th Pick
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Nearly every N.F.L. team ceaselessly plans for the first night of the leagues draft, trying to anticipate every possible outcome of the teams picking before them. Teams also assess any conceivable off-the-field issue besmirching a top prospects worthiness, just in case that player is available when it is their turn to make a first-round selection.

title: Fresh Opportunities for the Stanley Cup
description: The casualties from the first round of the N.H.L. playoffs include the last four Stanley Cup champions and the entrants from the Original Six.

title: Jets Take Darron Lee, the Latest in a Long Line of Defensive Picks
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets draft philosophy, as explained by General Manager Mike Maccagnan, is not to let decisions be swayed by needs. If he were to factor them into his evaluations, it could skew the process, and so, Maccagnan has said, he adheres to his board and does not deviate.

title: U.S. to Curb Queries on Criminal Histories of Government Job Seekers
description: WASHINGTON  The White House on Friday moved to bar federal agencies from asking applicants for tens of thousands of government jobs about their criminal histories until the very end of the process.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | tutelary
description: tutelary  \t-t-ler-e, ty-\  adjective

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Its as incomprehensible as the Internet and social media can get, but people enjoy it.

title: Corrections: April 29, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: Team Foxcatcher revisits the shooting of the wrestler Dave Schultz by the wrestling patron John E. du Pont. Ricky Gervais and Eric Bana play radio journalists on the lam in Special Correspondents. And Ron Miscavige looks at the ascent of his son David, the leader of the Church of Scientology.

title: John Kasich Tells Oregon Voters His Wife Agreed: Keep Going
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Gov. John Kasich was helping his wife carry some clothes to the basement of their home in Ohio on Wednesday when they broached the subject that many Republicans have been wondering about.

title: Pick-by-Pick Analysis of the N.F.L. Draft's First Round
description: The first round of the 2016 N.F.L. Draft started the way most people expected it to  with quarterbacks going Nos. 1 and 2  but turned into a surprising mix of controversy, trades and questionable picks. Heres what happened.

title: North Korea Sentences American to 10 Years for Spying, Reports Say
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An American who has been held in North Korea since October was sentenced to 10 years of hard labor on Friday for spying and other offenses, news agencies reported from Pyongyang, the North Korean capital.

title: The Week in Pictures: April 29
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

title: The Racist Roots of a Way to Sell Homes
description: From the 1930s through the 1960s, most African-Americans could not get mortgages because the government had deemed neighborhoods where they lived ineligible for federal mortgage insurance, the Depression-era innovation that made mortgages widely affordable.

title: Dont Abandon Americas Afghan Helpers
description: The House Armed Services Committee approved a version of the 2017 defense spending bill on Thursday that would leave thousands of Afghan interpreters who worked for the American government in Afghanistan in the lurch.

title: A Summer Vacation That Lasts a Lifetime
description: In the summer of 1983, 8-year-old Darryl Rattray boarded a bus to Schenectady, N.Y., not knowing what to expect. At the time, he lived in a Bronx neighborhood plagued with drugs and violence. At home, his mother was undergoing treatment for breast cancer. The Fresh Air Fund provided a much-needed break.

title: Wrath of the Conned
description: Maybe we need a new clich: It aint over until Carly Fiorina sings. Anyway, it really is over  definitively on the Democratic side, with high probability on the Republican side. And the results couldnt be more different.

title: If Not Trump, What?
description: Donald Trump now looks set to be the Republican presidential nominee. So for those of us appalled by this prospect  what are we supposed to do?

title: Working-Class Fraud
description: He descended from the sky last Sunday in a helicopter that could have come from heaven, landing outside a hangar in Hagerstown, Md. He would talk for little more than an hour, mostly about himself, how he is a smart guy and I look really good and I equal love.

title: Theres No Such Thing as a Free Rolex
description: THIS week, the Supreme Court heard McDonnell v. United States, the case of Bob McDonnell, the former governor of Virginia who is appealing his 2014 conviction for public corruption. Although the courts ruling is not expected until June, in Wednesdays hearing several justices seemed set on undermining a central, longstanding federal bribery principle: that officials should not accept cash or gifts in exchange for giving special treatment to a constituent.

title: How to Prepare for the Next Recession
description: Washington  DESPITE solid job numbers, Americas gross domestic product grew by just 0.5 percent during the first three months of 2016, the slowest pace in two years. The current expansion is already longer than the postwar average, so it will be no surprise if policy makers begin asking, Is a recession lurking around the corner?

title: R.B.S. Losses Widen After Payment to British Government
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Friday that its losses widened in the first quarter compared with a year earlier, after it made a payment of 1.19 billion pounds, or about $1.7 billion, to the British government to fulfill a condition of its bailout package.

title: The Remarkable Rise of Leicester City
description: For casual soccer fans, it may be difficult to fully understand the absurdity of Leicester City winning Englands Premier League title. To say it is an upset or a shock or a stunner seems wholly inadequate, particularly when one considers that those words are so often used to describe one-time results (the United States over the Soviet Union in the 1980 Olympic hockey tournament, for example) as opposed to the feat of endurance that is required for a relative minnow like Leicester to dominate the sharks of English soccer for a nine-month season.

title: Anheuser-Busch InBev Offers to Sell More SABMiller Assets in Europe
description: LONDON  Anheuser-Busch InBev said on Friday that it had offered to sell the Central and Eastern European operations of SABMiller in order to win approval from European regulators for their more than $100 billion merger.

title: Refugee Held on Nauru Dies After Self-Immolation to Protest Australian Policy
description: An Iranian refugee who set fire to himself to protest Australias policies toward people who try to reach its shores by sea died on Friday.

title: News Qs | Beyonc Makes Lemonade Out of Marital Strife
description: The following lesson activity is based on the review Beyonc Makes Lemonade Out of Marital Strife by Jon Pareles.

title: Read This Story Without Distraction (Can You?)
description: Stop what youre doing.

title: Puerto Rico Debt Deadline Looms With Washington Still Haggling
description: In December, House Speaker Paul D. Ryan instructed lawmakers to find a responsible solution to Puerto Ricos debt crisis in the first three months of this year, giving the island plenty of time to prepare for a May 1 deadline on a $422 million debt payment.

title: A Checklist for New Landlords
description: Being a landlord is about far more than banking the rent checks. Here are some tips:

title: The Entire Netflix History of Us
description: Rob and I broke up on a Monday. It was the first warm day after an impossibly long winter, which made the whole thing feel that much more cruel. I was in line at Starbucks when I got a text that read, Hey, you around? I think we need to talk.

title: Plan to Turn Sony Building Into Luxury Apartments Is Abandoned
description: Apartments for billionaires were all the rage in Manhattan three years ago when the developer Joseph Chetrit paid $1.1 billion for the granite-sheathed Sony Building at 550  Madison Avenue.

title: When the Landlord Is a Friend
description: With New York City real estate prices soaring, the only way for some city dwellers to achieve the American dream of owning property is to become landlords. And these days, many landlords are their tenants contemporaries  learning on the fly how to manage property and relying on YouTube for how-to tutorials on home repairs. Still others are filling their homes with friends-turned-tenants.

title: Debt Collectors Adopt Mob Tactics as Russians Struggle to Pay Bills
description: MOSCOW  They have stripped and sexually abused a woman, severely burned a toddler by firebombing a house and broken a womans pinkie as a warning. Gang members, bandits, mobsters? Not exactly. These are debt collectors, a peculiarly Russian variety that is flourishing amid the countrys economic turmoil.

title: The Professor Has a Daring Past
description: Prof. Justus Rosenberg pulled a tattered, marked-up copy of Voltaires Candide out of a mushroom-brown soft zippered pouch emblazoned with the old Channel 13 logo. We have an existential problem, he said, waving the paperback at a seminar of 10 students at Bard College. The concept of the El Dorado. What does it mean, the El Dorado?

title: Student Question | Should Distracted Driving Be Punished Like Drinking and Driving?
description: Have you ever been a passenger in a car in which someone was texting and driving  or driving while scrolling through or posting to social media? Have you ever been that driver?

title: The 6 Countries That Tell the Story of Europes (Still Shaky) Recovery
description: Unlike the United States, which surpassed its pre-bubble peak in 2011, the eurozone as a whole has stumbled along. Here are some of the blocs notable leaders and laggards.

title: Europes Economy, After 8-Year Detour, Is Fitfully Back on Track
description: By one measure, the economic crisis that has long ravaged Europe is finally over.

title: If Anyone Here Objects to This Union, Bark
description: Some people say that bringing an animal to your wedding is as inadvisable as inviting an ex-lover with a drinking problem  trouble, if not injury, seems inevitable.

title: Protest Turns Violent at Donald Trump Rally in Costa Mesa, Calif.
description: A protest outside a campaign rally for Donald J. Trump in Costa Mesa, Calif., turned violent late Thursday night, as the crowd smashed a police car, the authorities closed nearby streets and officers arrested about 20 people.

title: Ask Well: Determining a Target Heart Rate
description: Question:

title: Your Friday Briefing: Ted Cruz, Aleppo, Laremy Tunsil
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: New York Today: The Science of Sneezing
description: Updated, 11:13 a.m.

title: Mr. Donahues Roast Beef Is Rare in Its Simplicity
description: The roast beef at Mr. Donahues, which opened in February on Mott Street, is a testament to the virtues of simplicity. But there are moments when Ann Redding and Matt Danzer, the chefs at the NoLIta microdiner, find themselves wrestling with that.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: 1 Minute of Exercise, E-Cigarettes and Cosmetic Surgery
description: Take the Quiz

title: The Curious Case of the Caspian Seas Scars
description: What crafted these crisscrossing lines in the Caspian Sea?

title: Seeing the Cycle of Life in My Baby Daughters Eyes
description: Like many new fathers, I spend as much of my free time as I can get away with gazing into my baby daughters eyes as she stutters and scans. I remember a day not long ago when I rocked my daughter, Eva, in my arms, and her eyes stopped and steadied as they looked back into mine. Her arms and legs ceased to rock and her entire body just relaxed. A chill went down my spine.

title: Raising a Child With Grit Can Mean Letting Her Quit
description: The rule at the grit expert Angela Duckworths house? You can quit. But you cant quit on a hard day.

title: Morning Agenda: Bigger Is Better For Health Care Companies
description: BIGGER IS BETTER FOR HEALTH CARE COMPANIES  | The entire health care industry seems to be following the same playbook, Leslie Picker reports in DealBook. And the advice seems to be to team up with a similar company so that you can become the leading provider and use your clout to negotiate with hospitals and health insurers.

title: The 4.17.16 Issue
description: RE: MINECRAFT

title: How to Deliver a Baby
description: You dont want the baby to fall on the floor, says Dr. Paulo Alves, a medical director for MedAire, which provides 136 airlines with medical training, logistics and a telephone service that connects flight attendants all over the world to emergency-room doctors in Phoenix. If a woman goes into labor somewhere far from a hospital  37,000 feet above the Pacific Ocean, say  ask if anyone in the vicinity has medical training. If not, help her into a comfortable place. On a plane, thats usually a reclining first-class seat or the galley floor. Make sure blankets support her body so that when the baby arrives, it lands gently. Babies are slippery when theyre born, Alves warns.

title: Ode to the Flute
description: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

title: Hunger Games in South Africa
description: I was never among the whos-who in Durban, the beautiful city on the Indian Ocean coast of South Africa, where I live. But a few years ago, after some success as a writer, I became a person to invite. I loved it, make no mistake: the parties with the intellectual set, the politicians and anti-apartheid heroes, the serious journalists and entertainers. It seemed I had arrived.

title: Letter of Recommendation: The Rabbit Who Wants to Fall Asleep
description: Putting our 3-year-old son to bed isnt a task my wife and I undertake lightly. On a typical night, there will be actual physical struggles and a great deal of bitter haggling over the particulars  over whether it will be she or I who keeps vigil as he bravely contends against his own fatigue, over how many stories will be read to him and which ones. There will also, typically, be a series of increasingly hostile demands for glasses of water, and at least one trip to the toilet that will eventually be exposed as a cynical diversionary tactic. One night, his claim that he needed to go was revealed as spurious, and I let him know that I was onto his hustle. Im not a fool, I said.

title: Eat, Pray, Love and Travel
description: Elizabeth Gilbert has written several best-selling books of fiction and nonfiction, but she is best known for Eat, Pray, Love, her 2006 memoir of travel and personal discovery in Italy, Indonesia and India. To celebrate the books 10th anniversary, Riverhead Books has published Eat, Pray, Love Made Me Do It, a collection of 47 essays written by people inspired by the book. Following are edited excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Gilbert.

title: Teenagers in The Times | April 2016
description: Our latest roundup of articles about young people that have appeared in The Times includes news from high school and college campuses, but this month a jaunt to Broadway also made headlines.

title: Soaking Up Starlight on Sark Island
description: Off the coast of Normandy, this isolated spot merits a Dark Sky designation.

title: Readers Pick Americas Greatest Year
description: When was America greatest? How about 1491?

title: A Job Interview With the Whole Airport Departure Lounge
description: Recently, I was waiting for a flight from Boston to San Francisco when I realized that a man seated nearby was loudly interviewing someone on his mobile phone for a technology job. At least five or six people could hear this, as well as a subsequent call he made to his supervisor telling him or her that he was passing on the candidate, in part because the requested salary ($180,000) was too high.

title: Vivian Lee: Trust in Your Own Leadership Style
description: This interview with Vivian S. Lee, C.E.O. of University of Utah Health Care, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Republicans Make Early Rush to California
description: Its primary election is not until June, but the rush to California  a gold mine of delegates  is on.

title: Ted Cruz, Attacking Donald Trump, Uses Transgender Bathroom Access as Cudgel
description: INDIANAPOLIS  As Senator Ted Cruz of Texas seeks every possible edge to stop Donald J. Trump, he has seized on a once-obscure issue with a proven power to inflame conservatives: letting transgender women use womens bathrooms.

title: Sexual Assault Ruling in Oklahoma Spurs Calls to Change State Laws
description: Outraged activists and prosecutors in Oklahoma called for changes to a state law on forced oral sex after a court rejected the prosecution of a teenage boy in Tulsa because his 16-year-old accuser had been intoxicated to the point of unconsciousness.

title: Got Ink? Navy Is Relaxing Its Rules on Tattoos
description: The United States Navy is loosening its rules governing tattoos effective Saturday in response to their growing popularity among young people and to remove a potential barrier for desired recruits.

title: Cloud Services Show Their Value in Earnings Reports
description: Ten years ago last March, Amazon started the era of renting data storage and computing over the Internet, what is now known as cloud computing. On Thursday, Amazon showed how critical it is to the retailers future.

title: A Private Equity Alums Guide to Better Payday Lenders
description: Yale. Morgan Stanley. Private equity.

title: A New Windows PC for an Old iTunes Library
description: Q. I want to move my iTunes library from my old Windows computer to my new computer, which runs Windows 10. Which method is the easiest?

title: Better Aging Through Practice, Practice, Practice
description: SIXTY is not the new 40. Fifty isnt either. Your lung capacity in late-middle age is in steady decline, as are the fast-twitch muscle fibers that provide power and speed. Your heart capacity has been ebbing for decades. Your sight has been getting worse, your other senses, too, and this, along with a gradually receding ability to integrate information you are absorbing and to then issue motor commands, means your balance is not what it used to be. (Your flattening arches arent helping.) Your prefrontal cortex  where the concentrating and deciding gets done  has been shrinking for some time, perhaps since you graduated from college. More of your career (more of your life) is behind you than in front of you. Do not kid yourself about this. You are milling in the anteroom of the aged.

title: Ben Foster Brings His Beast Mode to A Streetcar Named Desire
description: Last week, an ape sat eating his bacon and eggs at a Dumbo cafe. An extremely polite ape. An ape who asked if he could please leave the tip.

title: The Pros and Cons of Using a Robot as an Investment Adviser
description: SHOULD you trust your hard-earned retirement dollars to a robot?

title: Warning to a Samaritan
description: Dear Diary:

title: Rovi Buys TiVo in $1.1 Billion Deal
description: As television moves to the cloud, two companies are coming together to try to find the silver lining.

title: Money, Race and Success: How Your School District Compares
description: Sixth graders in the richest school districts are four grade levels ahead of children in the poorest districts.

title: U.S. Denounces Chinese Law Restricting Foreign Organizations
description: BEIJING  American leaders and interest groups have sharply criticized a new law in China aimed at controlling and limiting the work of foreign nongovernmental organizations in the country, saying it will lead to the deterioration of ties between the Chinese and people from abroad.

title: At the N.F.L. Draft, Ezekiel Elliott Brings Back the Crop Top
description: In recent years, the first day of the N.F.L. draft has turned into something of a fashion moment, with players (and their families) posing on the red carpet, often in tailored suiting, and best and worst of the N.F.L. draft fashion lists circulating online.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Alan Cumming
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the actor, director and writer Alan Cumming, who shares his list exclusively with T. (From May 1-22, One Grand will host a pop-up shop at Industry City in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.)

title: 1916: General Townshend Surrenders at Kut
description: LONDON  After holding out 143 days at Kut-el-Amara for relief, General Townshend has surrendered. Lack of food and lack of ammunition forced the British to capitulate to the Turkish force which had surrounded them since the first days of December last.

title: At Small Colleges, Harsh Lessons About Cash Flow
description: RINDGE, N.H.  Amber Jackson remembers the moment she learned that both her majors  dance and math  had been cut from the program at Franklin Pierce University. She immediately called her mother, whose reaction was: They can do that?

title: Economic Gravity in the Oil Industry: What Goes Up Comes Down
description: ITS not rocket science. What shoots up quickly usually comes back to earth.

title: Ted Cruzs Father Worked With Supplements Maker Sued by Investors
description: By 1990, the oil-services company Rafael Cruz had founded with his wife had collapsed. Their properties had been foreclosed on; they declared bankruptcy.

title: Forging a Path for Women, Deep Into Indias Sacred Shrines
description: NASHIK DISTRICT, India  When the priests learned to their horror that a woman had somehow slipped into the holy shrine of Shani Shingnapur Temple to pray late last year, they immediately began an elaborate purification ceremony, dousing the deity in yogurt and honey.

title: Sallie Mae Now Offers Education Loans to Parents, Too
description: SALLIE MAE this week became the latest lender to make private loans available to parents who want to help pay for their childs higher education.

title: A New Generations Anger Resounds From a Packed Plaza in Paris
description: PARIS  There are denunciations of speciesism, of multinational corporations, capitalism, G.M.O.s, the police and nuclear power. There are pleas for Julian Assange and African workers. There are drumming, guitar playing, free soup and 20-somethings swigging beer.

title: Helicopter Crashes Off Norway, Leaving No Signs of Survivors
description: OSLO  A helicopter carrying 13 people from an oil field in the North Sea to the city of Bergen crashed on Friday off the Norwegian coast, and there were no signs of survivors.

title: What Are Bathroom Rights?
description: Many states have legislation pending that would make it illegal for transgender people to choose which public bathroom they use based on their gender identity.

title: Robert Carlock on Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt, Identity Politics and Big Biscotti
description: Once mostly anonymous, the producers who oversee top television series have sometimes become as well known as the actors who star in them. On occasion, The New York Times will pose questions from readers (and some of our own) to notable showrunners.

title: Marlins All-Star Dee Gordon Suspended 80 Games for Doping
description: Dee Gordon, the reigning National League batting champion and an All-Star second baseman for the Miami Marlins, was suspended for 80 games early Friday because he tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs. Major League Baseball announced the suspension after the Marlins victory in Los Angeles, saying that Gordon had tested positive for exogenous testosterone and clostebol.

title: How Youre Making Facebook a Money Machine
description: What you do when waiting for the bus or avoiding work goes a long way to explaining a tectonic shift in business and media.

title: 1941: Roosevelt Asserts Right to Patrol Seas Around British Isles
description: WASHINGTON  President Roosevelt declared this afternoon that he has full authority to send American warships into waters around the British Isles and into other combat zones from which American merchant ships are barred under provisions of the neutrality law.

title: 2 Charged With Aiding Brussels Attacks Suspect Appear in London Court
description: LONDON  Two men living in Birmingham, England, appeared on Friday in court after being charged with supplying money to Mohamed Abrini, the man in the hat who confessed to having accompanied two suicide bombers to Brussels Airport last month.

title: Connectography, by Parag Khanna
description: CONNECTOGRAPHYMapping the Future of Global CivilizationBy Parag KhannaIllustrated. 466 pp. Random House. $30.

title: Maurice Issermans Continental Divide
description: CONTINENTAL DIVIDEA History of American MountaineeringBy Maurice IssermanIllustrated. 436 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $28.95.

title: He Said He Was 17, but High School Basketball Player May Be Closer to 30
description: A South Sudan immigrant and standout basketball player at a Catholic high school in Canada has been arrested after it was revealed that his true age is not 17, but closer to 29, the authorities said.

title: Nicholas Guyatts Bind Us Apart
description: BIND US APARTHow Enlightened Americans Invented Racial SegregationBy Nicholas GuyattIllustrated. 403 pp. Basic Books. $29.99.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Limits of Military Power

title: Chinese Appear Underwhelmed by Under Armour Knockoff
description: HONG KONG  A famous sportswear brand worn by the likes of the New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady and his wife, the model Gisele Bndchen, has a savvy new competitor in one of its hottest markets, China.

title: Valeants New Skipper Is on the Same Tack
description: When a deeply troubled company replaces its chief executive, it makes sense to expect the new C.E.O. to bring a fresh take to its operations. A clean sweep, so to speak.

title: Whit Channels Jane
description: The filmmaker Whit Stillmans 1990 debut, Metropolitan, about a group of young upper-class New Yorkers, immediately established a tonal kinship between the writer-director and Jane Austen. In The Times, Vincent Canby called the movie a comedy of manners of a very high order, and wrote: Like Jane Austen, Mr. Stillman severely restricts his characters field of action, which is sometimes combat.

title: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana Endorses Ted Cruz as Primary Nears
description: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana said Friday that he would vote for Senator Ted Cruz, handing Mr. Cruz a much-needed endorsement before the states crucial primary next week.

title: Found: Walt Whitmans Guide to Manly Health
description: In 1858, when Walt Whitman sat down to write a manifesto on healthy living, he came up with advice that might not seem out of place in an infomercial today.

title: Walt Whitman: Manly Health and Training
description: Part one of 13 in a nearly 47,000-word journalistic series called Manly Health and Training that had been lost for more than 150 years.

title: The Brazen Age, by David Reid
description: THE BRAZEN AGENew York City and the American Empire: Politics, Art, and BohemiaBy David ReidIllustrated. 504 pp. Pantheon Books. $30.

title: Trump Rally in California Turns Violent
description: Clashes grew more heated on Thursday as the night went on outside an event for Donald J. Trump in Costa Mesa, Calif.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: And Now, I Unfollow Thee
description: Noah Masterson, a web marketing manager in Austin, Tex., is like the Marie Kondo of Twitter. He keeps it tidy. I just unfollowed about 20 people to get down to an even 400, he said. It felt really good.

title: The Midnight Watch, by David Dyer
description: THE MIDNIGHT WATCHA Novel of the Titanic and the CalifornianBy David Dyer323 pp. St. Martins Press. $26.99.

title: Medivation Rejects Takeover Bid From Sanofi
description: Medivation, which makes drugs for prostate cancer, has a message for the French drug company Sanofi: The $9.3 billion cash takeover offer was not good enough.

title: Zappa Plays Zappa Pits Zappa vs. Zappa
description: For a decade, Dweezil Zappa, a son of the rock star Frank Zappa and a noted guitarist in his own right, has been paying tribute to his fathers music under the name Zappa Plays Zappa. The project, which features exacting performances of Frank Zappas famously complex music, has toured the world and won a Grammy.

title: The Brilliant Red Salmon Thats Worth the Splurge
description: At the Pike Place Market in Seattle, its the glistening, freshly caught salmon piled high that youll notice first. The fishmongers are jolly, and sales are brisk.

title: Flights of Memory (Not Just Birds) at the Barclay Hotel
description: The InterContinental New York Barclay  or the Barclay, as any New Yorker would call the hotel  is to reopen Friday in the Grand Central area of Midtown Manhattan after a 20-month renovation. It is not one of the most famous hotels in the city, but to judge from readers responses to a Building Blocks column about the renovation, it is among the most fondly regarded.

title: Detroit Resurrected, by Nathan Bomey
description: DETROIT RESURRECTEDTo Bankruptcy and BackBy Nathan Bomey297 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $27.95.

title: Shopping Guide: Outdoor Furniture
description: The interior designer Samuel Amoia lives in Manhattan, but these days his thoughts often stray to the beach. Thats because one of his largest projects is Itzana, a resort and residential development in Belize opening later this year.

title: Sports Detectives Tracks Down Famed Memorabilia
